ðŸ”—hpiinstruments <aaronhunt@...>

2/14/2010 10:54:48 PM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Mike Battaglia wrote:
> It isn't that every single dyad has to sound good in
> isolation, it's that you will perceive the harmonic relationship
> between each dyad in isolation as well as that of the whole chord.

Well, sort of. I can can transcribe the exact voices I hear (or
think I hear) in a sonority, which shows that I can perceive
all the voices in a chord and understand all the relationships
between them in a combinatorial sort of way. But I don't see
any way that justifies this notion that in JI 16:21 or 20:27
make a chord unsatisfactory because all the intervals aren't
'pure'. Those intervals can sound absolutely right *in the
chord*. I'm pretty sure I just caught a phrase in a broader
discussion that didn't really ask for this particular input,
and probably nobody is really arguing anything here, so
again I take my leave, and bid you ...

adieu,
AAH
=====

ðŸ”—Carl Lumma <carl@...>

2/14/2010 11:21:56 PM

Aaron Hunt wrote:

> Well, a chord as an isolated thing is the simultaneous sounding
> of more than 2 tones. Why argue that every interval from every
> tone to every other tone in the chord has to sound good in
> isolation, as if they weren't sounding together as a chord?

It's true that the best dissonance measure for chords would
work on entire chords as gestalts, and we've made some progress
on this (mostly Paul Erlich's pioneering work). But almost all
time-tested and ready dissonance measures are dyadic. The
question arises as to whether they can also be applied to larger
chords at all. The answer is yes (with a few provisions) *if*
one considers all dyads in a chord. For example, take

1/1 6/5 3/2 7/4 vs. 1/1 7/6 3/2 7/4

Their dyads measured from 1/1 are roughly the same, but the
former chord has a 35/24 fifth hiding it it, and it certainly
sounds more dissonant to me!

> It doesn't make much sense. The basic rules of counterpoint
> don't even require that.

?

> Now, voice he chord differently, in a different inversion or
> different register, open voicing, etc. and you may want to
> change the tuning again,

Right. And knowing that is... half the battle. We can also
develop chords that don't require such care and feeding, for
those musicians who desire that flexibility (which we enjoy,
for the most part, in 12-ET).

> The chords sound good and that's good enough for me.

The other point is that there are chords that sound good
which you wouldn't discover drawing on just intonation alone.

-Carl

ðŸ”—Daniel Forró <dan.for@...>

2/14/2010 11:23:40 PM

On 15 Feb 2010, at 1:59 PM, Mike Battaglia wrote:

>
> The question is, what makes a chord a chord? When you're playing a > polytonal mix of two major chords, is it really one big chord, or > two separate chords? The fact that we "conceive" of a certain > harmonic structure as a singular unit - a "chord" - is a cognitive > decision, not a psychoacoustic one.
>
>

When you talk just about two chord mixed together, call it bichord. Bitonality it would be in the case two tonalities are used together with all their internal relations and chord functions, to be understood clearly as distinctive keys, tonalities.

Polytonality means to combine a lot tonalities.

And concerning understanding the chord combinations, it depends how they are used and arranged, that mean it's context sensitive. If you will have C-E-G played by strings, and D-F#-A by horns, it will be clearly heard as two chords. Even in very narrow voicing C-D-E-F#-G-A, which is in fact cluster. If you will arrange the same cluster this way: C-E-A in horns, D-F#-G in strings, chord A-C-E will be heard as main.
If you will use thirdal structure D-F#-A-C-E-G, which is in fact D11 chord, it will be heard as one chord on the piano, or in another one timbre sound. But again you can divide both triad to different timbres, and support bichordal structure...
If you will make from it quartal chord E-A-D-G-C-F#, it will be heard as one quartal chord. But again you can arrange it so, that E-G-C will be in one timbre, A-D-F# in another one, then you will support bichordality. This time it will be more difficult because of wide voicing.

You can create quintal, sextal, septimal chords from it... and their combinations... So there's much more chords which can be created from these six tones, each of them can have different intevallic structure and sound character. Add arranging to it and you get almost unlimited possibilities.

Daniel Forro

ðŸ”—Daniel Forró <dan.for@...>

2/14/2010 11:25:55 PM

Same opinion here.

Daniel Forro

On 15 Feb 2010, at 3:14 PM, hpiinstruments wrote:

>
> Well, a chord as an isolated thing is the simultaneous sounding
> of more than 2 tones. Why argue that every interval from every
> tone to every other tone in the chord has to sound good in
> isolation, as if they weren't sounding together as a chord? It
> doesn't make much sense. The basic rules of counterpoint don't
> even require that. Things work fine in 3 parts between upper
> voices that wouldn't work in two parts. Both those tunings I
> gave for A:C:D:G sound "wicked good". Who cares if there is a
> septimal fourth in one of them that would sound wrong in
> isolation. It's not in isolation. It's in the chord. Now, voice
> the chord differently, in a different inversion or different
> register, open voicing, etc. and you may want to change the
> tuning again, but there are always a few tunings to find for
> any chord in JI. Even the Pythagoren version of that chord
> sounds great: 27:32:36:48 It's all harmonics. However
> you want to tune it, they all fall somewhere in some series,
> pointing to some root, somewhere, and it makes sense as
> a chord. The rest is all supposition, which doesn't pass muster
> IMO. It's a matter of seconds to sit down and play all three
> versions of that chord one after the other on a TPX keyboard,
> and they are all beautiful, and all sound different. Now if
> you were going to orchestrate the 16:21 for two trombones
> and give the rest to a flute choir then I'd call you insane,
> and musicians would never play it that way, intentionally.
> Maybe that's where you're going with this. If you build
> chords of varied timbre then you just have to use common
> sense and good taste to make it sound right. That's
> getting into the art of orchestration. OK well I've gone on
> enough about this. I do beg your pardon; I don't wish to
> speculate on ear / brain mechanisms. The chords sound
> good and that's good enough for me.
>
> Cheerio,
> AAH
> =====
>

ðŸ”—Kalle <kalleaho@...>

2/15/2010 2:47:29 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "hpiinstruments" <aaronhunt@...> wrote:
>
> Well, a chord as an isolated thing is the simultaneous sounding
> of more than 2 tones. Why argue that every interval from every
> tone to every other tone in the chord has to sound good in
> isolation, as if they weren't sounding together as a chord? It
> doesn't make much sense.

Aaron,

I didn't argue that every dyad must sound good in isolation. Mike and
I were discussing whether JI math can model diatonic hearing. I was
trying to show that it can't. The fact that you tuned the D:G in
A:C:D:G as 20:27 and still hear it as a diatonic fourth just proves
my point.

Kalle Aho

ðŸ”—Kalle <kalleaho@...>

2/15/2010 7:29:22 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...> wrote:

> > The hearing of that particular harmonic structure is indeed
> > "modelled" quite well with rational number math. But although
> > integer ratios have an important role in the explanation of
> > psychoacoustic consonance and root perception I suspect that the
> > brain doesn't literally use rational number math in the
> > perception and cognition of music. Not only is this a bit hard to
> > believe but JI doesn't even generally work as a theory of music
> > perception because there are many commonly used chords that
> > cannot be analyzed in terms of JI. Play the chord A:C:D:G in some
> > meantone tuning, for example 12-equal. A:C is heard as a minor
> > 3rd, A:D and D:G are heard as 4ths and C:G is heard as a 5th. The
> > chord sounds perfectly natural and commonplace but it
> > nevertheless cannot be tuned in JI so that all those intervals
> > are pure! Ergo, diatonic hearing and structure cannot be modelled
> > with JI math and this makes the claim that the brain analyzes
> > music in terms of JI dubious.
>
> That's a great example. I figuring out why that chord works is the
> same as why my chord progression works.
>
> Yeah, A:C:D:G (and some other even worse chords I've sound) screw it
> up. But what I think is happening is the same thing that's happening
> with C-Ev-G: the Ev will tend to "flip" back and forth between Eb
> and E, and in this case, the C, D, and G will "flip" back and forth
> between C:D:G and C+:D+:G+. However, not only is C:D:G/C+:D+:G+ a
> much more subtle change than Eb/E - I don't think many listeners
> could recognize such a perceptual change if they hear it.

Personally I don't hear such duck/rabbit or Necker cube like flipping
at all.

> Since it's easy for us to put a label on the way we're perceiving
> the C-Ev-G example - as the first dyad being "major" (5/4)
> vs "minor" - that example is relatively easy to figure out.
> However - we're not used to a system of tuning in which 32/27 and
> 6/5 are different intervals, nor in which 4/3 and 27/20 are
> different intervals, nor in which 16/9 and 9/5 are different
> intervals. So my theory is that our modes of perception for these
> intervals are constantly shifting without us really being aware of
> this. Alternatively, or perhaps it's more that our 12-tet
> experience of a minor seventh just is 16/9 and 9/5 all smushed
> together.
>
> So I guess in the end I really am saying what you're saying, but in
> a slightly different way. We do perceive music in terms of more
> "diatonic" pitch sets and intervals - at least for now, since that's
> what we're used to - but these diatonic pitch sets can then be
> analyzed in terms of JI. Each equal tempered interval can map back
> to more than one JI pitch, but mentally, schematically, we just
> lump all of these possible JI functions into the same schema for
> the chord.

We could model the diatonic way of hearing with 5-limit JI math but
with the additional rule that (81/80)*r=r, syntonic comma being
an "identity element". But this is potentially misleading because one
might then think that "syntonically equivalent" ratios are actually
heard (flipping) when one hears an interval in the context of music
tuned to meantone. But it can't be so because there is an infinity
of syntonically equivalent ratios. It would have to stop at
some "depth" and I suspect that most diatonic listeners don't hear
much depth at all. Perhaps somebody who has deeply internalized JI
pitch relations would hear intervals as flipping all the time when
listening to music tuned to meantone but in a sense he/she would be
hearing the music in a "wrong" way.

> > > When you said this, you mentioned that the brain
> > > doesn't "remember" previous frequency ratios and that's why
> > > comma pumps don't cause you to become psychotic.
> >
> > No, I didn't say that. Of course the brain remembers previous
> > intervals to an extent. Tempered comma pump progressions sound
> > fine because we hear them diatonically. There is even a diatonic
> > math that models this but it cannot be based on JI. It is
> > actually the JI comma pumps that sound weird and "unnatural" to
> > intonationally naive western listeners! How can that be if the
> > brain represents music in terms of JI?
>
> Well, one thing's for sure - you're absolutely right about that.
> But how does the diatonic math work? It can't just be arbitrary, JI
> has to be involved -somewhere- down the line.

Actually anybody who is interested in non-meantone temperaments or
composes JI music where the syntonic comma functions as a distinct
interval *assumes* that syntonic equivalence is arbitrary i.e. a
matter of choice. For them, syntonic equivalence is not some
"eternal axiom of musicke" but just one (valid) way of hearing.

How is JI involved then?

For arguments sake, take the 12-equal C major scale as a given. Now
don't think of its' fifths, minor thirds and major thirds as 2:3s,
5:6s and 4:5s but simply as 12-equal fifths, minor thirds and major
thirds. After all, they aren't acoustically 2:3s, 5:6s or 4:5s! Try
to think of them as intervals of their own, not as approximations.
D:A really is a 12-equal fifth even if JI C major scale doesn't have
a pure 2:3 fifth there. There are structural properties, intervals
and chords that don't exist in JI and they are really there
acoustically!

The (relatively mediocre) consonance of 12-equal intervals and chords
is explained by their proximity to purely tuned intervals and chords.
Also 12-equal pitches can form approximate harmonic series segments
which explains the perception of roots. I believe this is the only
way JI is involved.

Searching for alternative temperaments often starts with a JI lattice
of pitches. Then some commas are tempered out and the lattice
is "collapsed" to lower dimensions. Even if this is done, one should
resist the temptation to think that the JI lattice is somehow still
there in the resulting temperament. After all, you can start from the
opposite direction and find temperaments from equal divisions.

Kalle Aho

ðŸ”—Michael <djtrancendance@...>

2/15/2010 7:37:12 AM

Kalle>"A:C is heard as a minor 3rd, A:D and D:G are heard as 4ths and C:G is heard
as a 5th. The chord sounds perfectly natural and commonplace but it
nevertheless cannot be tuned in JI so that all those intervals
are pure!"

How low odd-limit do you believe a chord have to be before it is considered pure, though?

I still have this odd feeling that the human brain does not need everything to fit pure JI, but rather to fit a certain level of periodicity (or something very close to it)...and that 5-limit JI, for example, is often way under that threshold leaving much room for growth in scale complexity.

ðŸ”—caleb morgan <calebmrgn@...>

Thanks, everybody.

So far, for the production of microtonal sound, it looks like I'm most
interested in what Chris Vaisvil has suggested:

http://www.pianoteq.com/

http://www.cakewalk.com/Products/Z3TA/default.asp

Garritan Personal Orchestra 4.0 - ok microsupport

Chris, do these work on Mac OS X, and will they be usable with Logic?

What are some others? Anybody?

for Logic, I've already constructed a pitch-bend conversion chart, and
did a quick study to see if it sounded ok. (It did.)

It's available here: Go to the 'Stuff' folder, it's called 'Pitch-
Bend Conversion Chart'.

I like individual pitch-bends, because that way of working doesn't
lock me into any tuning at any moment, whatsoever.

http://www.box.net/files/0/f/17990454/Composer_Caleb_Morgan_Advocates_for_Audio_Surveillance#/
files/0/f/17990454/
Composer_Caleb_Morgan_Advocates_for_Audio_Surveillance

I tried pasting the pitch-bend chart in this message, but it didn't
format right.

--So, I used pitch-bends in Logic, and I use virtual instruments, such
as the ones Chris has suggested.

--I get Melodyne--retuning pitch-by-pitch by hand is just fine. (I'm
an old yankee scrimshaw type of guy.)

--Next, I need to investigate something like Scala--mostly for thepurpose of visualizing the advanced tunings

you folks are talking about.

--One final question for now: Carl, at one point you suggested some
virtual synths that will do microtuning.

Are there any that will work with Logic that will allow 'any-note-per-
octave' tunings?

Caleb

ðŸ”—hpiinstruments <aaronhunt@...>

2/15/2010 7:58:51 AM

> --- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "hpiinstruments" <aaronhunt@> wrote:
> >
> > Well, a chord as an isolated thing is the simultaneous sounding
> > of more than 2 tones. Why argue that every interval from every
> > tone to every other tone in the chord has to sound good in
> > isolation, as if they weren't sounding together as a chord? It
> > doesn't make much sense.
>
> Aaron,
>
> I didn't argue that every dyad must sound good in isolation. Mike and
> I were discussing whether JI math can model diatonic hearing. I was
> trying to show that it can't. The fact that you tuned the D:G in
> A:C:D:G as 20:27 and still hear it as a diatonic fourth just proves
> my point.
>
> Kalle Aho

Hi Kalle.

Thanks, I suspected a larger context for that remark of
which I was unaware, so I'm sorry if I was barking up
the wrong tree : )

But, since I'm here now, how does the claim that 20:27,
is still heard as a fourth even though dissonant (in my
nomenclature it's L4, Large 4th) 'prove' your point that
JI math doesn't model diatonic hearing? I think if anything
it is evidence that 20:27, L4 is heard in the same interval
family as 3:4, P4, and such evidence tends in *favor* of
using JI for interval measurement, that it can adequately
account for interval categories and families at least.

Claims that we 'hear in JI' are to me just wrong, and on
the wrong track. JI is useful as a simple means to measure
and classify intervals. Numbers are a measuring tool, and
nothing more. The only 'rules' to be gathered from
psychoacoustics tell us that what we hear is a very
complicated and subjective thing, and it's definitely
not the same thing either as numbers or the symbolic
representations of those numbers by notation. There
are many spooky correspondences between numbers
and what we hear, for sure, but IMO they are to JI what
relativity is to Newtonian mechanics... not well worded,
but I think you get my point.

Cheers,
AAH
=====

ðŸ”—Michael <djtrancendance@...>

2/15/2010 7:53:15 AM

Aaron> How's that? I immediately see at least two easy ways to tune the chord A:C:D:G in JI.
> (1) 15:18:20:27

Carl>"We have to consider all the dyads in the chord. In tuning 1, D to G is 20:27"
What's so wolf about that? Those two notes don't sound so odd together to me...27/20 IE 1.35 is obviously not as relaxed as 1.3333 but still quite confident and aligned sounding (at least to me)...what makes that dyad supposedly so bad?

ðŸ”—Chris Vaisvil <chrisvaisvil@...>

2/15/2010 8:08:44 AM

Z3ta+ does not come in an audio unit format, the others do.

I know little about Macs - my presumption is OSX and audio unit
compatibility means these will work with Logic.

An alternative soft synth could be Native Instruments Absynth. - it comes in
a Mac version (my son uses it on a Mac) and takes scala's "gly' format
output supposedly - I've not tried to microtune it yet.

Chris

ðŸ”—Kalle <kalleaho@...>

2/15/2010 8:16:11 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Michael <djtrancendance@...> wrote:
>
> Kalle>"A:C is heard as a minor 3rd, A:D and D:G are heard as 4ths
> and C:G is heard as a 5th. The chord sounds perfectly natural and
> commonplace but it nevertheless cannot be tuned in JI so that all
> those intervals are pure!"
>
> How low odd-limit do you believe a chord have to be before it
> is considered pure, though?

I don't have an opinion about that. Something like 4:11 may already
sound a bit fishy on its' own but in a 4:5:6:7:9:11 chord it sounds
beautiful. But considering my chord example the consensus is that
JI perfect 5ths are 2:3s, JI perfect 4ths are 3:4s and JI minor
3rds are 5:6s. One may consider 20:27 a type of JI fourth but it is
not the pure perfect 4th.

> I still have this odd feeling that the human brain does not need
> everything to fit pure JI, but rather to fit a certain level of
> periodicity (or something very close to it)...and that 5-limit JI,
> for example, is often way under that threshold leaving much room
> for growth in scale complexity.

Well there is this periodicity in Aaron's 15:18:20:27 and it indeed
is just fine way to tune A:C:D:G. My point was that because 4:3 and
20:27 are different ratios but still function as perfect fourths in
diatonic context JI without the additional assumption of "syntonic
equivalence" doesn't model diatonic hearing.

Kalle Aho

ðŸ”—Chris Vaisvil <chrisvaisvil@...>

2/15/2010 8:24:07 AM

It looks like a Linux version is out there - boot camp and Ubuntu might
work.
Most scale files (all?) are text so translation should not be an issue.

ðŸ”—Kalle <kalleaho@...>

2/15/2010 8:32:31 AM

Aaron,

what I mean by the claim that JI doesn't model diatonic hearing is
that a diatonic interval (or pitch class) doesn't map to a single
rational number but to an infinity of such numbers. When ratios
differing by syntonic commas are put under families or equivalence
classes those families of numbers indeed model diatonic hearing. But
JI on its' own without this "syntonic equivalence" is a poor and
unnecessarily complicated model for diatonic hearing and doesn't
reflect the way our brain processes music (tuned in meantone).

Kalle Aho

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "hpiinstruments" <aaronhunt@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Kalle.
>
> Thanks, I suspected a larger context for that remark of
> which I was unaware, so I'm sorry if I was barking up
> the wrong tree : )
>
> But, since I'm here now, how does the claim that 20:27,
> is still heard as a fourth even though dissonant (in my
> nomenclature it's L4, Large 4th) 'prove' your point that
> JI math doesn't model diatonic hearing? I think if anything
> it is evidence that 20:27, L4 is heard in the same interval
> family as 3:4, P4, and such evidence tends in *favor* of
> using JI for interval measurement, that it can adequately
> account for interval categories and families at least.
>
> Claims that we 'hear in JI' are to me just wrong, and on
> the wrong track. JI is useful as a simple means to measure
> and classify intervals. Numbers are a measuring tool, and
> nothing more. The only 'rules' to be gathered from
> psychoacoustics tell us that what we hear is a very
> complicated and subjective thing, and it's definitely
> not the same thing either as numbers or the symbolic
> representations of those numbers by notation. There
> are many spooky correspondences between numbers
> and what we hear, for sure, but IMO they are to JI what
> relativity is to Newtonian mechanics... not well worded,
> but I think you get my point.
>
> Cheers,
> AAH
> =====
>

ðŸ”—Michael <djtrancendance@...>

2/15/2010 8:40:37 AM

>"When ratios differing by syntonic commas are put under families or equivalence
classes those families of numbers indeed model diatonic hearing."

If I understand this correctly, where are these "ranges" of frequencies near ratios....these ranges where the mind has a clear perception of a diatonic pitch?
And....how would we use this information to choose pitches...how would it differ from, say, de-tuning around JI ratios?

ðŸ”—hpiinstruments <aaronhunt@...>

2/15/2010 9:02:27 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Carl Lumma" <carl@...> wrote:
> The question arises as to whether they can also be applied to
> larger chords at all. The answer is yes (with a few provisions) *if*
> one considers all dyads in a chord. For example, take
>
> 1/1 6/5 3/2 7/4 vs. 1/1 7/6 3/2 7/4
>
> Their dyads measured from 1/1 are roughly the same, but the
> former chord has a 35/24 fifth hiding it it, and it certainly
> sounds more dissonant to me!

Yes, but this still doesn't suggest that *every single* dyad
has to be some ideal low number ratio or the chord is somehow
invalid. It only suggests that common sense should be used
when building a chord in JI if you want it to sound good.

The tunings I gave were:

(1) 5-Limit, using A:+C 5:6 and A:+G 5:9
(2) 7-Limit, using A:~C 6:7 and A:~G 4:7
(3) 3-Limit, using A:C 27:32 and A:G 9:16

In each chord A:D is tuned 3:4 and a P5 exists between
the 3rd and 7th:

(1) P5 +C:+G
(2) P5 ~C:~G
(3) P5 C:G

I would not mix 5:6 and 4:7 in the same chord, exactly
for the reason that it sounds like sh*t, since the P5 which
is begging to exist between the 3rd and 7th becomes a
Narrow 5th (N5) +C:~G 24:35 that is essentially diminished,
close to the Wide diminished 5th (Wd5) 9:13 and
enharmonic with a Large augmented 4th (La4) 11:16.
Likewise, I wouldn't mix 6:7 and 5:9 in the chord since
the opposite effect takes place, giving a Wide 5th (W5)
~C:+G

> > It doesn't make much sense. The basic rules of counterpoint
> > don't even require that.
>
> ?
>

You apparently missed the next sentence I wrote:

"Things work fine in 3 parts between upper
voices that wouldn't work in two parts."

And that can be extended from 3 to 4 parts, etc.
Things that sound good in 3 parts don't by requirement
have to sound good in 2 parts if you took one part away.
When writing in 3 parts you do not have to write in
such a way that if some Joe Schmo picked up your
score and said "bwah ha ha!, I'm going to eliminate the bass
line and THEN we'll see just how good this guy's music is!"
It doesn't work that way. Analyzing / writing the counterpoint
requires interaction of all the voices present, and in many
cases taking a voice away will make something sound
wrong and that's why there are different rules for 2 part
writing than there are for 3 part writing. Anybody who
writes contrapuntal music knows this!

> > Now, voice he chord differently, in a different inversion or
> > different register, open voicing, etc. and you may want to
> > change the tuning again,
>
> Right. And knowing that is... half the battle. We can also
> develop chords that don't require such care and feeding, for
> those musicians who desire that flexibility (which we enjoy,
> for the most part, in 12-ET).

Of course, and that's useful for sure.

>
> > The chords sound good and that's good enough for me.
>
> The other point is that there are chords that sound good
> which you wouldn't discover drawing on just intonation alone.
>
> -Carl
>

Of course. This goes back to the 3 kinds of correctness I
summarized in a different thread: fifths-cycle, JI, ETs.
Chords derived from any of these or any mixture of basic
principles inherent in these will have something about it
that sounds 'correct'.

Cheers,
AAH
=====

ðŸ”—hpiinstruments <aaronhunt@...>

2/15/2010 9:08:19 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Kalle" wrote:
> Aaron,
>
> what I mean by the claim that JI doesn't model diatonic
> hearing is that a diatonic interval (or pitch class) doesn't
> map to a single rational number but to an infinity of such
> numbers.

Ah, of course. OK.

> When ratios differing by syntonic commas are put under
> families or equivalence classes those families of numbers
> indeed model diatonic hearing. But JI on its' own without
> this "syntonic equivalence" is a poor and unnecessarily
> complicated model for diatonic hearing and doesn't
> reflect the way our brain processes music (tuned in
> meantone).
>
> Kalle Aho

OK.

I don't know about 'diatonic hearing', but diatonicism
certainly comes first from the fifths-cycle, is secondarily
is reinforced by JI, and thus works its way into ETs.

Cheers,
AAH
=====

Aaron Hunt>Of course. This goes back to the 3 kinds of correctness I
>summarized in a different thread: fifths-cycle, JI, ETs.

Could some of you imagine ways to gain a sense of resolve-consonance in scale that have a lot to do with a concept not included in these three?
I'll agree fifths-cycles and JI have a lot to do with the correctness of an awful lot of scales. Though I wonder if some will argue circles of thirds, not-TET/non-mean-tone-tempering, and otherwise can have just as much of a place as possible ways to make scales with several possible resolved-sounding chords and/or natural sounding melodies.

ðŸ”—Torsten Anders <torsten.anders@...>

2/15/2010 10:32:07 AM

On 15.02.2010, at 15:56, caleb morgan wrote:
> Are there any that will work with Logic that will allow 'any-note-> per-octave' tunings?

As mentioned before, there are a few approaches in principle for this in MIDI-land (supported by different softwynths). ALl have their obvious advantages and disadvantages

- Use a single MIDI channel and tune the 128 available notes freely
- Use multiple MIDI channels
- Change the tuning on the fly

Best wishes,
Torsten

--

Interdisciplinary Centre for Computer Music Research
University of Plymouth
Office: +44-1752-586219
Private: +44-1752-558917
http://strasheela.sourceforge.net
http://www.torsten-anders.de

12 notes per octave, for example.

restrictions.

I'm not interested in virtual synths like those.

synths, and instrument emulators that allow any arbitrary tuning.

knows how

ðŸ”—Petr Parízek <p.parizek@...>

2/15/2010 11:25:09 AM

Aaron wrote:

>Of course. This goes back to the 3 kinds of correctness I
>summarized in a different thread: fifths-cycle, JI, ETs.

#1. Do you classify one particular tuning into one particular of these categories, or do you mean that one tuning can belong into all of them at a time? The 1D temperament of 31-EDO can be used as a 2D meantone chain of fiths, which actually approximates 3D 5-limit JI.

#2. If only tunings belonging to one of these categories should be musically "useful", then what about those like tetracot or semisixths or other 2D tunings which I've admired for such a long time? Maybe I'd recommend you looking at the RTF document I saved in the Tuning Files (although I still haven't updated the error in it yet).

Petr

is "off-topic," then

replies, some of which were from you.

-Mike

On Mon, Feb 15, 2010 at 1:41 AM, Carl Lumma <carl@...> wrote:

ðŸ”—Michael <djtrancendance@...>

2/15/2010 12:22:30 PM

Mike B>"If trying to figure out the psychoacoustic properties of temperaments
is "off-topic," then
a) Doesn't sound like much really is on topic"

My general view (for just about anything musical) is as follows. No matter how justified the excuse to censor something for lack of correctness on any musical forum...what will quite likely happen is people overlooking the list will think "looks like this guy/censored can't disprove the validity of this in detail, otherwise why would he/she suddenly label so many things off-topic?"
I admit I have been guilty of jumping the gun and saying something is dead wrong or perfectly right at first glance as well only to find otherwise later on.
----------------------------------------
Now I try my best to be very careful and remember tuning is ultimately part of music and music is highly subjective in many ways. Otherwise there would be one formula to make songs everyone likes (and we could sell it to a major label for some ridiculous sum of money...or, better yet, take them down by making it 'open-source'"). :-D

And if anything truly has virtually no applications or value it need not be "censored out": it will simply generate less and less interest.
Such as was true with a scale I 'made' years ago which turned out to just be the x/16 harmonic series. Meanwhile another scale people at first jumped at as being absurd, the "Silver section" scale actually got brought back by others even after I abandoned it.

It seems obvious to me we should rate ideas on here as more/less likely to work rather than "right" or "wrong"...because, ultimately, some initially conceived as "more wrong" ideas may prove themselves "more right" and vice-versa. Some ideas, like JI, are always going to be around b/c so many people think they are "more right/applicable than wrong/inapplicable"...but that doesn't mean other ideas instantly become "off-topic" or can't grow into something equally useful.

The best way to make progress in tuning, IMVHO, is to keep your mind open and let things prove (or disprove) themselves. And, IMVHO, psychoacoustic properties of temperament sounds like something that could easily become "more right" within the subject of tuning if people work on it and are allowed to do so in peace. So why not?

ðŸ”—hpiinstruments <aaronhunt@...>

2/15/2010 12:36:41 PM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Petr Parízek <p.parizek@...> wrote:
> Aaron wrote:
> >Of course. This goes back to the 3 kinds of correctness I
> >summarized in a different thread: fifths-cycle, JI, ETs.
>
> #1. Do you classify one particular tuning into one particular
> of these categories, or do you mean that one tuning can
> belong into all of them at a time? The 1D temperament of
> 31-EDO can be used as a 2D meantone chain of fiths, which
> actually approximates 3D 5-limit JI.
>
> #2. If only tunings belonging to one of these categories
> should be musically "useful", then what about those like
> tetracot or semisixths or other 2D tunings which I've
> admired for such a long time? Maybe I'd recommend you
> looking at the RTF document I saved in the Tuning Files
> (although I still haven't updated the error in it yet).

Hi Petr.

The thread where I jumped in is here:
</tuning/topicId_86071.html#86231>

Answer #1: My whole point was that whatever gives an impression
of being obviously right in the tuning can be traced to its similarity
to the simplicities of each of those three things. Any tuning can have
characteristics of any of those things, not just one or another.

For example, 12ET is a very strong tuning for 2 core simplicities:

(1) fifths-cycle: it very closely resembling the cycle of 13 fifths
(2) ETs: it's an ET; all its steps are equal in size

Both of those things sound correct in a general way: a fifths cycle
for its simple constant 3-ness and equal step sizes for the
simple global consistency of structures.

12ET is of course weaker in terms of JI simplicity, since it does
not model low integer JI well; instead it does well with 17 and 19,
and that fact does have great significance for the sound of the
tuning, so it indeed relates to (3) but not as basically as it relates
to (1) and (2).

Answer #2: I've said absolutely nothing about only those categories
being musically "useful". I'm saying those things embody core
simplicities to which all tunings have an inescapable relationship.

I hope what I'm saying is becoming more clear?

Cheers,
AAH
=====

ðŸ”—Carl Lumma <carl@...>

> > larger chords at all. The answer is yes (with a few provisions)
> > *if* one considers all dyads in a chord. For example, take
> >

> >
> > Their dyads measured from 1/1 are roughly the same, but the
> > former chord has a 35/24 fifth hiding it it, and it certainly
> > sounds more dissonant to me!
>

> has to be some ideal low number ratio or the chord is somehow
> invalid.

Yes, I never said that! :)

> > > It doesn't make much sense. The basic rules of counterpoint
> > > don't even require that.

the price of tea in China...

> And that can be extended from 3 to 4 parts, etc.
> Things that sound good in 3 parts don't by requirement
> have to sound good in 2 parts if you took one part away.
> When writing in 3 parts you do not have to write in
> such a way that if some Joe Schmo picked up your
> score and said "bwah ha ha!, I'm going to eliminate the bass
> line and THEN we'll see just how good this guy's music is!"
> It doesn't work that way. Analyzing / writing the counterpoint
> requires interaction of all the voices present, and in many
> cases taking a voice away will make something sound
> wrong and that's why there are different rules for 2 part
> writing than there are for 3 part writing. Anybody who
> writes contrapuntal music knows this!

I thought we were talking about chords. Sometimes they're
played straight, 'comping or whatever. Other times, only
various subsets are heard simultaneously, in contrapuntal
writing. None of this changes the analysis that I can see.

On Mon, Feb 15, 2010 at 10:29 AM, Kalle <kalleaho@...> wrote:
>
>
>
> --- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...> wrote:
>
> > > The hearing of that particular harmonic structure is indeed
> > > "modelled" quite well with rational number math. But although
> > > integer ratios have an important role in the explanation of
> > > psychoacoustic consonance and root perception I suspect that the
> > > brain doesn't literally use rational number math in the
> > > perception and cognition of music. Not only is this a bit hard to
> > > believe but JI doesn't even generally work as a theory of music
> > > perception because there are many commonly used chords that
> > > cannot be analyzed in terms of JI. Play the chord A:C:D:G in some
> > > meantone tuning, for example 12-equal. A:C is heard as a minor
> > > 3rd, A:D and D:G are heard as 4ths and C:G is heard as a 5th. The
> > > chord sounds perfectly natural and commonplace but it
> > > nevertheless cannot be tuned in JI so that all those intervals
> > > are pure! Ergo, diatonic hearing and structure cannot be modelled
> > > with JI math and this makes the claim that the brain analyzes
> > > music in terms of JI dubious.
> >
> > That's a great example. I figuring out why that chord works is the
> > same as why my chord progression works.
> >
> > Yeah, A:C:D:G (and some other even worse chords I've sound) screw it
> > up. But what I think is happening is the same thing that's happening
> > with C-Ev-G: the Ev will tend to "flip" back and forth between Eb
> > and E, and in this case, the C, D, and G will "flip" back and forth
> > between C:D:G and C+:D+:G+. However, not only is C:D:G/C+:D+:G+ a
> > much more subtle change than Eb/E - I don't think many listeners
> > could recognize such a perceptual change if they hear it.
>
> Personally I don't hear such duck/rabbit or Necker cube like flipping
> at all.

In C:Ev:G, or in A:C:D:G? What I'm saying is that you wouldn't notice
the necker-cube like flipping in A:C:D:G, since the intervals it could
be perceived as are so similar. There is, however, a huge difference
between C-E-G and C-Eb-G.

> We could model the diatonic way of hearing with 5-limit JI math but
> with the additional rule that (81/80)*r=r, syntonic comma being
> an "identity element". But this is potentially misleading because one
> might then think that "syntonically equivalent" ratios are actually
> heard (flipping) when one hears an interval in the context of music
> tuned to meantone. But it can't be so because there is an infinity
> of syntonically equivalent ratios. It would have to stop at
> some "depth" and I suspect that most diatonic listeners don't hear
> much depth at all. Perhaps somebody who has deeply internalized JI
> pitch relations would hear intervals as flipping all the time when
> listening to music tuned to meantone but in a sense he/she would be
> hearing the music in a "wrong" way.

Well, it isn't like that with a 400 cent interval you'll hear it
flipping between 5/4, 5/4 * 81/80, 5/4 * 81/80 * 81/80, etc. With a
400 cent interval in isolation - you'll probably hear it as 5/4. What
I'm saying is that in a specific musical context, you might hear a
tempered interval one way, and in a different context, you might hear
it another.

If you mess around in 7-tet for a bit, you'll note that there are
times in which you hear elements of "majorness" and "minorness"
popping out of the mix, even though all triads are tuned the same. I
think this applies to 12-tet as well, although if you have no prior
experience with JI - would you even notice?

> For them, syntonic equivalence is not some
> "eternal axiom of musicke" but just one (valid) way of hearing.

Hahaha!

> How is JI involved then?
>
> For arguments sake, take the 12-equal C major scale as a given. Now
> don't think of its' fifths, minor thirds and major thirds as 2:3s,
> 5:6s and 4:5s but simply as 12-equal fifths, minor thirds and major
> thirds. After all, they aren't acoustically 2:3s, 5:6s or 4:5s! Try
> to think of them as intervals of their own, not as approximations.
> D:A really is a 12-equal fifth even if JI C major scale doesn't have
> a pure 2:3 fifth there. There are structural properties, intervals
> and chords that don't exist in JI and they are really there
> acoustically!

I think you're right with this. So from the standpoint that a chord is
really a harmonic structure - would that then mean that "magic chords"
with commas tempered out of them really just indicate a very slightly
inharmonic structure? Kind of like Sethares' retuning of timbres to
temper out 81/80 and so forth?

So perhaps in that regard - the question really turns into one of how
inharmonic timbres are perceived.

> Searching for alternative temperaments often starts with a JI lattice
> of pitches. Then some commas are tempered out and the lattice
> is "collapsed" to lower dimensions. Even if this is done, one should
> resist the temptation to think that the JI lattice is somehow still
> there in the resulting temperament. After all, you can start from the
> opposite direction and find temperaments from equal divisions.

Alright, I think that what you're saying is true. But I do think that
in some way, shape or form JI influences are still "present" in the
end result, given that you can hear harmonic relationships in
inharmonic intervals. As you yourself said, 3/2 isn't even there in
12-tet, but I don't think I'd be able to distinguish a JI 3/2 from a
12-tet 3/2 if I tried, except for some beating.

Either way your point is well taken. So I guess I got what I wanted
out of this thread then. I'll have to do some more thinking about all
of this, and thanks for the insight.

-Mike

> Kalle Aho
>
>

ðŸ”—Petr Parízek <p.parizek@...>

2/15/2010 1:04:58 PM

Aaron wrote:

> I'm saying those things embody core simplicities to which all tunings
> have an inescapable relationship.

All tunings? I think this may be true in the context of the development of Renaissance/Baroque harmony but not in general. Or otherwise I'm still not sure if I'm following you. Why should a chain of 4 tempered 3/2s approximating 5/1 (i.e. meantone) be preferred over, let's say, a chain of 6 tempered 6/5s approximating 3/1 (i.e. hanson) for some general "acoustical" statements that may eventually lead to a demonstrative explanation of the musical possibilities of tempered tunings? Just because meantone is more familiar, I can't think of anything else.

Petr

ðŸ”—Chris Vaisvil <chrisvaisvil@...>

ðŸ”—Carl Lumma <carl@...>

2/15/2010 1:17:45 PM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, caleb morgan <calebmrgn@...> wrote:
>
> Oh, sorry!
>
> There's so many messages, and some get stuck in my spam box,
> for no apparent reason.

You may not have followed the link I provided:

/makemicromusic/topicId_21655.html#21656

> Yeah, Logic. Mac. Pitch-bends in Logic.

No, not pitch bends! Full-scale retuning.

> Get Pianoteq. Melodyne.

I don't know if Melodyne will be so useful for you. At least,
it's a 2.0 kind of purchase. First get your DAW & synths going.

> Then, begging your patience as I try to understand how some
> of you are coming up with these sophisticated scales.

The basic theory is since pitch bends suck for retuning
(not what they were designed for), we need to use more
specific messages. Realtime note tuning change messages
(Torsten's 3rd method) are ideal, but support for them
is virtually nonexistent among synths available today.
That leaves full scale retuning, which is limited to 128
pitches (not notes, actual pitches, so if you want 3 octaves
of 31-ET, that uses ~ 93 of your 128). So generally one
needs to chain several instances of a softsynth together,
and use a MIDI split to send, say, the bottom 3 octaves
to instance 1 and the top 3 to instance 2. If you're not
familiar with the idea of an "instance"... basically, if
you buy pianoteq, you can run several copies of it at once.
You run each copy inside its own track in Logic.

Make sense?

-Carl

ðŸ”—hpiinstruments <aaronhunt@...>

2/15/2010 1:22:02 PM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Carl Lumma" <carl@...> wrote:
>
> --- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "hpiinstruments" <aaronhunt@> wrote:
> > --- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Carl Lumma" <carl@> wrote:
> > > The question arises as to whether they can also be applied to
> > > larger chords at all. The answer is yes (with a few provisions)
> > > *if* one considers all dyads in a chord. For example, take
> > >
> > > 1/1 6/5 3/2 7/4 vs. 1/1 7/6 3/2 7/4
> > >
> > > Their dyads measured from 1/1 are roughly the same, but the
> > > former chord has a 35/24 fifth hiding it it, and it certainly
> > > sounds more dissonant to me!
> >
> > Yes, but this still doesn't suggest that *every single* dyad
> > has to be some ideal low number ratio or the chord is somehow
> > invalid.
>
> Yes, I never said that! :)

> > > > It doesn't make much sense. The basic rules of counterpoint
> > > > don't even require that.
> > >
> > > ?
> >
> > You apparently missed the next sentence I wrote:
> >
> > "Things work fine in 3 parts between upper
> > voices that wouldn't work in two parts."
>
> Didn't miss it, just wasn't sure what it had to do with
> the price of tea in China...
>
> > And that can be extended from 3 to 4 parts, etc.
> > Things that sound good in 3 parts don't by requirement
> > have to sound good in 2 parts if you took one part away.
> > When writing in 3 parts you do not have to write in
> > such a way that if some Joe Schmo picked up your
> > score and said "bwah ha ha!, I'm going to eliminate the bass
> > line and THEN we'll see just how good this guy's music is!"
> > It doesn't work that way. Analyzing / writing the counterpoint
> > requires interaction of all the voices present, and in many
> > cases taking a voice away will make something sound
> > wrong and that's why there are different rules for 2 part
> > writing than there are for 3 part writing. Anybody who
> > writes contrapuntal music knows this!
>
> I thought we were talking about chords. Sometimes they're
> played straight, 'comping or whatever. Other times, only
> various subsets are heard simultaneously, in contrapuntal
> writing. None of this changes the analysis that I can see.

I was responding to your claim (which you now appear to be
denying) that all the dyads have to be analyzed to pass some
kind of acid test. Read what I wrote again and see if you can
find a connection; I've explained it as best I can. Perhaps
someone else who writes music could say the same thing in
a clearer way.

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Petr Parízek <p.parizek@...> wrote:

> 3/1 (i.e. hanson) for some general "acoustical" statements

ðŸ”—Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...>

2/15/2010 1:40:17 PM

> I was responding to your claim (which you now appear to be
> denying) that all the dyads have to be analyzed to pass some
> kind of acid test. Read what I wrote again and see if you can
> find a connection; I've explained it as best I can. Perhaps
> someone else who writes music could say the same thing in
> a clearer way.
>
> Yours,
> AAH

I've been considering the same thing, and I don't think it's that
every dyad has to pass an acid test per se. To give an example, a
supermajor triad sounds pretty rough because of that 7:9, but it
sounds pretty good in 6:7:9. A neutral triad with the third as 9:11
sounds pretty rough as well, but the same 9:11 in the context of
8:9:10:11 might sound just fine.

I think that what's happening is that different dyads are perceived as
having different harmonic "strengths." A 9:11 by itself might only
very, very weakly produce a fundamental pitch at 1, but more strongly
produce a skewed root as though it were a flat 5/4. However, within
the context of other intervals referring to the "actual" 1 of the
9:11, such as 8:9, 9:10, 10:11, etc, the perception of it as 9:11 is
strengthened, and so on.

It isn't quite as linear as just analyzing the separate dyads and
adding them together. As for these "magic chords" we've been
discussion - my original guess was that they simply "flip flopped"
back and forth between different perceptions of the same chord without
us noticing, but it might just be that they're viewed as slightly
inharmonic, and that's it - similarly to how we perceive slightly
inharmonic timbres.

I think the big picture is that it isn't only JI chords that sound
good, since it isn't only perfectly harmonic series' that sound
"good."

-Mike

>
>

ðŸ”—Carl Lumma <carl@...>

2/15/2010 1:49:30 PM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "hpiinstruments" <aaronhunt@...> wrote:

> > > has to be some ideal low number ratio or the chord is somehow
> > > invalid.

> > Yes, I never said that! :)
>
> You sure did:
>

> > We have to consider all the dyads in the chord.
> > In tuning 1, D to G is 20:27, and in tuning 2 this
> > interval is 16:21. Both of these are wolf fourths.
> </tuning/topicId_86071.html#86442>
>
> You said every dyad has to be considered, and then
> singled out two dyads that don't agree with an
> ideal low number ratio, to show me that the chords I
> gave were unsatisfactory.
>
> Are you taking that back? Sorry, I'm confused.

You misunderstood. I was explaining why Mike & Kalle were
discussing the tempered version of this chord as if it had
advantages over any JI tuning. Note, I said that in my own
experience, as long as the 'wolf' interval is voiced in the
right position, the JI version can sound smoother than
the tempered one, in many cases (I also mentioned that not
all listeners agree with me on this).

40 pages of music, several of which had been performed
publicly. Do either of us write music for a living? No.
So I don't think any inability to explain your idea, or
lack of understanding of basic methods for analysing the
consonance of chords, is explained.

ðŸ”—hpiinstruments <aaronhunt@...>

2/15/2010 3:51:37 PM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Carl Lumma" wrote:
> Let's back up a bit. This is about your comment on
> contrapuntal writing having something to do with the
> dissonance of chords. Does it?

No, no don't start conflating...

I tend to draw comparisons very abstractly, which is a
strength creatively but often a liability when
communicating.

I made an analogy, comparing a basic principle
of composition to the idea of combinatorial
dyad parsing which you just recanted.

Let me try again anyway, to make this as clear as I can,
though I feel this is becoming quite tedious ...

There are rules specific to 2 part writing. I'm saying by
analogy this is like your analyzing a dyad.

When composing in 3 parts, the rules specific to 2 parts
are relaxed, because you have another part there. It
changes the equation. The technique of polyphonic
composition is not limited to rules for 2 parts. I'm saying
by analogy that this is like your chord; writing for 3 parts
is not the same as writing for 2, and by analogy a chord
does not necessarily require analysis as a bunch of dyads.
There are times when you want to do that, the same way
there are times you want to write counterpoint that's
invertible or retrograde invertible, etc., but it's not a
requirement that those stringent rules govern everything
all the time.

What I'm saying is actually somewhat similar to what Mike
is saying here, from a different angle:
</tuning/topicId_86071.html#86510>

Which touches on a very basic aspect of tonal composition
that I mentioned before, that the addition or subtraction of
a single pitch can easily change the entire harmonic context.
Jazz pianists use this principle all the time, giving the bass
to the bass player means the chords get harmonically
interpreted in different ways, and it's hip to play things that
have several harmonic axes going on simultaneously. That's
certainly a huge strength of tempered systems. Do things in
JI and to change harmonic context you have to retune the
chord. Probably that was the whole point to begin with.

Yours,
AAH
=====

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

not be?

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/16/2010 4:46:57 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...> wrote:

> I've been considering the same thing, and I don't think it's that
> every dyad has to pass an acid test per se. To give an example, a
> supermajor triad sounds pretty rough because of that 7:9, but it
> sounds pretty good in 6:7:9. A neutral triad with the third as 9:11
> sounds pretty rough as well, but the same 9:11 in the context of
> 8:9:10:11 might sound just fine.

Hm, I think a neutral triad with an 11/9 third sounds very round and smooth. Just half an hour ago I introduced a guy with a very good ear and traditional European childhood music school training to microtonality- his unsolicited opinion of 11/9 alone and in a triad with 3/2 was also "smooth/soft". Of course it not possible around here not to hear microtonal Balkan music, so a neutral third isn't a complete stranger to anyone, but still, I suspect that a person has to learn to hear an 11/9 as rough. The guy recognized 11/8 immediately as an "in tune augmented fourth", which is quite interesting come to think of it.

I did have a "shredding" "jazz" pianist complain that 5/4 sounds dreadfully flat, the one and only such experience I can remember, everyone else I've ever "tested" has always found Just intervals, including higher limits, to sound "soft", "ancient", "ethnic", and so on. :-) Oh, and 7/4 is almost 100% guaranteed to get the response "blues!", which is quite telling I think.

9/7 is another interval I hear as quite smooth, but personally I also need it in context, because I find it exceedingly pushy- not unstable as far as spectra, but very aggressive as far as wanting to go somewhere. An interval I have a hard time with, a kind of bully that doesn't often play well in tunings.

ðŸ”—Petr Parízek <p.parizek@...>

2/16/2010 5:05:39 AM

Aaron wrote:

> Petr, yes I mean all tunings and no I'm afraid you have not quite
> followed; as for the cycle of 5, I already addressed that. It's not
> as basic as the cycle of 3 because 3 < 5, end of argument. I gave
> a link to the previous thread for a reason (why do people
> consistently ignore links I give for specific purposes?)

It's not that I haven't read the message. In fact, I've read it on the day you posted it. It's that it doesn't answer my question. Before the phenomenon of chords appeared, Pythagorean tuning was an excellent choice because 1) the "trine" of 2:3:4 was understood as the most stable of all and 2) the fifth of 3/2 splits the octave (i.e. the equivalence interval) into two "linearly equidistant" steps (not exponentially), which slightly amplifies the relative frequency of 1 in this trine (i.e. the GCD is 1, 3-2 is 1, and 4-3 is 1). However, during the 16th century, the meaning of the prime 5 was highly promoted because of the new phenomenon of chords. On one hand, it became apparent that music based on chords sounded better with thirds of 5/4 and 6/5 than with 81/64 and 32/27 (a major third in a triad has a different meaning than a "ditone" which was considered unstable and required resolution to a stable interval). OTOH, since both the GCD and the difference frequency of a perfect fifth is an octave equivalent of the lower sounding tone (i.e. 1 octave lower) and is clearly audible, many people still insisted to keep the concept of a chain of fifths which had served for centuries. Of course, when the chains of fifths were large enough, when combined with the number 5, this lead to the problem of either having pairs of close pitches (differing by 81/80) or mistuned fifths or both. This is why meantone was eventually accepted as "the solution", although there are many possible solutions -- i.e. since it all began with Pythagorean tuning back in the 3-limit age, the chain of fifths seemed to be the correct choice preferred over a chain of anything else. But the fact is that 5-limit JI is 3-dimmensional and you can get a 2D tuning out of it by tempering out any interval you want (or an 1D tuning if you temper out two intervals). And there's no explicit reason why tempering out 81/80 should be "more obviously derived from the basic intervals" than tempering out 15625/15552 apart from the fact that a chain of fifths may look similar to Pythagorean tuning while a chain of minor thirds does not.

Let me give you two examples. First, let's say we start with a tone of D5 and we keep lowering it alternately by 6/5 and 5/4 until we've done 7 pitch changes. So we get D5, B4, G4, E4, C4, A3, F3, D3. Since we used thirds of 6/5 and 5/4 rather than some tempered thirds, our final D3 comes out as 20/81, which is a syntonic comma lower than 1/4. Interestingly enough, if we narrow each third by 1/7 of the comma and reduce the result into a single octave range, we get a diatonic scale of 2/7-comma meantone (i.e. 5 major seconds + 2 minor seconds) where 4 fifths are 1/7-comma smaller than 5/1 and where 3 fifths are 1/7-comma wider than 10/3.

Now let's say we start with a tone of, for example, B#5 and we keep lowering it alternately by 5/4 and 4/3 until we've done 11 pitch changes. Since standard notation is based on chains of fifths (i.e. it was meant to represent either Pythagorean or meantone), the notes would then come out as B#5, G#5, D#5, B4, F#4, D4, A3, F3, C3, Ab2, Eb2, Cb2. The final Cb2 compared to the B#5 is 972/15625, which is only a kleisma (15625/15552) lower than 1/16, or 4 octaves falling. If we narrow each third or fourth, respectively, by 1/11 of the kleisma and reduce the result into a single octave range, we get the 11-tone "quasi-diatonic" version of hanson (i.e. 7 small and 4 large intervals) where 6 minor thirds (if I use the conventional name) are 1/11-kleisma wider than 3/1 and where 5 minor thirds are 11-kleisma smaller than 5/2.

Both of these examples are equally valid in explaining approximating JI, in explaining the phenomenon of tempering, and in explaining possible development of certain harmonic progressions reflecting this (like the often discussed "C major, A minor, D minor, G major, C major" in the case of meantone).

Petr

ðŸ”—hpiinstruments <aaronhunt@...>

2/16/2010 9:45:21 AM

Hi Petr.

Thanks for writing.

First, it's good that you know the things you know, and
you do a fine job explaining them, but honestly, and for
heaven's sake, do you really think I need a history lesson
in tuning theory? Good grief, I know historical tuning
theory inside and out; thanks and no offense. As a small
correction, chords didn't all of a sudden 'appear' in the
16th century; harmony has been experimental since
the beginning of recorded music history. The Greeks
knew full well that 5/4 was 'sweeter' than the ditone, etc.

More importantly, nothing you stated refutes any of what
I'm talking about; in fact it confirms what I've said. I'm not
challenging your or any tuning philosophy, at all. Having
written a lot about this by this time, I'm weary of repeating
myself, but since nobody else has piped up and said 'I get it;
he means ... ', I have to assume the fault is mine for
choosing the wrong words, apparently. I really think what
I've already written is as clear as day, but allow me to add
the following.

If you want to construct things from periods of 3, cycles
of 5, periods of 7, cycles of 19, Pi cent steps that diminish
by Phi exponentially, unequal divisions of a Cantor series,
Euler's constant, the current price of beans, and Avagadro's
number, that's all perfectly fine, and I've never said anything
to the contrary. Use whatever methods you want to
construct any musical structure available to humankind,
with more or less historical precedent, more or less overall
reasonableness; the resulting will have some 'obviousness',
'rightness', 'correctness', and 'simplicity' which boils down
to:

(1) it's similarity to a 3-cycle
(2) it's similarity to integer ratios
(3) it's similarity to an ET

I AM NOT SAYING that these three things are the only way to
BULD anything or the only way to HEAR anything, or the only
way to EXPLAIN anything. I'm saying:

(1) 3-cycle
(2) JI
(3) ET

THESE ARE THE SIMPLEST SIMPLICITIES IN TUNING AND
EVERYTHING IS INESCAPABLY RELATED TO THEM.

In your examples, you give cycles involving both 5 and 3.
Unless you want to argue that 5 is less than 3 and the
interval 2:3 is really built from powers of 5, you are proving
my point exactly. The fact that historically 3 preceded explicit
theoretical promulgation of 5, and that a circle of fifths
persists to this day also proves the point. Please reread my
remarks about 12ET. Please reread everything I've said about
this.

I'm not challenging anything; these things are simple, and
my point is nothing incredibly insightful, and nothing
new at all.

On a personal note, I'm keeping conversations here right now,
which I don't normally do, because I'm packing up to move,
and I can't do any actual work like programming or building,
and I'm looking at this list when I take a break. If what I wrote
here still does clear things up, does not make sense, is lacking
somehow to convince anybody that what I'm saying is perfectly
valid and doesn't challenge any tuning philosophy in the least,
I'm just going to leave it at that, because I'm really pretty tired
of this. If someone understood me, it really would be nice to
hear from you.

Yours,
AAH
=====

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Petr Parízek <p.parizek@...> wrote:
>
> Aaron wrote:
>
> > Petr, yes I mean all tunings and no I'm afraid you have not quite
> > followed; as for the cycle of 5, I already addressed that. It's not
> > as basic as the cycle of 3 because 3 < 5, end of argument. I gave
> > a link to the previous thread for a reason (why do people
> > consistently ignore links I give for specific purposes?)
>
> It's not that I haven't read the message. In fact, I've read it on the day you posted it. It's that it doesn't answer my question. Before the phenomenon of chords appeared, Pythagorean tuning was an excellent choice because 1) the "trine" of 2:3:4 was understood as the most stable of all and 2) the fifth of 3/2 splits the octave (i.e. the equivalence interval) into two "linearly equidistant" steps (not exponentially), which slightly amplifies the relative frequency of 1 in this trine (i.e. the GCD is 1, 3-2 is 1, and 4-3 is 1). However, during the 16th century, the meaning of the prime 5 was highly promoted because of the new phenomenon of chords. On one hand, it became apparent that music based on chords sounded better with thirds of 5/4 and 6/5 than with 81/64 and 32/27 (a major third in a triad has a different meaning than a "ditone" which was considered unstable and required resolution to a stable interval). This is why meantone was eventually accepted as "the solution", although there are many possible solutions -- i.e. since it all began with Pythagorean tuning back in the 3-limit age, the chain of fifths seemed to be the correct choice preferred over a chain of anything else. But the fact is that 5-limit JI is 3-dimmensional and you can get a 2D tuning out of it by tempering out any interval you want (or an 1D tuning if you temper out two intervals). And there's no explicit reason why tempering out 81/80 should be "more obviously derived from the basic intervals" than tempering out 15625/15552 apart from the fact that a chain of fifths may look similar to Pythagorean tuning while a chain of minor thirds does not.
>
> Let me give you two examples. First, let's say we start with a tone of D5 and we keep lowering it alternately by 6/5 and 5/4 until we've done 7 pitch changes. So we get D5, B4, G4, E4, C4, A3, F3, D3. Since we used thirds of 6/5 and 5/4 rather than some tempered thirds, our final D3 comes out as 20/81, which is a syntonic comma lower than 1/4. >
> Now let's say we start with a tone of, for example, B#5 and we keep lowering it alternately by 5/4 and 4/3 until we've done 11 pitch changes. Since standard notation is based on chains of fifths (i.e. it was meant to represent either Pythagorean or meantone), the notes would then come out as B#5, G#5, D#5, B4, F#4, D4, A3, F3, C3, Ab2, Eb2, Cb2. The final Cb2 compared to the B#5 is 972/15625, which is only a kleisma (15625/15552) lower than 1/16, or 4 octaves falling. If we narrow each third or fourth, respectively, by 1/11 of the kleisma and reduce the result into a single octave range, we get the 11-tone "quasi-diatonic" version of hanson (i.e. 7 small and 4 large intervals) where 6 minor thirds (if I use the conventional name) are 1/11-kleisma wider than 3/1 and where 5 minor thirds are 11-kleisma smaller than 5/2.
>
> Both of these examples are equally valid in explaining approximating JI, in explaining the phenomenon of tempering, and in explaining possible development of certain harmonic progressions reflecting this (like the often discussed "C major, A minor, D minor, G major, C major" in the case of meantone).

ðŸ”—Kalle <kalleaho@...>

2/16/2010 10:53:58 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...> wrote:

> > Personally I don't hear such duck/rabbit or Necker cube like
> > flipping at all.
>
> In C:Ev:G, or in A:C:D:G? What I'm saying is that you wouldn't
> notice the necker-cube like flipping in A:C:D:G, since the
> intervals it could be perceived as are so similar. There is,
> however, a huge difference between C-E-G and C-Eb-G.

In A:C:D:G.

> Well, it isn't like that with a 400 cent interval you'll hear it
> flipping between 5/4, 5/4 * 81/80, 5/4 * 81/80 * 81/80, etc. With a
> 400 cent interval in isolation - you'll probably hear it as 5/4.
> What I'm saying is that in a specific musical context, you might
> hear a tempered interval one way, and in a different context, you
> might hear it another.
>
> If you mess around in 7-tet for a bit, you'll note that there are
> times in which you hear elements of "majorness" and "minorness"
> popping out of the mix, even though all triads are tuned the same. I
> think this applies to 12-tet as well, although if you have no prior
> experience with JI - would you even notice?

I'd say that a (hypothetical) person whose musical mother tongue was
strict JI would probably hear such flipping in A:C:D:G because she
would listen it within a strict JI template. I tend to hear the
neutral third as major or minor and think that this is the same
phenomenon. My brain is trying to fit the neutral third into the
diatonic category of third which is supposed to come in two
varieties, minor and major. This is the phenomenon of categorical
perception, for example many Japanese can't hear the difference
between /l/ and /r/. Once when I took a course in Swedish my teacher
tried to teach me the difference between two versions of the
vowel /y/ (or was it /u/, I'm not sure). I just kept staring at her
because I heard no difference. :D

I feel that categorical perception is a much more important thing to
consider for microtonalists than it is often taken to be. Of course
it is not so important if one is working with "recognizable diatonic
tunings" (Easley Blackwood's term) as intervals are then supposed to
be heard in diatonic terms as minor and major thirds and sixths,
diminished and perfect fifths and so on.

It is very easy to hear 6:7 and 7:9 as some kinds of minor and major
thirds but if you look at table 1 in Paul Erlich's 22-tone paper you
see that the 22-equal approximation of 6:7 is a major 3rd(10) while
~5:6 is a minor 4th(10). ~7:9 is an aug. 4th(10) or a dim. 5th(10)
while ~4:5 is a major 4th(10). If you want to hear decatonically, you
must hear the ~6:7 as belonging to the same generic interval category
of 3rd(10) as ~7:8/~8:9. I really hope it is not as hard as learning
new phonemes!

I wonder if people who listen and play a lot of octatonic (diminished
scale) music have learned some kind of octatonic template. I often
hear octatonic passages as undergoing modulation even when they stay
within one octatonic collection.

> I think you're right with this. So from the standpoint that a chord
> is really a harmonic structure - would that then mean that "magic
> chords" with commas tempered out of them really just indicate a
> very slightly inharmonic structure? Kind of like Sethares' retuning
> of timbres to temper out 81/80 and so forth?
>
> So perhaps in that regard - the question really turns into one of
> how inharmonic timbres are perceived.

I guess so, the spectra of all tempered chords really are inharmonic
even when they approximate harmonic series.

> thanks for the insight.

The pleasure is mine!

Kalle Aho

ðŸ”—Marcel de Velde <m.develde@...>

2/16/2010 11:46:31 AM

> I'd say that a (hypothetical) person whose musical mother tongue was
> strict JI would probably hear such flipping in A:C:D:G
>

I just played A:C:D:G as 5/3 2/1 9/4 3/1
And then my ear heard a F# as in mode.
So I mistuned it and even then my ear/brain heard/interpreted it as the most
logical solution.
Which is 27/16 2/1 9/4 3/1, and the F# would be 45/16 making it a dominant
7th chord.

To hear A:C:D:G as 5/3 2/1 9/4 3/1:
5/3 2/1 9/4 3/1
5/3 2/1 9/4 8/3
3/2 15/8 9/4 8/3
1/1 3/2 2/1 5/2

There is no flipflopping, it's the mode / notes that came previously or
later that make clear to the brain which tuning it is even if the ear can't
hear it.

Marcel

ðŸ”—Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...>

2/16/2010 12:42:26 PM

> Hm, I think a neutral triad with an 11/9 third sounds very round and smooth. Just half an hour ago I introduced a guy with a very good ear and traditional European childhood music school training to microtonality- his unsolicited opinion of 11/9 alone and in a triad with 3/2 was also "smooth/soft". Of course it not possible around here not to hear microtonal Balkan music, so a neutral third isn't a complete stranger to anyone, but still, I suspect that a person has to learn to hear an 11/9 as rough. The guy recognized 11/8 immediately as an "in tune augmented fourth", which is quite interesting come to think of it.

I didn't mean that 11/9 was synesthetically "rough" or anything like
that, just that it's hard to swallow for those of us not used to it.
It does have a fairly "smooth" sound, but especially in lower
registers, I tend to just hear it as a really sharp minor triad or a
really flat major triad, with it flipping back and forth.

But again, what you say here is more anecdotal evidence supporting
what I've believed for a while: that you can be "trained" to recognize
the order in higher-entropy intervals.

> I did have a "shredding" "jazz" pianist complain that 5/4 sounds dreadfully flat, the one and only such experience I can remember, everyone else I've ever "tested" has always found Just intervals, including higher limits, to sound "soft", "ancient", "ethnic", and so on. :-) Oh, and 7/4 is almost 100% guaranteed to get the response "blues!", which is quite telling I think.

Well, I'm a jazz pianist. And, in certain circles, one could say that
I "shred." And now that I've destroyed all perception of humility for
myself, I might as well weigh in and say that sometimes, especially at
first, 5/4 did sound dreadfully flat. However, this has to do with the
fact that as Kalle mentioned, us jazz guys tend to take the 400 cent
interval as being a lot more than just a 5/4 - its use as 81/64 is
very common (as in the tendency of jazz musicians to use quartal and
quintal chords), and probably some other intuitive ways to use that
interval that I'm not thinking of. That was one of the main problems
for me at first - I tended to always think in terms of the circle of
fifths. It's also a bit too flat to create much tension as a leading
tone.

Nowadays I actually do like 5/4 quite a bit, but I'd prefer 81/32 for
a chord like C G Bb+ D F+ A C+ E, or 32/21 for a chord like C F Bb Eb
G.

As for 7/4, my response as well as that of my friends at school was
that it was also very "flat" at first, since were used to thinking of
a minor seventh as being accessible via the circle of fourths if
necessary. Nowadays I just hear it as a separate animal from the usual
12-tet "minor seventh" though.

> 9/7 is another interval I hear as quite smooth, but personally I also need it in context, because I find it exceedingly pushy- not unstable as far as spectra, but very aggressive as far as wanting to go somewhere. An interval I have a hard time with, a kind of bully that doesn't often play well in tunings.

Just curious, have you written many pieces making extensive use of
this interval? I have only heard one piece of yours, a vocal
composition from a long time ago. Maybe you're just more dialed into
these higher-limit intervals than I am.

-Mike

>

ðŸ”—Kalle <kalleaho@...>

Marcel,

the question was whether such flipflopping is heard if A:C:D:G is
tuned to 12-equal or some other meantone tuning.

Kalle Aho

Hi Mike,

I might as well weigh in and say that sometimes, especially at
> first, 5/4 did sound dreadfully flat. However, this has to do with the
> fact that as Kalle mentioned, us jazz guys tend to take the 400 cent
> interval as being a lot more than just a 5/4 - its use as 81/64 is
> very common (as in the tendency of jazz musicians to use quartal and
> quintal chords), and probably some other intuitive ways to use that
> interval that I'm not thinking of. That was one of the main problems
> for me at first - I tended to always think in terms of the circle of
> fifths. It's also a bit too flat to create much tension as a leading
> tone.
>

I personally never like 81/64.
But have you considered / explored 32/25?
In my view it has the sound and function you just described.
Even in the circle of fifths way, as in my opinion it's formed by 3 times 4
3/2 fifths connected by 5/4 in the following way:
1/1 3/2 9/4 27/8 5/1 15/2 45/4 135/8 25/1 75/2 225/4 675/8

Marcel

> tuned to 12-equal or some other meantone tuning.

Yes I understood this.
I ment that even when I'm mistuning it in JI I can still interpret it in a
different way.
So it goes for 12tet even more so.
I think there's no fipflopping, the brain makes a decision (though it can be
made to change what it picked), but that there's also not good enough ear
resolution to hear for sure no matter the tuning.

Marcel

ðŸ”—hpiinstruments <aaronhunt@...>

2/16/2010 4:51:50 PM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Carl Lumma" <carl@...> wrote:
> You may not have followed the link I provided:
>
> /makemicromusic/topicId_21655.html#21656

Carl incorrectly states in that message that H-Pi software
is in beta; it's not.

> > Yeah, Logic. Mac. Pitch-bends in Logic.
>
> No, not pitch bends! Full-scale retuning.
>
> > Get Pianoteq. Melodyne.
>
> I don't know if Melodyne will be so useful for you. At least,
> it's a 2.0 kind of purchase. First get your DAW & synths going.

The only Melodyne user I know of on this forum is Charles Lucy.
Maybe he can say something about Melodyn's ease of use or
range of use or learning curve?

Pianoteq is a really good product from a good company and
it has excellent tuning support ...

> The basic theory is since pitch bends suck for retuning
> (not what they were designed for), we need to use more
> specific messages. Realtime note tuning change messages
> (Torsten's 3rd method) are ideal, but support for them
> is virtually nonexistent among synths available today.
> That leaves full scale retuning, which is limited to 128
> pitches (not notes, actual pitches, so if you want 3 octaves
> of 31-ET, that uses ~ 93 of your 128). So generally one
> needs to chain several instances of a softsynth together,
> and use a MIDI split to send, say, the bottom 3 octaves
> to instance 1 and the top 3 to instance 2. If you're not
> familiar with the idea of an "instance"... basically, if
> you buy pianoteq, you can run several copies of it at once.
> You run each copy inside its own track in Logic.
>
> Make sense?
>
> -Carl

Or, you can run ONE copy of Pianoteq and send it output
directly from anything that sends multi-channel pitch bend,
like a Tonal Plexus or Tuning Box or Scordatura or TPXE or
CSE, because Pianoteq has implemented GM microtuning
(*not* MTS), as oulined in this document:
<http://www.h-pi.com/additionals/TPXSoftInstGuide.pdf>

*NO TUNING TABLES NECESSARY IN PIANOTEQ* when using
multi-channel pitch bend.

Same is true for Kontakt, using the universal tuning script
I wrote that you can download and use for free. Open ONE
instance of Kontakt, and get totally retuneable microtuning,
NO TUNING TABLES NECESSARY IN KONTAKT using the script.

Do not dismiss multi-channel pitch bend (GM microtuning) -
the most universally compatible microtuning solution - just
because Mr. Carl Lumma said 'it sucks'. It doesn't suck.
It's not ideal, but it actually has MANY advantages over other
methods, the most obvious one being that *it actually works*,
and the second being that *the receiver does not need tuning
tables*. The 6 page pdf linked above clarifies that and more.

All the music on this page was made using the pitch bend
method. <http://www.h-pi.com/musicFiles.html>

Plug TBX1 into a $150 Yamaha synth, flip a switch and you
have a 61-key velocity sensing completely retuneable
microtonal keyboard. A TPX controller works on that same
$150 synth.

Pitch bends: 98304 steps per octave = 0.01 cents precision.

It more than works.

Yours,
AAH
=====

ðŸ”—Chris Vaisvil <chrisvaisvil@...>

2/16/2010 4:45:58 PM

Caleb does a script care if kontakt is running on a mac or pc?

Perhaps I can see if my son will try it on his mac. I bought this but really
haven't used it yet - but I'm a PC as they say.

Chris

> So, I stopped reading, for now.

> I'm trying to find stuff to add to my Mac setup, for now.

> > Right, I guess I'm most interested in 'tuning the 128 available
> > notes freely'-
>
> With Kontakt you have a very flexible sampler that can do this, thanks
> to its scripting capability. E.g.
>
> http://www.12equalboresme.com/Scala2Kontakt/index.html
>
> Best wishes,
> Torsten

> Office: +44-1752-586219
> Private: +44-1752-558917
> http://strasheela.sourceforge.net
> http://www.torsten-anders.de

ðŸ”—Carl Lumma <carl@...>

2/16/2010 4:56:14 PM

Hi Caleb,

> I thought you can't get more than 12 notes per octave in Logic.

Only Logic's *built-in microtuning feature* has this limitation.

> I also thought that Scala doesn't do what I want, according to Carl,

Right.

> and it, according to me, looks gnarly to implement on a Mac.

Right.

> So, question: What does the 'full scale retuning'?

Synths like pianoteq.

> Paint a picture for this ignorant old codger.

Please read:
/tuning/topicId_86071.html#86506

Jeez, wait, this is the post you're replying to. Read:

>The basic theory is since pitch bends suck for retuning
>(not what they were designed for), we need to use more
>specific messages. Realtime note tuning change messages
>(Torsten's 3rd method) are ideal, but support for them
>is virtually nonexistent among synths available today.
>That leaves full scale retuning, which is limited to 128
>pitches (not notes, actual pitches, so if you want 3 octaves
>of 31-ET, that uses ~ 93 of your 128).

Especially, this part:

>So generally one needs to chain several instances of a
>softsynth together, and use a MIDI split to send, say, the
>bottom 3 octaves to instance 1 and the top 3 to instance 2.
>If you're not familiar with the idea of an "instance"...
>basically, if you buy pianoteq, you can run several copies
>of it at once. You run each copy inside its own track
>in Logic.

I'd be happy to go into more detail if any of this is unclear.

-Carl

ðŸ”—Carl Lumma <carl@...>

2/16/2010 5:05:52 PM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "hpiinstruments" <aaronhunt@...> wrote:

> > You may not have followed the link I provided:
> >
> > /makemicromusic/topicId_21655.html#21656
>
> Carl incorrectly states in that message that H-Pi software
> is in beta; it's not.

Thanks for the correction. As you know, at the time I wrote
that, your webpage incorrectly stated one of them was in beta.

> Do not dismiss multi-channel pitch bend (GM microtuning) -
> the most universally compatible microtuning solution - just
> because Mr. Carl Lumma said 'it sucks'.

And don't build a studio around them just because Mr Aaron Hunt
wants to sell you a box with MIDI cables coming out of it.

> All the music on this page was made using the pitch bend
> method. <http://www.h-pi.com/musicFiles.html>

...all of which are monotimbral.

-Carl
