This makes a lot of sense--the part about full scale retuning.

That's the method I've used in the past, on hardware. (Yamaha synths,
etc.)

Also, the link looks like very useful stuff.

Sorry, I'm not sure why I didn't see this message--it wasn't in the
Spam box, either.

Give me a day or so to look at the MakeMicroMusic link.

Thanks,

Caleb

> Maybe he can say something about Melodyn's ease of use or
> range of use or learning curve?
>
> Pianoteq is a really good product from a good company and
> it has excellent tuning support ...
>
> > The basic theory is since pitch bends suck for retuning
> > (not what they were designed for), we need to use more
> > specific messages. Realtime note tuning change messages
> > (Torsten's 3rd method) are ideal, but support for them
> > is virtually nonexistent among synths available today.
> > That leaves full scale retuning, which is limited to 128
> > pitches (not notes, actual pitches, so if you want 3 octaves
> > of 31-ET, that uses ~ 93 of your 128). So generally one
> > needs to chain several instances of a softsynth together,
> > and use a MIDI split to send, say, the bottom 3 octaves
> > to instance 1 and the top 3 to instance 2. If you're not
> > familiar with the idea of an "instance"... basically, if
> > you buy pianoteq, you can run several copies of it at once.
> > You run each copy inside its own track in Logic.
> >
> > Make sense?
> >
> > -Carl

Carl, I have an interest in helping Caleb understand the
facts and not be misled by you. He contacted me through
my business to ask for advice. I saw he was asking here
and sent him a note explaining that I usually do not get
involved in anything on this list that involves discussing
my business, for exactly the reason that you make very clear
here by saying something as stupid as the above. Caleb told
me it would be fine to take part in this discussion so that's
what I'm doing. Save your stupid remarks for your living
room, please.

As for MIDI cables, I designed U-PLEX for folks who don't
like or need DIN connectors.
<http://www.h-pi.com/TPX28buy.html>

Yours,
AAH

ðŸ”—hpiinstruments <aaronhunt@...>

2/16/2010 6:02:15 PM

Hi Ozan.

Instructions for Sibelius and Logic are in Scordatura Help files.
Pianoteq is the same. You just route MIDI out to Pianoteq,
making sure MIDI is set up correctly to receive there.

Pianoteq is a great product, and has not only piano sounds, but
a few very nice harpsichords and a pianoforte as well.

Yours,
AAH
=====

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Ozan Yarman <ozanyarman@...> wrote:

oh - so.... this is not routing OUT of pianoteq as I thought I read.

> > > methods, the most obvious one being that *it actually works*,
> > > and the second being that *the receiver does not need tuning
> > > tables*. The 6 page pdf linked above clarifies that and more.
> > >
> > > All the music on this page was made using the pitch bend
> > > method. <http://www.h-pi.com/musicFiles.html>
> > >
> > > Plug TBX1 into a $150 Yamaha synth, flip a switch and you
> > > have a 61-key velocity sensing completely retuneable
> > > microtonal keyboard. A TPX controller works on that same
> > > $150 synth.
> > >
> > > Pitch bends: 98304 steps per octave = 0.01 cents precision.
> > >
> > > It more than works.
> > >
> > > Yours,
> > > AAH
> > > =====
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > ------------------------------------
> > >
> > > You can configure your subscription by sending an empty email to one
> > > of these addresses (from the address at which you receive the list):
> > > tuning-subscribe@yahoogroups.com <tuning-subscribe%40yahoogroups.com>- join the tuning group.
> > > tuning-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com<tuning-unsubscribe%40yahoogroups.com>- leave the group.
> > > tuning-nomail@yahoogroups.com <tuning-nomail%40yahoogroups.com> - turn
> off mail from the group.
> > > tuning-digest@yahoogroups.com <tuning-digest%40yahoogroups.com> - set
> group to send daily digests.
> > > tuning-normal@yahoogroups.com <tuning-normal%40yahoogroups.com> - set
> group to send individual emails.
> > > tuning-help@yahoogroups.com <tuning-help%40yahoogroups.com> - receive
> general help information.
> > > Yahoo! Groups Links
> > >
> > >
> > >
> >
>
>
>

ðŸ”—Ozan Yarman <ozanyarman@...>

2/16/2010 6:51:36 PM

Does Pianoteq have on-the-fly tuning change support? Scordatura can be
commanded to utilize unlimited tunings one after the other throughout
a piece.

Oz.

✩ ✩ ✩
www.ozanyarman.com

> in anything on this list that involves discussing my
> business, for exactly the reason that you make very clear
> here by saying something as stupid as the above. Caleb told
> me it would be fine to take part in this discussion so that's
> what I'm doing. Save your stupid remarks for your living

Aaron, I'd prefer we have cordial and productive conversations,
but if you insist on hurling insults at me, making veiled and
explicit comparisons between our professional qualifications,
I'm hardly afraid.

Not sure what I did to drive you to this behavior. Was it in
December 2006 when I rejected your bid to buy a review of the
Tonal Plexus in Keyboard magazine? Or in 2007 when I gave an
unfavorable review of that instrument on the MMM list?

I think H-Pi represents a phenomenal effort and I sincerely
believe you are a very talented person. You shouldn't take
criticism of your products personally. You shouldn't draw
battle lines, as you have in the past, about my 'refusal to
support the only microtonal corporation in the world'. And
probably, if you wanted to sell instruments to microtonalists,
you should have bothered to understand the microtonal theory
developed on the largest and longest-lived hangout for
microtonalists in the world before plowing ahead with your
own keyboard and notation ideas.

As for Caleb's needs, he clearly stated that he's looking to
abandon hardware and go for a softsynth-based studio. Which
is certainly a prudent choice. Therefore your depiction of
the tuning box's virtues seems to have been misplaced.

-Carl

ðŸ”—Ozan Yarman <ozanyarman@...>

2/16/2010 7:35:27 PM

Obviously, one great use of being able to change tunings on-the-fly is
the mapping of dozens of maqams in succession to a 12-tone layout for
easy access to the "diatonically impaired" such as myself.

Other possible uses come to mind in similar xentonal directions or
involving one-at-a-time subsets of voluminous equal divisions, which
are not too convoluted to imagine.

Oz.

✩ ✩ ✩
www.ozanyarman.com

2/16/2010 7:48:23 PM

Treading very carefully here...

While I cannot approve of the hurtful remarks by Aaron, I cannot agree
with Carl's demeanour either. Carl, you were obviously sledgehammering
Aaron's company by insinuating that buyers of H-Pi products should
beware. The tuning list should not be a place where hurting humble
businesses - let alone a company geared towards the development of
microtonal hardware and software - is condoned. Besides, Aaron Andrew
is not advertising here that you should appear to disprage his products.

Moreover, Aaron has every right to act on a personal initiative to develop his products based on multiples of 41-EDO or whatnot without
taking as reference the myriad squabbles and endless polemics of this
list. We should not pretend that there is some consensus on even the
basic topics of intonation and tuning.

Besides, I never have yet used 41-EDO or Aaron's notation system to
compose my music with Scordatura.

That being said, I crawl back to my lair.

Oz.

✩ ✩ ✩
www.ozanyarman.com

Hi Oz,

of past hostilities between Aaron H. and I, I had been doubly
careful to be courteous and positive in the recent engagements.
Then Aaron made several veiled, and then more direct insults.
I will generally return in kind.

> businesses

Aaron's reaction to criticism and has been anything but humble.
I am perfectly justified in stating my opinions of his products.
Not everyone is comfortable with open review their work. My
advice to them is to stay off the internet.

> Besides, Aaron Andrew is not advertising here that you should
> appear to disprage his products.

I have no problem with Aaron describing and even advocating
his products here (in fact, I've told him on several occasions
that his restraint against 'advertising' here has been, if
anything, too great!) However when description and advocacy
include statements that my opinion is biased or worthless, I
can certainly point out that his opinion may also be biased.
I didn't stoop to calling it stupid, though I clearly feel he's
made several poor design choices.

> to develop his products based on multiples of 41-EDO or whatnot
> without taking as reference the myriad squabbles and endless
> polemics of this list.

Of course. And I think it's good that different inventors
are pursuing their dreams. But Aaron has also expressed
disappointment at the market response. In that case, more
research wouldn't have hurt.

in fact for anyone who has the vision to be thinking about
microtonality in the first place, remains undiminished.

2/16/2010 8:28:39 PM

Aaron Hunt wrote:

> The only Melodyne user I know of on this forum is Charles Lucy.
> Maybe he can say something about Melodyn's ease of use or
> range of use or learning curve?

There are also Marcel, Aaron Wolf (a 'Plexus owner IIRC),
and Jon Wild (and some of his colleagues, who are using it
in a series of papers), and to a limited extent, myself.

There seems to be agreement that retuning polyphonic music
with Melodyne is very tedious, time-consuming, and rewarding
work. If Caleb is interested in field recording and the
like, he may take to it after all. But given what I gleaned
from previous discussions about his music-making habits, and
the question he asked recently, I wouldn't put it on the list
of 'must haves'. Could be wrong though,

-Carl

ðŸ”—hpiinstruments <aaronhunt@...>

2/16/2010 9:54:59 PM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Chris Vaisvil <chrisvaisvil@...> wrote:
> oh - so.... this is not routing OUT of pianoteq as I thought I read.
>
> This is routing TO pianoteq.
>
> Why would you want to do that? Pianoteq has excellent micro support?

Chris, If you need truly dynamic retuning, using more than 128
pitches, then a tuning table does not suffice. Dynamic channel
pitch bend microtuning allows unlimited dynamic retuning
without the need to ever load a tuning table into the instrument.

Yours,
AAH
=====

ðŸ”—Graham Breed <gbreed@...>

2/16/2010 10:19:06 PM

On 16 February 2010 16:46, cameron <misterbobro@...> wrote:

> I did have a "shredding" "jazz" pianist complain that 5/4 sounds
> dreadfully flat, the one and only such experience I can remember,
> everyone else I've ever "tested" has always found Just intervals,
> including higher limits, to sound "soft", "ancient", "ethnic", and
> so on. :-) Oh, and 7/4 is almost 100% guaranteed to get the
> response "blues!", which is quite telling I think.

I used "A Red, Red Rose" for the examples in my Tripod Notation paper,
with my own transcription and harmonization that may or may not agree
with anybody else's. One thing I found there is that the opening "my
luve's" sounds flat in the retuned versions. I don't think it's an
implementation bug: it really is like that in near-JI. The reason is
that those notes are the third of the chord. It's in tune to JI, but
JI is not in tune to my ears at the start of the piece. Later on, or
on a second listen, it's fine.

The files are out there if anybody wants to compare this.

Graham

ðŸ”—Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...>

2/17/2010 12:09:30 AM

One more thing I should have addressed, and I will keep this very short:

Kalle wrote:
> I wonder if people who listen and play a lot of octatonic (diminished
> scale) music have learned some kind of octatonic template. I often
> hear octatonic passages as undergoing modulation even when they stay
> within one octatonic collection.

I use this scale all the time in my compositions, and I think it's a very,
very cool sound. Harmonically, I still tend to think of it diatonically,
with it being a dom7 with certain extensions - b/#9, maj13, #11, etc.
However, there are ways to emphasize it's "octatonic"ness as well. For
example, over a C aux. diminished scale, play the fourth Db-F#, and then
transpose it up octatonically stepwise. So Db-F#, Eb-G, E-A, F#-Bb, etc.
That'll shake it up a bit.

I can vouch from personal experience that at school, guys would be
practicing symmetrical octatonic patterns until the wee hours of the
morning. Teachers would actually assign patterns for students to learn. And
in general Jazz guys -love- stuff like this, because it's a break from the
"usual" diatonic perception of things. Finding breaks from the "usual"
diatonic perception of things in 12-tet is pretty much all that jazz seems
to be about these days, since we're all bored to tears of the "usual" stuff.

-Mike

ðŸ”—Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...>

2/16/2010 11:59:18 PM

Kalle wrote:
> I'd say that a (hypothetical) person whose musical mother tongue was
> strict JI would probably hear such flipping in A:C:D:G because she
> would listen it within a strict JI template. I tend to hear the
> neutral third as major or minor and think that this is the same
> phenomenon. My brain is trying to fit the neutral third into the
> diatonic category of third which is supposed to come in two
> varieties, minor and major.

What you said is true, but I think there are certain cases in 12-tet
even to a 12-tet "native" where you can hear the difference.

Consider this example: C Eb+ G Bb+ D F+ A C+
vs this one: C E- G B- D F#- A C#-

Note that the examples are closely related: one is a stack of minor
and major thirds, and the other is a stack of major and minor thirds.

In 12-tet, the C# on top of the second example clearly sounds like
some kind of extension of the chord, and in JI, it would be - it would
be 135/64. In 12-tet, the C on top also "feels" like some kind of
extension of the chord, and in JI, it also would be, as 81/40. However
- in 12-tet this same interval is also tempered to be equal to the octave.

And if you play the chord for long enough, the fact that that C-C dyad
is a perfect 4/1 will stand out to you, and change your perception of
things a bit - with that C on top starting to just sound like a benign
octave doubling of the root and not really adding any new "color."

The same thing doesn't happen with the C E G B D F# A C# example in
12tet. There is absolutely no question in anyone's mind that that C#
is a unique chord extension, not just some "doubling at the octave,"
and for pretty obvious reasons. But because the parallel of the C# in
the first chord is a C natural in 12tet - the perception flips of it between
being a unique chord extension (the minor third above the A is prioritized
as the “figure”) and just a low-entropy, benign, octave doubling of the root
(the 4/1 above the C is prioritized as the “figure”).

Maybe this is just me, because my jazz background preempts me to "find
routes" between complex intervals subconsciously as part of the way I
improvise. Or maybe this is universal. I don't know.

> It is very easy to hear 6:7 and 7:9 as some kinds of minor and major
> thirds but if you look at table 1 in Paul Erlich's 22-tone paper you
> see that the 22-equal approximation of 6:7 is a major 3rd(10) while
> ~5:6 is a minor 4th(10). ~7:9 is an aug. 4th(10) or a dim. 5th(10)
> while ~4:5 is a major 4th(10). If you want to hear decatonically, you
> must hear the ~6:7 as belonging to the same generic interval category
> of 3rd(10) as ~7:8/~8:9. I really hope it is not as hard as learning
> new phonemes!

Well, think about the 12-tet "altered scale" - C Db Eb Fb Gb Ab Bb C.
This is used in jazz all the time as a dominant chord, especially
leading to a minor chord. This is because jazz musicians often tend to
think of it more as C Db D# E F# Ab Bb C - with the Fb as a major third.

The fact that that major third "should" be spelled as an Fb, implying
that it's 32/25 or something, didn't really matter to guys who were
just doing this for fun. So, the diesis vanishes, and it becomes a major
third.

Contrast that with the interpretation of the same scale as an "even
more" locrian mode with a diminished fourth. If you play it in that
"context" mentally, it's easy to come up with some ultra-dissonant,
much darker interpretations of the scale, and create voicings and
progressions in which that E sounds very, very, very dissonant and
almost unnaturally so.

So I would say that decatonically the same thing will happen. The
option to just hear the 7/6 as a type of third will always be there.
The only difference is that now you have this new "option" in which
you can hear it in other ways, which didn't exist before.

- Mike

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/17/2010 1:08:57 AM

I'm not familiar with the tune, but what you've got notated there (p.8) from memory (perfect approach, the proper method for folk music outside of custodial work) is a melody that I personally would
harmonize in F Lydian, solving the third problem I bet (probably creating a slew of others LOL).

Mike, would you take a gander at Graham's Red, Red Rose? (And, should
I reword that question hehe.)

ðŸ”—Torsten Anders <torsten.anders@...>

2/17/2010 1:29:13 AM

Kontakt runs on both Mac and Windows. It supports scripting on both
platforms. Kontakt already ships with scripts with several tuning
scripts (e.g., for arbitrary equal temperaments including > 12 pitches
per octave).

I did not use the Scala 2 Kontakt Microtuner of which I sent the link
myself (I write my own Kontakt scripts), but I am surprised it claims
to be Windows only...

Best wishes,
Torsten

University of Plymouth

http://www.torsten-anders.de

ðŸ”—Torsten Anders <torsten.anders@...>

2/17/2010 1:39:34 AM

On 17.02.2010, at 00:51, hpiinstruments wrote:
> Do not dismiss multi-channel pitch bend (GM microtuning) -
> the most universally compatible microtuning solution

Distributing simultaneous pitches with the same sound setting over multiple MIDI channels are are each individually tuned with pitch bend is limiting if you also need multiple channels for different timbres.

This approach is not an issue if you use a DAW like Logic where you can use multiple instances of instruments for different timbres.

Best wishes,
Torsten

--
Torsten Anders
Interdisciplinary Centre for Computer Music Research
University of Plymouth
Office: +44-1752-586219
Private: +44-1752-558917
http://strasheela.sourceforge.net
http://www.torsten-anders.de

ðŸ”—Torsten Anders <torsten.anders@...>

2/17/2010 1:43:06 AM

On 17.02.2010, at 01:24, Chris Vaisvil wrote:
> Where is this script?

The Kontakt script for the Tonal Plexus is part of the latest release of this software (freely available). I can confirm that it works nicely :)

Best wishes,
Torsten

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/17/2010 2:50:02 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Graham Breed <gbreed@...> wrote:
>
> On 17 February 2010 13:08, cameron <misterbobro@...> wrote:
> > http://x31eq.com/magic/tripod.pdf
> >
> > I found this, do you have a link to sound files? You're a very >good writer BTW.
>
> Why thank you! I'm another full time teacher who can't explain
> anything so people can understand it ;-)

Heh, you explain things very well. I *have* to read Diderot and
ilk, as I work in the "art world" (great place for microtonal
musicians!) so actually saying something is something I value
more with each passing day...

>
> MIDI files are in this bundle:
>
> http://x31eq.com/magic/tripod-code.zip
>
> > I'm not familiar with the tune, but what you've got notated there (p.8) from memory (perfect approach, the proper method for folk music outside of custodial work) is a melody that I personally would
> > harmonize in F Lydian, solving the third problem I bet (probably creating a slew of others LOL).
>
> I originally worked it out for guitar, but I use less chords for that.
> I could look at other versions because it's still my standard piece
> for testing notation. I have the chords for a 9-limit blues version
> somewhere. If that ever gets finished you'd better watch out!
>
>
> Graham
>

To be more specific, in a yee anciente modall take on the thing I'd approach the tune you have notated as Hypolydian, and take the entire thing as a sort of half-cadence for a longer piece (the finalis of Hypolydian being F). But, kicking off as it does on e and with phrases ending on c, a "modern" approach could be F Lydian with the first phrase treated as ending in a half-cadence and the second with
the melody landing on the fifth and the harmony on the tonic F. As you have it, in C, I would say that might be viewed as an interesting alternative-history representation of the (alleged) morphing of Hypolydian into today's "Ionian".

ðŸ”—Torsten Anders <torsten.anders@...>

2/17/2010 2:52:55 AM

> What is the practical use of such an ability?
>

- Unlimited number of pitches (per octave and number of octaves)
- A single piece can use different temperaments

Best wishes,
Torsten

2/17/2010 3:08:34 AM

Please Aaron and Carl,

You do not need to behave like that. When insulting in public, you
only put yourself in a bad light (politicians know that pretty well :).

Perhaps it helps if I remark that I hold you both in high esteem. I
learnt a lot from you, Carl; and I certainly like the design of my
Tonal Plexus (e.g., I can even prima-vista play JI notations like theExtended Helmholtz-Ellis notation -- very slowly :).

And doubting the professionalism of each other is irrelevant (I am
saying that with a PhD in music and a MA in composition).

Best wishes,
Torsten

> simply a first class LIAR. A LIAR!

> anywhere near anything I do. I am a professional musician
> and I have more knowledge and understanding of music in
> my excrement than you have in your entire body. You are a
> pretentious charlatan with no musical qualifications
> whatsoever, whose opinion I spit on. and I am sick and
> tired of your tedious pretentious blathering, your absurd
> and insipid insinuations, and your poisonous Internet
> posting demeanor. Really, it is sickening, just absolutely
> sickening the way you behave. You spread misinformation
> across these lists, spewing totally inane garbage about
> everything under the sun, pretending that you know things
> you absolutely do not understand, using nonsensical and
> bizarre Internet tactics which scare away serious rational
> educated people.

> is the last straw. It is idiocy, downright complete idiocy
> for me to continue to even acknowledge your existence.

> discharge of utter B.S. enveloped in smoke screens
> and snake oil, so much the worse for them.

ðŸ”—caleb morgan <calebmrgn@...>

2/17/2010 4:17:43 AM

Well said, Torsten.

/makemicromusic/topicId_21655.html#21656

'DBD' (the author of the query) is similar to me, except I'm already committed to
Logic Pro.

As for my working habits and personality, it would be tedious for you all for
me to go into detail. Let me say some more, though.

I can be very persistent, so Melodyne doesn't scare me.

I like working on a low level with my hands--as opposed to a 'top down' programming approach.

Mike Battaglia thinks like me when it comes to jazz theory and some working habits--I like what I think he said about needing to get to improvisational fluency with the scale/tuning.

I need to have the whole scale under my hands as I work, and also hear the sounds I'm composing with. This rules out notating something first, then doing a Midi version of it. Or writing a piece, then 'tuning' it.

The strangeness and small intervals of microtonal scales interest me as much
as the possibility of perfect consonance.

I don't have university support, nor even a job at this point, so the money for this
is coming out of savings, which will never be replenished.

This means I have to get 'mass produced' stuff, but only stuff that supports complete microtonal tunings of more than 12 notes per octave.

I've developed something of an aversion to cheap synthesis and beeping of all kinds--I prefer the sounds animals and humans make when they sing or talk to the sound of an oscillator.

It pains me to have to take step or to back from the level of synthesis I was accustomed to with hardware, but I expect my chops with Logic, etc. will improve.

Grim determination I've got, persistence, also. Also a checkered career going back 35 years.

I only have a few more shots at writing some good music after many years of experiments. The scarcest ingredients for me are pleasure, hope, confidence, calm.

I'm sorry if I've misled anyone--it's surprisingly hard to get information, so user groups like this are essential.

Give me some more time to check out the link at the top, here.

Caleb

> You can configure your subscription by sending an empty email to one

> tuning-subscribe@yahoogroups.com - join the tuning group.
> tuning-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com - leave the group.
> tuning-nomail@yahoogroups.com - turn off mail from the group.
> tuning-digest@yahoogroups.com - set group to send daily digests.
> tuning-normal@yahoogroups.com - set group to send individual emails.
> tuning-help@yahoogroups.com - receive general help information.

On 17.02.2010, at 12:17, caleb morgan wrote:
> I need to have the whole scale under my hands as I work, and also hear
> the sounds I'm composing with. This rules out notating something
> first, then doing a Midi version of it. Or writing a piece, then
> 'tuning' it.

You made clear that you are looking for a mass-product because of your finance situation.

Nevertheless, for having "all those pitches under your hands as you work", the Tonal Plexus is really a nice option. For free, you can play with the "virtual version" of this instrument, in the shape of the Tonal Plexus Editor (http://www.h-pi.com/TPXEsoftware.html).

Best wishes,
Torsten

ðŸ”—Marcel de Velde <m.develde@...>

2/17/2010 6:22:10 AM

Hi Mike,

I seem to keep replying to your messages, but it is because you give such
nice actual note examples :)

What you said is true, but I think there are certain cases in 12-tet
> even to a 12-tet "native" where you can hear the difference.
>
> Consider this example: C Eb+ G Bb+ D F+ A C+
> vs this one: C E- G B- D F#- A C#-
>
> Note that the examples are closely related: one is a stack of minor
> and major thirds, and the other is a stack of major and minor thirds.
>

I must disagree here.
I think it's wrong to see this as a stack of major and minor thirds.
And to tune it to JI as such, stacking 5/4 and 6/5 thirds sound very much
out of tune to me and makes no sense.
You have to take into account octave equivalence.

Try for instance this:
C Eb G Bb D F A C
1/1 32/27 40/27 16/9 20/9 8/3 10/3 4/1
Perhaps it's easyer to see if we tranpose it up by a whole tone:
D (9/8) - F (4/3) - A (5/3) - C (2/1) - E (5/2) - G (3/1) - B (15/4) - D
(9/2)
As you can see, no out of tune octave, and only 1/1 5/4 3/2 major chords,
and a 9/8 4/3 5/3 minor chord.

And for the other one:
C E G B D F# A C#
You tune it like this::
1/1 5/4 3/2 15/8 9/4 45/16 27/8 135/32
As you can see you also tune a 1/1 5/4 27/16 minor triad (1/1 32/27 40/27 in
inversion)
And you also tune a 1/1 5/4 40/27 major triad with 5/4 27/8 135/128.
I think your tuning is correct here.
And that this is indeed an example of 1/1 5/4 40/27 major triad.
The chord sounds very very dissonant to me no matter the tuning.

>
> In 12-tet, the C# on top of the second example clearly sounds like
> some kind of extension of the chord, and in JI, it would be - it would
> be 135/64. In 12-tet, the C on top also "feels" like some kind of
> extension of the chord, and in JI, it also would be, as 81/40. However
> - in 12-tet this same interval is also tempered to be equal to the octave.
>
> And if you play the chord for long enough, the fact that that C-C dyad
> is a perfect 4/1 will stand out to you, and change your perception of
> things a bit - with that C on top starting to just sound like a benign
> octave doubling of the root and not really adding any new "color."
>

I think you're wrong to think that there would ever be an 81/20 possible in
JI and that the mind sees it as such.
I certainately never hear an 81/20 there when playing this chord in 12tet.
So I don't see this as a good example of switching in perception.

Marcel

ðŸ”—Ozan Yarman <ozanyarman@...>

2/17/2010 8:01:54 AM

Extending a tentacle here...

Carl,

Did you not say:

And don't build a studio around them (GM microtuning) just because Mr
Aaron Hunt
wants to sell you a box with MIDI cables coming out of it.

Maybe your words were not spelled out appropriately above. Some people
might be swayed to follow your words literally against buying H-Pi
instruments products although you did not mean to sway them so.

I perceive a general trend in the tuning list towards degeneration.
This does not bode well for the spirit of microtonality. A few years
ago, the community enjoyed a burst of activity and collaboration. What
triggered this downfall?

Oz.

✩ ✩ ✩
www.ozanyarman.com

> research wouldn't have hurt.

ðŸ”—Ozan Yarman <ozanyarman@...>

2/17/2010 8:14:35 AM

Dear Torsten,

Scordatura uses 16 ports with 16 channels each for GM microtuning. You
can divide each port to 4 parts with a maximum of 20-note polyphony
each. That makes a total of 64 distinct instruments and 1280-voicepolyphony. Even the most colossal of Stravinsky orchestrations could
be microtonally tuned with real-time on-the-fly tuning change support
to achieve unlimited and unprecedented pitch detail given sufficient
effort and dedication.

Oz.

✩ ✩ ✩
www.ozanyarman.com

On Feb 17, 2010, at 11:39 AM, Torsten Anders wrote:

> On 17.02.2010, at 00:51, hpiinstruments wrote:
>> Do not dismiss multi-channel pitch bend (GM microtuning) -
>> the most universally compatible microtuning solution
>
>
> Distributing simultaneous pitches with the same sound setting over
> multiple MIDI channels are are each individually tuned with pitch bend
> is limiting if you also need multiple channels for different timbres.
>
> This approach is not an issue if you use a DAW like Logic where you
> can use multiple instances of instruments for different timbres.
>
> Best wishes,
> Torsten
>
> --
> Torsten Anders
> Interdisciplinary Centre for Computer Music Research
> University of Plymouth
> Office: +44-1752-586219
> Private: +44-1752-558917
> http://strasheela.sourceforge.net
> http://www.torsten-anders.de
>

ðŸ”—Torsten Anders <torsten.anders@...>

2/17/2010 9:36:22 AM

Dear Ozan,

That is great, but AFAIK Scordatura only supports soundfonts. Of
course, that allows for a wide range of timbres, but is not quite the same as some of the other softsynths or samplers recently mentioned
here.

Nevertheless, multi-channel pitch bend is a flexible method for
arbitrary softsynth (that supports multiple MIDI channels and
pitchbend). See my previous message :)
> > On 17.02.2010, at 00:51, hpiinstruments wrote:
> >> Do not dismiss multi-channel pitch bend (GM microtuning) -
> >> the most universally compatible microtuning solution
> >
> > Distributing simultaneous pitches with the same sound setting over
> > multiple MIDI channels are are each individually tuned with pitch
> bend
> > is limiting if you also need multiple channels for different
> timbres.
> >
> > This approach is not an issue if you use a DAW like Logic where you
> > can use multiple instances of instruments for different timbres.
>
Best wishes,
Torsten

--
Torsten Anders
Interdisciplinary Centre for Computer Music Research
University of Plymouth
Office: +44-1752-586219
Private: +44-1752-558917
http://strasheela.sourceforge.net
http://www.torsten-anders.de

On 17.02.2010, at 16:14, Ozan Yarman wrote:

> Dear Torsten,
>
> Scordatura uses 16 ports with 16 channels each for GM microtuning. You
> can divide each port to 4 parts with a maximum of 20-note polyphony
> each. That makes a total of 64 distinct instruments and 1280-voice
> polyphony. Even the most colossal of Stravinsky orchestrations could
> be microtonally tuned with real-time on-the-fly tuning change support
> to achieve unlimited and unprecedented pitch detail given sufficient
> effort and dedication.
>
> Oz.
>
> ✩ ✩ ✩
> www.ozanyarman.com
>
> On Feb 17, 2010, at 11:39 AM, Torsten Anders wrote:
>
> > On 17.02.2010, at 00:51, hpiinstruments wrote:
> >> Do not dismiss multi-channel pitch bend (GM microtuning) -
> >> the most universally compatible microtuning solution
> >
> >
> > Distributing simultaneous pitches with the same sound setting over
> > multiple MIDI channels are are each individually tuned with pitch
> bend
> > is limiting if you also need multiple channels for different
> timbres.
> >
> > This approach is not an issue if you use a DAW like Logic where you
> > can use multiple instances of instruments for different timbres.
> >
> > Best wishes,
> > Torsten
> >
> > --
> > Torsten Anders
> > Interdisciplinary Centre for Computer Music Research
> > University of Plymouth
> > Office: +44-1752-586219
> > Private: +44-1752-558917
> > http://strasheela.sourceforge.net
> > http://www.torsten-anders.de
> >
>
>
>

ðŸ”—Torsten Anders <torsten.anders@...>

2/17/2010 9:51:49 AM

On 17.02.2010, at 17:36, Torsten Anders wrote:
> That is great, but AFAIK Scordatura only supports soundfonts

I am just looking at the Scordatura documentation: I might have been wrong with that statement.

The helpfile SCORDATURA-1r0x7/SCORDATURA Library/Help html/MIDIPorts.html says that "SCORDATURA creates 16 virtual MIDI input and output ports for linking to external applications such as sequencers and notation programs." Does that mean, e.g., that I can route the microtonally tuned MIDI output of Scordatura to, say, Logic/Cubase and play arbitrary AU/VST instruments (as long as they support pitch bend and process multiple MIDI channel input)?

Thank you!

Best wishes,
Torsten

--
Torsten Anders
Interdisciplinary Centre for Computer Music Research
University of Plymouth
Office: +44-1752-586219
Private: +44-1752-558917
http://strasheela.sourceforge.net
http://www.torsten-anders.de

ðŸ”—Torsten Anders <torsten.anders@...>

2/17/2010 9:59:55 AM

On 17.02.2010, at 17:51, Torsten Anders wrote:
> On 17.02.2010, at 17:36, Torsten Anders wrote:
> > That is great, but AFAIK Scordatura only supports soundfonts
>
> I am just looking at the Scordatura documentation: I might have been
> wrong with that statement.
>
> The helpfile SCORDATURA-1r0x7/SCORDATURA Library/Help html/
> MIDIPorts.html says that "SCORDATURA creates 16 virtual MIDI input and
> output ports for linking to external applications such as sequencers
> and notation programs." Does that mean, e.g., that I can route the
> microtonally tuned MIDI output of Scordatura to, say, Logic/Cubase
> and play arbitrary AU/VST instruments (as long as they support pitch
> bend and process multiple MIDI channel input)?
>
OK, to answer that question myself -- yes you can do that (I just played Kontakt in stand-alone mode). Nice :)

Best wishes,
Torsten

ðŸ”—caleb morgan <calebmrgn@...>

2/17/2010 1:33:23 PM

So, I've purchased PianoTeQ, and I'm blown away. It's amazing.

There's just one little problem.

If I want to implement my own tuning, I have to load a Scala file into PianoTeq.

PianoTeQ doesn't have its own tuning editor implemented, unless I'm wrong.

So, I've written out, below, the specs for Caleb's Hairy UnJust Tuning.

So named, because it's like Partch's.

This is the scale I spent some 10 years jamming with & I can play it in my sleep.

In fact, I was able to recall the ratios by memory, by running my
hands over an imaginary keyboard, and hearing it in my head.

Cents are from Partch, plus an online ratio-to-cents converter.

1/1 -------A
16/15------Bb 111.7
13/12------B 138.6
12/11------C 150.6
11/10------C# 165
10/9-------D 182
9/8--------D# 203.9
8/7--------E 231.2
7/6--------F 266.9
32/27------F# 294.1
6/5--------G 315.6
11/9-------G# 347.4

5/4--------A 386.3
14/11------Bb 417.5
9/7--------B 435.1
4/3--------C 498
15/11------C# 536.9
11/8-------D 551.3
7/5--------D# 582.5
10/7-------E 617.5
16/11------F 648.7
22/15?-----F# 663
3/2--------G 702
14/9-------G# 764.9

11/7-------A 782.5
8/5--------Bb 813.7
18/11------B 852.6
5/3--------C 884.4
27/16------C# 905.9
12/7-------D 933.1
7/4--------Eb 968.8
16/9-------E 996.1
9/5--------F 1017.6
20/11------F# 1035
11/6-------G 1049.4
15/8-------G# 1088.3

2/1--------A 1200
(repeat pattern for as many keys as you can)

Can someone, please, please, pretty please, make me a Scala file for Mac?

I'd owe you one. I'll be your friend.

Caleb

ðŸ”—Torsten Anders <torsten.anders@...>

2/17/2010 1:46:22 PM

Dear Caleb,

The Scala scale file format is described here.

http://www.huygens-fokker.org/scala/scl_format.html

Scala scale files are simply text files, you can create them in any
text editor that allows to save plain text (http://www.pure-mac.com/textword.html
).

Best wishes,
Torsten

--
Torsten Anders
Interdisciplinary Centre for Computer Music Research
University of Plymouth
Office: +44-1752-586219
Private: +44-1752-558917
http://strasheela.sourceforge.net
http://www.torsten-anders.de

ðŸ”—Ozan Yarman <ozanyarman@...>

2/17/2010 2:31:31 PM

Hi again Torsten,

Scordatura does indeed work with soundfonts, free samples of which can
be found on the internet, purchased or created via conversion from
existing libraries such as those of Logic. I used Translator byChicken Systems for conversion purposes.

Yes, other soft-synths geared towards physical modelling, realistic
sampling or reconstructive phrase modelling will naturally excel over
SF2. But then, microtuning is seldom an area of focus in these synths:
Aural realism gains the supremacy against "freedom of pitch".

Scordatura turns the tables over, so that total freedom and control of
pitch is given first priority. This is, after all, an indispensible
feature to a microtonal composer - even over aural realism.

Nevertheless, I think that two recent microtonal compositions of mine
made through Scordatura, "East Dreams West" and "Icicle Caverns"
demonstrate that a modest amount of realism is very much achievable
even when using 16-bit 44.1 Hz mono soundfonts.

As for linking Scordatura to Logic... As far as I know, you can
configure Sibelius (for instance) to send MIDI data to all the ports
and parts of Scordatura, which can in turn send the data to the
relevant output destinations after tuning the incoming notes. The soft-
instruments hooked up to Scordatura must, of course, be able to respond to GM pitch bending.

Another thing to be mindful of if using Sibelius as the sender, is
that you need to specify your own manual soundset under Sibelius
Playback Devices in order to be able to choose a channel number in the
instrument Mixer window. This is necessary if you have specified
several intrument patch groups in a virtual Scordatura port.

I have myself failed to create instruments in Logic Pro which can
receive MIDI data from Scordatura's output ports. Even if it could be
done, a 16 port x 4 channel part setup would require 64 distinct
tracks in the arrange window. Very possible, but surely a resource
gulper. If anybody succeeds to hook Logic to Scordatura, and if they
have discovered a way to disable MIDI input to Logic from your MIDI
controller, please let me know.

Oz.

✩ ✩ ✩
www.ozanyarman.com

On Feb 17, 2010, at 7:51 PM, Torsten Anders wrote:

> On 17.02.2010, at 17:36, Torsten Anders wrote:
>> Dear Ozan,
>>
>> That is great, but AFAIK Scordatura only supports soundfonts. Of
>> course, that allows for a wide range of timbres, but is not quite the
>> same as some of the other softsynths or samplers recently mentioned
>> here.
>>
>> Nevertheless, multi-channel pitch bend is a flexible method for
>> arbitrary softsynth (that supports multiple MIDI channels and
>> pitchbend). See my previous message :)
>>
>
>
> I am just looking at the Scordatura documentation: I might have been
> wrong with that statement.
>
> The helpfile SCORDATURA-1r0x7/SCORDATURA Library/Help html/
> MIDIPorts.html says that "SCORDATURA creates 16 virtual MIDI input and
> output ports for linking to external applications such as sequencers
> and notation programs." Does that mean, e.g., that I can route the
> microtonally tuned MIDI output of Scordatura to, say, Logic/Cubase
> and play arbitrary AU/VST instruments (as long as they support pitch
> bend and process multiple MIDI channel input)?
>
> Thank you!
>
> Best wishes,
> Torsten

OK, to answer that question myself -- yes you can do that (I just
played Kontakt in stand-alone mode). Nice :)

Best wishes,
Torsten

2/17/2010 2:33:56 PM

Scordatura's GM microtuning also efficiently solves the problem of
uninterrupted slide-step-slide pitch bending described here:

http://www.synful.com/SynfulPitchWheel.htm

Oz.

✩ ✩ ✩
www.ozanyarman.com

On Feb 17, 2010, at 7:59 PM, Torsten Anders wrote:

> On 17.02.2010, at 17:51, Torsten Anders wrote:
>> On 17.02.2010, at 17:36, Torsten Anders wrote:

>>
>> I am just looking at the Scordatura documentation: I might have been
>> wrong with that statement.

>> MIDIPorts.html says that "SCORDATURA creates 16 virtual MIDI input

>> output ports for linking to external applications such as sequencers
>> and notation programs." Does that mean, e.g., that I can route the
>> microtonally tuned MIDI output of Scordatura to, say, Logic/Cubase

ðŸ”—Daniel Forró <dan.for@...>

2/17/2010 4:30:11 PM

On 18 Feb 2010, at 7:31 AM, Ozan Yarman wrote:

> Nevertheless, I think that two recent microtonal compositions of > mine made through Scordatura, "East Dreams West" and "Icicle > Caverns" demonstrate that a modest amount of realism is very much > achievable even when using 16-bit 44.1 Hz mono soundfonts.
>

As for imitative authenticity the most important is a way of playing the sound - facture, texture, instrument's typical tricks, arpeggios, articulation, ornamentation, modulations, imitationg of high positions on fretboard on stringed instruments and similar. Not the authenticity of the sound itself.

Of course for experimental use we can use instrumental sounds out of their the most typical range, with non-authentic textures and articulation, or on music which is physically impossible to perform on real instruments (with big jumps, too fast, without breathing, too long sustained notes, very wide chords, chords with more notes then 10, difficult rhythms, polytempi, microintervals etc.). Then even with the basic GM set there can be interesting results.

Daniel Forro

ðŸ”—Chris Vaisvil <chrisvaisvil@...>

2/17/2010 4:43:22 PM

Seems to be an appropriate discussion to put this reminder:

Gigabytes of free soundfonts at this address.

http://clones.soonlabel.com/public/sfbank/

On another topic - Daniel what does facture mean (in context)?

Thanks,

Chris

> > Caverns" demonstrate that a modest amount of realism is very much
> > achievable even when using 16-bit 44.1 Hz mono soundfonts.

> the sound - facture, texture, instrument's typical tricks, arpeggios,
> articulation, ornamentation, modulations, imitationg of high
> positions on fretboard on stringed instruments and similar. Not the
> authenticity of the sound itself.

ðŸ”—Torsten Anders <torsten.anders@...>

2/17/2010 4:27:16 PM

On 17.02.2010, at 20:30, Chris Vaisvil wrote:
> I wonder if the multiple channel pitch bend will work with any VSTi > that support omni in.
>

Unfortunately, this does not work. The instrument must support that individual MIDI channels as tuned differently, and not all instruments do that :-/

Best wishes,
Torsten

--
Torsten Anders
Interdisciplinary Centre for Computer Music Research
University of Plymouth
Office: +44-1752-586219
Private: +44-1752-558917
http://strasheela.sourceforge.net
http://www.torsten-anders.de

ðŸ”—Daniel Forró <dan.for@...>

2/17/2010 6:07:12 PM

Maybe just my wrong English, it's used in German language as well in Czech. Maybe better to say voicing, settting, a way how music for concrete instrument is set, done, written, performed, put together. The same music will be arranged in a different way for piano, guitar, violine, string quartet, brassband, pipe organ, koto, zymbalon, marimba... - because each instrument and ensemble has different features, possibilities and way of playing. Is there an appropriate English term for this?

Daniel Forro

On 18 Feb 2010, at 9:43 AM, Chris Vaisvil wrote:

>
>
> On another topic - Daniel what does facture mean (in context)?
>
> Thanks,
>
> Chris

ðŸ”—Chris Vaisvil <chrisvaisvil@...>

2/17/2010 6:15:38 PM

Hi Daniel,

I'm not sure there is an English equivalent.
I do know what you mean now - every instrument has its own natural phrasings
and tendencies.

Chris

On Wed, Feb 17, 2010 at 9:07 PM, Daniel Forró <dan.for@...> wrote:

>
>
> Maybe just my wrong English, it's used in German language as well in
> Czech. Maybe better to say voicing, settting, a way how music for
> concrete instrument is set, done, written, performed, put together.
>

ðŸ”—Daniel Forró <dan.for@...>

2/17/2010 9:43:59 PM

Hi, Chris,

not only phrasing and articulation, but also for example polyphony - how many voices can the instrument play in the chords (if it can play chords at all), and what's possible concerning voicing (narrow, wide). For example a guitar has different voicing for the chords than violin or mandoline. And chords on guitar can be played in quick arpeggio down or up, or rasgueado, which is not possible on the violin. Violin chords are usually broken in two dyads, or arpeggiated up/down. Guitar can play plucked tremolo on one string, violin not (only single pizzicato, but tremolo can be achieved with the bow, of course). Mandoline and some double stringed balalaika can easily play tremolo with a plectre, but also some instruments without doubled string can do it (koto...).

Or harp is strictly diatonic instrument which can't play quick chromatic scale. One of the reasons why big orchestras have two harps.

Or take higher positions on the fretboard of stringed instruments combined with open strings - such chords like on the guitar you will never find on the keyboard, also because sometimes there's real unisono between open string and same note fretted on the other string...

Or take amplitude envelope of the sound - piano, marimba or harpsichord music looks totally different than accordeon, organ or reed organ music with sustained notes which are impossible on the previous (sustain pedal on the piano has different effect). It directly dictates how ideal music for each of this instruments should look. Harpsichord toccata or highly ornamentated Couperin's work has different structure and character than organ prelude with long sustained chords. Mozart's piano music is different than Chopin's music not only because of different music styles, but also thanks to the invention of the sustain pedal which created specific piano music different from that written for harpsichord, clavichord, pipe organ or reed organ. Nothing to say about jazz organ, for example Hammond with very specific playing technique (palm and finger glissandos, block chords, quick riffs and licks, tremolos, using of percussion effect, Leslie speed switching, vibrato/chorus, clearly defined role of both hands...).

Some instruments are predestined for playing polyphony (keyboards), the others are limited in this (strings), with some others it's almost impossible even when they can play chords (marimba).
Also some other elements of music have their specialties and limitations on certain instruments, for example trills and tremolos. Or take a glissando - for example on trombones there's a lot of limitations, the longest tritone glissando must start from certain notes only... Fretless string instruments can play fully continuous glissando, fretted ones only chromatic glissando...

While keyboard instruments nowadays use five finger technique for passages, string instruments can use only four fingers. This has a great impact on the music. I can often recognize if music was composed on the piano or on the guitar - piano has unlimited passage structures, and pentachords are often to hear, or groups with less or more neighboring tones, while guitar relies on tetrachordal structure or less. I mentioned this for the first time when playing with fusion group in 1975 we studied works of Corea's Return to Forever. "Mediterranean Sundance" by guitarist Al DiMeola had totally different character of passages than works of Corea who of course invented them on the piano. So it was more difficult to play them on piano than on guitar, as I remember, and it was possible only with some special piano fingering, and still not so comfortable.

Also instrument specific things and tactile human interface must be taken into the account how ideal music (and that means also relatively easily performable or improvisable) for that instrument will look. For example I know zillions of piano works using white keys and black keys as two groups, each one for every hand, played alternatively or together. So many compositions that I personally try to avoid this in my own works, it sounds almost like a cheap old trick good only to attract girls during improvisation :-). The other instruments have similar features. If you consider tactile action as priority, you can find interesting things directly reflected in the music. I did more compositions where I have selected this "tactile" attitude, for example shapes of the fingerings on the fretboard or keyboard, and it gave me interesting patterns I would never find when the main approach would be pure notes and their organization.

Daniel Forro

On 18 Feb 2010, at 11:15 AM, Chris Vaisvil wrote:

>
> Hi Daniel,
>
> I'm not sure there is an English equivalent.
> I do know what you mean now - every instrument has its own natural > phrasings and tendencies.
>
> Chris
>

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/18/2010 1:09:59 AM

Factura is Latin, the making of something. In English the most obvious example is in "manufacture", literally, "handmade" (contrasting a product of nature for example).

Factura usually means "invoice" (or "bill"?, my monetary/accounting knowledge is pathetic...) in most Indo-European languages today, I suspect. That's what it usually means in Slovene and German (Zollfaktura at the border for example), Croatian, Russian...

Anyway in English this meaning of the Latin factura would be instrumentation, setting, or arrangement.

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Daniel Forró <dan.for@...> wrote:
>
> Maybe just my wrong English, it's used in German language as well in
> Czech. Maybe better to say voicing, settting, a way how music for
> concrete instrument is set, done, written, performed, put together.

> violine, string quartet, brassband, pipe organ, koto, zymbalon,
> marimba... - because each instrument and ensemble has different
> features, possibilities and way of playing. Is there an appropriate
> English term for this?

> Daniel Forro

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/18/2010 3:55:54 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...> wrote:

> > I did have a "shredding" "jazz" pianist complain that 5/4 sounds dreadfully flat, the one and only such experience I can remember, everyone else I've ever "tested" has always found Just intervals, including higher limits, to sound "soft", "ancient", "ethnic", and so on. :-) Oh, and 7/4 is almost 100% guaranteed to get the response "blues!", which is quite telling I think.
>
> Well, I'm a jazz pianist. And, in certain circles, one could say that
> I "shred." And now that I've destroyed all perception of humility for
> myself, I might as well weigh in and say that sometimes, especially at
> first, 5/4 did sound dreadfully flat. However, this has to do with the
> fact that as Kalle mentioned, us jazz guys tend to take the 400 cent
> interval as being a lot more than just a 5/4 - its use as 81/64 is
> very common (as in the tendency of jazz musicians to use quartal and
> quintal chords), and probably some other intuitive ways to use that
> interval that I'm not thinking of. That was one of the main problems
> for me at first - I tended to always think in terms of the circle of
> fifths. It's also a bit too flat to create much tension as a leading
> tone.
>
> Nowadays I actually do like 5/4 quite a bit, but I'd prefer 81/32 >for
> a chord like C G Bb+ D F+ A C+ E, or 32/21 for a chord like C F Bb >Eb
> G.
>
> As for 7/4, my response as well as that of my friends at school was
> that it was also very "flat" at first, since were used to thinking >of
> a minor seventh as being accessible via the circle of fourths if
> necessary. Nowadays I just hear it as a separate animal from the >usual
> 12-tet "minor seventh" though.

This points out a major problem in the presentation of the "regular mapping paradigm": the emphasis on "tempering out" intervals, whereas in actual practice the concern really amounts more to "tempering IN" intervallic possibilities. "Fa-of-Fa sounding the same as Te" means, in practice (however it described) a lot to a many musicians, whereas
"tempering out 64/63" does not. The seventh of 12-tET also has a direct parallel in 5-limit JI as well as this Pythagorean equivalent:
two 5/4s and a 9/8, however ordered, make a "pun" with 7/4. "An augmented sixth equals a minor seventh" needs to mentioned, not just "tempering out 225/224". You could have a temperament with a pure 7/4 divvied up into two M3's and a whole tone, or 12-tET, both with the same "pun" found in the lower harmonic series.

> Just curious, have you written many pieces making extensive use of
> this interval? I have only heard one piece of yours, a vocal
> composition from a long time ago. Maybe you're just more dialed into
> these higher-limit intervals than I am.

Hardly ever used 9/7 at all, ever, I tend to find it garish, like brightly painted fiberglass sculpture (depending on context of course). I prefer either a high third like 14/11, or most of all a "thirth" or "fourd" in the region between 13/10 and 17/13. I'll float some music your way, got a lot of catching up to do, it's beaurocratic season here, doing the after-action stuff of 2009's projects and figuring out 2010 concerts etc.

ðŸ”—Torsten Anders <torsten.anders@...>

2/18/2010 4:44:09 AM

Dear Chris,
On 17.02.2010, at 20:30, Chris Vaisvil wrote:
> I wonder if the multiple channel pitch bend will work with any VSTi
> that support omni in.

Like you, I was at first fooled to try this out with MIDI omni mode. This cannot work, because omni mode simply ignores the channel information and plays back all notes on the current channel.

Instead, what is needed are instruments with poly mode that allows to play multiple instruments on different channels at the same time. For our purposes, we just need to run the same instrument on as many channels as our maximum number of simultaneous notes will be (in Scordatura, individual MIDI channels can be enabled/disabled we only a subset of the 16 channels is needed).

Best wishes,
Torsten

--
Torsten Anders
Interdisciplinary Centre for Computer Music Research
University of Plymouth
Office: +44-1752-586219
Private: +44-1752-558917
http://strasheela.sourceforge.net
http://www.torsten-anders.de

ðŸ”—caleb morgan <calebmrgn@...>

2/18/2010 5:45:46 AM

P.S. i noticed I mapped your scale at quite low octave. If you want to change the octave of the whole keyboard, just select all Command-A, then type Command-' (apostrophy) for everything to go UP, and Command-/ for everything to go down.

Is it correct now?

-A

Well, I'm at a disadvantage because I'm trying to get by using a D50 keyboard as a midi controller instead of one of my 3 full-size Midi controllers. The D50 only has 5 octaves, which means my 3-octave scale doesn't fit twice in its entirety, but the D50 fits underneath my computer desk, so that's why I chose it.

Yeah, there are two things I'm trying to do.

1) Raise the sound of the scale approximately 2 octaves. Most of the pitches are useless in too low a register.

2) Make the 1/1, on the A key, sound as an 'A'--that is, some '2 multiple' of 440/220/110/55/27.5 cps.

Once I get the hang of this gear, it will be amazing.

>
>
>

ðŸ”—caleb morgan <calebmrgn@...>

2/18/2010 7:24:29 AM

So far, 2 hours of frustration.

Just want to hear my old scale in a high-enough register, on A 440, with
a simple mapping, so that it repeats every 36 keys.

The text-based Scala format has some obvious advantages, but also some
obvious disadvantages--you can't make a tweak and hear it.

Everything I've done so far has made only weirdness.

This scale should sound quite 'normal' and 'consonant'.

Patience, O brave warrior.

Caleb

ðŸ”—Daniel Forró <dan.for@...>

2/18/2010 7:38:16 AM

On 18 Feb 2010, at 9:44 PM, Torsten Anders wrote:
> Instead, what is needed are instruments with poly mode that allows to
> play multiple instruments on different channels at the same time. For
> our purposes, we just need to run the same instrument on as man
>

This mode is called "Multi", sometimes also 3B, and was not a part of original MIDI standard, that's the reason why it's not possible to select it by Mode messages. Usually it's necessary to use SysEx, and many instruments are automatically in permanent Multimode.

Daniel Forro

ðŸ”—caleb morgan <calebmrgn@...>

file, and the keyboard map.

sounding 2/1.

But it's not doing that.

ðŸ”—caleb morgan <calebmrgn@...>

2/18/2010 7:53:50 AM

Ah, your mistake was in the Scala file format.

When in doubt, read the instructions.

The first pitch SHOULD NOT be 1/1.

The last pitch, therefore, SHOULD BE 2/1.

Ok,

Well, for instruments on their each channel
Kontakt and Garritan Personal Orchestra can do at least 16 individual
instruments (sample sets)
Dimension pro is 4 or 6

and a number of my other VSTi can do that.

What is CSE?

ðŸ”—caleb morgan <calebmrgn@...>

2/18/2010 8:56:00 AM

http://www.box.net/shared/m37jhti1og

bottom of page one. Title: "I'm so happy!"

Here's pianoteq as a plug-in inside Logic.

Converted to Mp3 format with Audacity.

Uses Caleb's Hairy 36-note scale.

Haven't played this scale in years--it's like having an old friend for dinner.

Once the tech works for you, it's wonderful.

CPU meter on Mac ominously high, however.

Virtual instruments mean, among other things, no background noise.

ðŸ”—Chris Vaisvil <chrisvaisvil@...>

2/18/2010 9:12:21 AM

Sounds very interesting!

Has a "growl" to it in places - I imagine that is the just intervals?
Makes me wonder what that would sound like on a guitar through a metal
distortion set up. I'm thinking it would be really cool.

Chirs

Yeah, that's the Just 'buzz'.

With a fuzz box, you'd hear the fundamental, even more so.

This sounds even more in tune than the old Tx802's did. I'm not
hearing much 'wave' or slow beating, at all.

This isn't exactly great music, but it's a thrill to hear this old
scale of mine on new gear after a long wait.

Caleb

2/18/2010 9:07:51 AM

It's a tuning editor designed by Aaron Hunt. It's free.

I'm not sure, at this point, whether I'll try to learn it, or just
go with editing Scala files with a text editor.

They load very fast, and the lag-time isn't too difficult, once
you understand the (simple) Scala format.

Caleb

>
> Sounds very interesting!
>
> Has a "growl" to it in places - I imagine that is the just intervals?
> Makes me wonder what that would sound like on a guitar through a metal
> distortion set up. I'm thinking it would be really cool.
>
> Chirs

ðŸ”—Carl Lumma <carl@...>

2/18/2010 10:49:17 AM

Hi Caleb,

In the past, I've suggested that Scala files make an ideal
"literary format" for microtuning. That's something like
HTML was to traditional programming languages (though web
technologies have evolved in a bizarre fashion, where today
traditional programming languages are use to generate HTML
and humans seldom read or write it directly).

But yeah, anyway, I think there's a lot to gain by writing
them by hand (not to detract from CSE, which I've never used).
Especially useful is the ! for comments. I annotate my Scala
files with all kinds of information, like lattice diagrams
and so on. They're plain text, so you can search inside them
right from Spotlight in OS X, or the search thingy in later
versions of Windows. And if you send them to someone else,
all they need is a text editor to read them, or any one of a
growing number of soft synths to try them.

In fact I hope the format long outlives Scala itself.

-Carl

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, caleb morgan <calebmrgn@...> wrote:
>
> It's a tuning editor designed by Aaron Hunt. It's free.
>
> I'm not sure, at this point, whether I'll try to learn it, or just
> go with editing Scala files with a text editor.
>
> They load very fast, and the lag-time isn't too difficult, once
> you understand the (simple) Scala format.
>
> Caleb
>

ðŸ”—Chris Vaisvil <chrisvaisvil@...>

Chris

ðŸ”—caleb morgan <calebmrgn@...>

2/18/2010 10:25:13 AM

Not at all. Try away.

However, my polite but very capable attorneys will be in touch with you.

(Just kidding!)

It's basically the Harry Partch scale with a few notes changed.

It has 36 notes so it fits on a standard keyboard better than Partch.

It doesn't have anything below a 16/15, or above a 15/8--so it's
lopsided, in a way.

This is because I couldn't think of a pitch closely related to 1/1
harmonically, that was closer to 1/1, that I wanted.

It has the following 'fundamentals': /1, /3, /5, /7, /9, /11, and /
15. The rest of the pitches are just overtones of these pitches.

My attorneys Weasel, Bitum, & Chew will be interested in your progress.

Caleb
