ðŸ”—Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...>

2/18/2010 10:20:06 PM

> This points out a major problem in the presentation of the "regular mapping paradigm": the emphasis on "tempering out" intervals, whereas in actual practice the concern really amounts more to "tempering IN" intervallic possibilities. "Fa-of-Fa sounding the same as Te" means, in practice (however it described) a lot to a many musicians, whereas
> "tempering out 64/63" does not. The seventh of 12-tET also has a direct parallel in 5-limit JI as well as this Pythagorean equivalent:
> two 5/4s and a 9/8, however ordered, make a "pun" with 7/4. "An augmented sixth equals a minor seventh" needs to mentioned, not just "tempering out 225/224". You could have a temperament with a pure 7/4 divvied up into two M3's and a whole tone, or 12-tET, both with the same "pun" found in the lower harmonic series.

I don't get this "pun" thing. I thought I understood it a while ago,
but I don't. A pun is what, just a two JI intervals that tend to be
perceived as equivalent? So 5/4 and 50001/40000 make a pun?

> > Just curious, have you written many pieces making extensive use of
> > this interval? I have only heard one piece of yours, a vocal
> > composition from a long time ago. Maybe you're just more dialed into
> > these higher-limit intervals than I am.
>
> Hardly ever used 9/7 at all, ever, I tend to find it garish, like brightly painted fiberglass sculpture (depending on context of course). I prefer either a high third like 14/11, or most of all a "thirth" or "fourd" in the region between 13/10 and 17/13. I'll float some music your way, got a lot of catching up to do, it's beaurocratic season here, doing the after-action stuff of 2009's projects and figuring out 2010 concerts etc.

Haha, I like your analogy! Fiberglass sculpture. Well whenever you get
a chance, float it right on over.

-Mike

>

ðŸ”—Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...>

2/18/2010 10:51:30 PM

> Yes I understood this.
> I ment that even when I'm mistuning it in JI I can still interpret it in a different way.
> So it goes for 12tet even more so.
> I think there's no fipflopping, the brain makes a decision (though it can be made to change what it picked), but that there's also not good enough ear resolution to hear for sure no matter the tuning.
>
> Marcel

That's what flipflopping is. It makes a decision, then it changes it,
then it changes it, then it changes it, then it changes it, then it
changes it, then it changes it, then it changes it, then it changes
it, then it changes it, then it changes it...

The best example I've found in 12-tet so far is the C Eb G Bb D F A C example.

> I must disagree here.
> I think it's wrong to see this as a stack of major and minor thirds.
> And to tune it to JI as such, stacking 5/4 and 6/5 thirds sound very much out of tune to me and makes no sense.
> You have to take into account octave equivalence.
>
> Try for instance this:
> C Eb G Bb D F A C
> 1/1 32/27 40/27 16/9 20/9 8/3 10/3 4/1

This is a beautiful chord as well. The 40/27 makes it sound very, very
interesting. But it's really just a different chord than tuning it as
6/5 and 5/4's all the way.

I actually like the sound of the comma-shifted root on top. It doesn't
sound like an octave anymore, because it isn't an octave, and it isn't
supposed to be. That being said... I think most naive listeners would
think that it is an octave.

Your solution, my solution, and all of the partial solutions in
between coexist simultaneously within the 12-tet tempered version of
this chord. And although I have no way of testing this, I'm pretty
sure my qualitative experience of this chord involves an ambiguous
flip flop between them (until "musical context" kicks in, that is, at
which point we move on to something else).

At the very least I can say that it DOES involve an ambiguous flip
flop between my perception of the C-C as 4/1 on the outside and the
perception of the whole thing as bunch of stacked and very crunchy
sounding minor thirds, of which the C on top is a novel chord
extension. No wait, no it's not, it's just another C. But it is... but
it should be... but it's not. It confuses my ear in that way.

My hypothesis is that all of this corresponds to a flip flop
internally between JI "states," because it's like flipping between
hearing the C-C as 4/1 and 81/20. Maybe yes, maybe no. I don't know if
there's a way to test it, but that paradigm has been connecting a lot
of musical dots for me so far.

-Mike

ðŸ”—Michael <djtrancendance@...>

2/18/2010 11:06:19 PM

I'm trying to figure out either why this is...or if it's just me.

If I play four consecutive notes as a chord from 6TET they sound better than 7TET (as expected...since 7TET has more critical band roughness due to closer tones).
However, if I try the same thing with 5TET vs. 6TET...6TET actually sounds better to me: the beating seems more natural despite mathematics telling me it should feel more rough.

Another thing I noticed (after testing with several ratios) is my ear's sense of beating between two sine waves mostly stops around 6/5 (IE playing two sines 6/5 apart) feeling "very smooth" and becomes completely inaudible around 4/3 IE "perfectly smooth". The brain seems to "click" between different sectors of dissonance around each area IE the difference in perceived dissonance between 1.18 and 1.2 (6/5) sounds huge...but between 1.16 and 1.18 it sounds negligibly different.

Any clue why...or is it just my personal taste in hearing? Or...where/how does your brain react to different types of dyads...past what intervals does the beating seem to resolve to you?

ðŸ”—martinsj013 <martinsj@...>

2/18/2010 11:33:56 PM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...> wrote:
> > two 5/4s and a 9/8, however ordered, make a "pun" with 7/4.
>
> I don't get this "pun" thing. I thought I understood it a while ago,
> but I don't. A pun is what, just a two JI intervals that tend to be
> perceived as equivalent? So 5/4 and 50001/40000 make a pun?

I think that's right, except that both the ratios have to have a "meaning" to make a pun - so 5/4 and 81/64 make a pun (because 81/64 "means" four 5ths reduced). Not sure if 50001/40000 "means" anything - can't be bothered to factorise it!

Steve.

ðŸ”—Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...>

2/18/2010 11:40:11 PM

OK, so if I'm in C minor... and then over C minor, because I'm a hip jazz
guy, let's say I arpeggiate a C minor triad. Then I go up a whole tone and
play a D minor triad. Then I decide to play "out of key" and keep going up
in whole tones, arpeggiating an E minor triad, then an F# minor triad, then
a G# minor triad, then an A# minor triad, and then a B# minor triad -- in
12-equal that B# minor triad is the same thing as C minor.

So when you do this, it sounds like you're going way out into harmonic warp
drive factor 9 space, and then suddenly you're back at the root, and it's
kind of anticlimactic, and the lick has basically failed.

Is that a "pun," between the pythagorean comma and 1/1?

-Mike

On Fri, Feb 19, 2010 at 2:33 AM, martinsj013 <martinsj@...> wrote:

>
>
> --- In tuning@yahoogroups.com <tuning%40yahoogroups.com>, Mike Battaglia
> <battaglia01@...> wrote:
> > > two 5/4s and a 9/8, however ordered, make a "pun" with 7/4.
> >
> > I don't get this "pun" thing. I thought I understood it a while ago,
> > but I don't. A pun is what, just a two JI intervals that tend to be
> > perceived as equivalent? So 5/4 and 50001/40000 make a pun?
>
> I think that's right, except that both the ratios have to have a "meaning"
> to make a pun - so 5/4 and 81/64 make a pun (because 81/64 "means" four 5ths
> reduced). Not sure if 50001/40000 "means" anything - can't be bothered to
> factorise it!
>
> Steve.
>
>
>

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/19/2010 1:30:36 AM

I would not call martinj's example a pun from the harmonic series because the kind of "pun" I'm thinking of would happen, in your example, at the 53rd Pythagorean fifth. To me, a pun is a kind of logical homophonic vector "occuring in nature" so to speak. Human modalities implementing these are going to tend to be more immediately tangible as "sensible" and "harmonious", I think, for the simple reason that they mimic suggested modalities within the very sensible and, well, harmonious, harmonic series.

Forcing a heavy-handed pun of 81/64 and 5/4 is the grand failure of
Western music, in my opinion, not only because the sheer size of the interval "tempered out", but also because there is no connection between the naked characters (rather than rough scalar proximities) of the intervals punned, and of those creating the pun: four times "smooth" to get to "jangly" just doesn't make a good pun with a single step to "super smooth". Whereas smoothest third, smoothest third, smoothest second (aug 6) to get to a pun with the smoothest seventh works in both consistency of character and in sheer proximity (size of comma- more than 3 times smaller than the syntonic).

A search of the archives here at the tuning list turns up only a passing mention, and no disscusion at all, of what is perhaps the most obvious and simple "pun" in the low harmonics, which strikes me as very strange and hard to believe, perhaps the search function is not good. Herman Miller certainly knows all about it, as it is the "key" to one of his temperaments- the most immediately useful, by far and away, of any of the "regular temperaments" found at this list. This pun is both concretely more simple and more radical than "tempering out the syntonic comma", yet is also dealing with a comma much smaller: a "no brainer" so to speak. Will someone guess or exlain which one? :-)

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...> wrote:
>
> OK, so if I'm in C minor... and then over C minor, because I'm a hip jazz
> guy, let's say I arpeggiate a C minor triad. Then I go up a whole tone and
> play a D minor triad. Then I decide to play "out of key" and keep going up
> in whole tones, arpeggiating an E minor triad, then an F# minor triad, then
> a G# minor triad, then an A# minor triad, and then a B# minor triad -- in
> 12-equal that B# minor triad is the same thing as C minor.
>
> So when you do this, it sounds like you're going way out into harmonic warp
> drive factor 9 space, and then suddenly you're back at the root, and it's
> kind of anticlimactic, and the lick has basically failed.
>
> Is that a "pun," between the pythagorean comma and 1/1?
>
> -Mike
>
>
> On Fri, Feb 19, 2010 at 2:33 AM, martinsj013 <martinsj@...> wrote:
>
> >
> >
> > --- In tuning@yahoogroups.com <tuning%40yahoogroups.com>, Mike Battaglia
> > <battaglia01@> wrote:
> > > > two 5/4s and a 9/8, however ordered, make a "pun" with 7/4.
> > >
> > > I don't get this "pun" thing. I thought I understood it a while ago,
> > > but I don't. A pun is what, just a two JI intervals that tend to be
> > > perceived as equivalent? So 5/4 and 50001/40000 make a pun?
> >
> > I think that's right, except that both the ratios have to have a "meaning"
> > to make a pun - so 5/4 and 81/64 make a pun (because 81/64 "means" four 5ths
> > reduced). Not sure if 50001/40000 "means" anything - can't be bothered to
> > factorise it!
> >
> > Steve.
> >
> >
> >
>

ðŸ”—Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...>

2/19/2010 1:43:02 AM

> I would not call martinj's example a pun from the harmonic series because the kind of "pun" I'm thinking of would happen, in your example, at the 53rd Pythagorean fifth. To me, a pun is a kind of logical homophonic vector "occuring in nature" so to speak. Human modalities implementing these are going to tend to be more immediately tangible as "sensible" and "harmonious", I think, for the simple reason that they mimic suggested modalities within the very sensible and, well, harmonious, harmonic series.

Why would my pun happen at the 53rd fifth? I set it up so that 6 whole
steps tempers right into the octave. My question was mainly if the
word "pun" refers to the perceptual experience of harmonically "going
somewhere" and then arriving somewhere else due to tempering... as in
whoaa, this guy's going way out... wait hold on.. now we're back at
the I chord again. Hmmmm, this is awkward.

That's the most scientific way I can think to put it at least.

> Forcing a heavy-handed pun of 81/64 and 5/4 is the grand failure of
> Western music, in my opinion, not only because the sheer size of the interval "tempered out", but also because there is no connection between the naked characters (rather than rough scalar proximities) of the intervals punned, and of those creating the pun: four times "smooth" to get to "jangly" just doesn't make a good pun with a single step to "super smooth". Whereas smoothest third, smoothest third, smoothest second (aug 6) to get to a pun with the smoothest seventh works in both consistency of character and in sheer proximity (size of comma- more than 3 times smaller than the syntonic).
>
> A search of the archives here at the tuning list turns up only a passing mention, and no disscusion at all, of what is perhaps the most obvious and simple "pun" in the low harmonics, which strikes me as very strange and hard to believe, perhaps the search function is not good. Herman Miller certainly knows all about it, as it is the "key" to one of his temperaments- the most immediately useful, by far and away, of any of the "regular temperaments" found at this list. This pun is both concretely more simple and more radical than "tempering out the syntonic comma", yet is also dealing with a comma much smaller: a "no brainer" so to speak. Will someone guess or exlain which one? :-)

I... wish I knew what a pun was.

I'm gonna guess he tempers out the schisma?

-Mike

> --- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...> wrote:
> >
> > OK, so if I'm in C minor... and then over C minor, because I'm a hip jazz
> > guy, let's say I arpeggiate a C minor triad. Then I go up a whole tone and
> > play a D minor triad. Then I decide to play "out of key" and keep going up
> > in whole tones, arpeggiating an E minor triad, then an F# minor triad, then
> > a G# minor triad, then an A# minor triad, and then a B# minor triad -- in
> > 12-equal that B# minor triad is the same thing as C minor.
> >
> > So when you do this, it sounds like you're going way out into harmonic warp
> > drive factor 9 space, and then suddenly you're back at the root, and it's
> > kind of anticlimactic, and the lick has basically failed.
> >
> > Is that a "pun," between the pythagorean comma and 1/1?
> >
> > -Mike
> >
> >
> > On Fri, Feb 19, 2010 at 2:33 AM, martinsj013 <martinsj@...> wrote:
> >
> > >
> > >
> > > --- In tuning@yahoogroups.com <tuning%40yahoogroups.com>, Mike Battaglia
> > > <battaglia01@> wrote:
> > > > > two 5/4s and a 9/8, however ordered, make a "pun" with 7/4.
> > > >
> > > > I don't get this "pun" thing. I thought I understood it a while ago,
> > > > but I don't. A pun is what, just a two JI intervals that tend to be
> > > > perceived as equivalent? So 5/4 and 50001/40000 make a pun?
> > >
> > > I think that's right, except that both the ratios have to have a "meaning"
> > > to make a pun - so 5/4 and 81/64 make a pun (because 81/64 "means" four 5ths
> > > reduced). Not sure if 50001/40000 "means" anything - can't be bothered to
> > > factorise it!
> > >
> > > Steve.
> > >
> > >
> > >
> >
>
>

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/19/2010 1:57:41 AM

Sorry I was mixing up your example with martinj's, now I'll read your example again and see what you mean. Let's see... no, your example is trying to make a pun as wide as the Pythagorean comma. That's as bogus and crude as the M3/Pyth ditone "pun".

Going 5/4, 5/4, 9/8, gives you the augmented sixth of 225/128 Which is only 225/224, less than 8 cents, off of 7/4, and is a few smooth steps leading to another smooth step. Surely it is clear why I'd consider this quite a logical homophonic vector found within the (lower, even!) harmonic series- a "natural pun"?

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...> wrote:
>
> > I would not call martinj's example a pun from the harmonic series because the kind of "pun" I'm thinking of would happen, in your example, at the 53rd Pythagorean fifth. To me, a pun is a kind of logical homophonic vector "occuring in nature" so to speak. Human modalities implementing these are going to tend to be more immediately tangible as "sensible" and "harmonious", I think, for the simple reason that they mimic suggested modalities within the very sensible and, well, harmonious, harmonic series.
>
> Why would my pun happen at the 53rd fifth? I set it up so that 6 whole
> steps tempers right into the octave. My question was mainly if the
> word "pun" refers to the perceptual experience of harmonically "going
> somewhere" and then arriving somewhere else due to tempering... as in
> whoaa, this guy's going way out... wait hold on.. now we're back at
> the I chord again. Hmmmm, this is awkward.
>
> That's the most scientific way I can think to put it at least.
>
> > Forcing a heavy-handed pun of 81/64 and 5/4 is the grand failure of
> > Western music, in my opinion, not only because the sheer size of the interval "tempered out", but also because there is no connection between the naked characters (rather than rough scalar proximities) of the intervals punned, and of those creating the pun: four times "smooth" to get to "jangly" just doesn't make a good pun with a single step to "super smooth". Whereas smoothest third, smoothest third, smoothest second (aug 6) to get to a pun with the smoothest seventh works in both consistency of character and in sheer proximity (size of comma- more than 3 times smaller than the syntonic).
> >
> > A search of the archives here at the tuning list turns up only a passing mention, and no disscusion at all, of what is perhaps the most obvious and simple "pun" in the low harmonics, which strikes me as very strange and hard to believe, perhaps the search function is not good. Herman Miller certainly knows all about it, as it is the "key" to one of his temperaments- the most immediately useful, by far and away, of any of the "regular temperaments" found at this list. This pun is both concretely more simple and more radical than "tempering out the syntonic comma", yet is also dealing with a comma much smaller: a "no brainer" so to speak. Will someone guess or exlain which one? :-)
>
> I... wish I knew what a pun was.
>
> I'm gonna guess he tempers out the schisma?

> > > guy, let's say I arpeggiate a C minor triad. Then I go up a whole tone and

ðŸ”—Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...>

2/19/2010 2:04:22 AM

So a pun just refers to any two justly tuned intervals which are so close
together as to be audibly indistinguishable by the ear then?

For that matter, how about the schisma? Schismatic tunings are the best for
5-limit I've ever seen... or would you say that the pun there isn't all that
great since it takes like 8 fourths to finally get to the third?

It's also funny that you're talking about tempering 225/224 (marvel,
right?), because I believe that Petr was just talking in his Word document
about how he thinks we need to get away from that, since it's a hangover
from the old "meantone" way of thinking. Or at least I think that's what he
was saying.

Hey, I'm starting to get the hang of this stuff now!

-Mike

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/19/2010 2:10:24 AM

Oh, Mike- your pun really could take place at the 53 Pythogorean fifth, for you would not have the Pythagorean comma, but <4 cents discrepancy between your cycle of fifths and the octave. 6 9/8s just isn't going to work in this way.

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "cameron" <misterbobro@...> wrote:
>
> Sorry I was mixing up your example with martinj's, now I'll read your example again and see what you mean. Let's see... no, your example is trying to make a pun as wide as the Pythagorean comma. That's as bogus and crude as the M3/Pyth ditone "pun".
>

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/19/2010 2:52:29 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...> wrote:
>
> So a pun just refers to any two justly tuned intervals which are so >close
> together as to be audibly indistinguishable by the ear then?
>

No, I don't mean audibly indistinguishable, for they could be distinguishable yet be consistent in character (two "soft" or two "hard" for example).

> For that matter, how about the schisma? Schismatic tunings are the >best for
> 5-limit I've ever seen... or would you say that the pun there isn't >all that
> great since it takes like 8 fourths to finally get to the third?

Doesn't get to the third but a diminished fourth. :-) Just ribbing, I know you know that. I'd call that quite a good pun, why wouldn't I?
>
> It's also funny that you're talking about tempering 225/224 (marvel,
> right?), because I believe that Petr was just talking in his Word >document
> about how he thinks we need to get away from that, since it's a >hangover
> from the old "meantone" way of thinking. Or at least I think that's >what he
> was saying.

Have to take some time to read Petr's paper thoroughly. But I'm not talking about meantone, I'm talking about the harmonic series. It's a simple fact that in the harmonic series if you move by the proportion of the fifth partial to the fourth, then once again the same, then by the proportion of the ninth partial to the eigth, you wind up awfully close to the octave reduction of the seventh partial.

I don't claim that this is the "explanation" for the "seventh" in Western music, I'd speculate rather that the audible presence of the seventh partial more likely "justified" such modulations especially in later Romantic/Chromatic music, for example, rather than vice versa.

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/19/2010 3:35:59 AM

Oh, and I forgot to mention- I think it is wise not to get tunneled into the concept of "temperament" and "commas" too much. For example, while it is true that it takes eight fourths to pun with 5/4, it is also true that if you simply bop up a fifth and down a fourth a bunch of times, you don't just get a pun with 5/4, you wind up with more than a dozen extremely close puns with Just thirds or sixths (M + m) lurking in your tuning. There is no temperament going on at all.

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...> wrote:

> For that matter, how about the schisma? Schismatic tunings are the >best for
> 5-limit I've ever seen... or would you say that the pun there isn't >all that
> great since it takes like 8 fourths to finally get to the third?

ðŸ”—Petr Parízek <p.parizek@...>

2/19/2010 11:20:53 AM

Mike wrote:

> It's also funny that you're talking about tempering 225/224 (marvel, right?),
> because I believe that Petr was just talking in his Word document about how he thinks
> we need to get away from that, since it's a hangover from the old "meantone"
> way of thinking. Or at least I think that's what he was saying.

Actually, marvel is okay for me as long as it’s „only“ marvel. What is not okay for me, however, is to say that 7/4 has always the meaning of an augmented sixth. It is an augmented sixth only in meantone and nowhere else (that’s what I was missing in the past).

Another suggestion in that document was that I think the best way to discover the actual possibilities of the 7-limit intervals is to try out some 3D temperaments, which some people disagree.

Petr

ðŸ”—Marcel de Velde <m.develde@...>

2/19/2010 11:40:36 AM

Hi Mike,

I'm pretty sure my qualitative experience of this chord involves an
> ambiguous
> flip flop between them (until "musical context" kicks in, that is, at
> which point we move on to something else).
>

Aah ok. Hmm yes I think I can agree with that.
Musical context makes a lot clear. Without it many chords indeed have
ambiguouty (I just know I must have spelled that wrong haha, but can't check
am on wireless with only email access no rest of internet)

>
> At the very least I can say that it DOES involve an ambiguous flip
> flop between my perception of the C-C as 4/1 on the outside and the
> perception of the whole thing as bunch of stacked and very crunchy
> sounding minor thirds, of which the C on top is a novel chord
> extension. No wait, no it's not, it's just another C. But it is... but
> it should be... but it's not. It confuses my ear in that way.
>
> My hypothesis is that all of this corresponds to a flip flop
> internally between JI "states,"
>

Ok yes agreed on flip flop JI states then. (just not agreed on 81/20 ever
occuring in music as we know it)
But I do not think this ambiguity is something that can be exploited
musically. And as far as the ear is concerned, this ambiguity is still there
to a large degree even when tuning something to JI, as the ear often isn't
precise enough to hear it anyhow.
In other words, that 12tet has an advantage here, or that it makes possible
things in 12tet that are not possible in JI is not so in my opinion.
All that is possible in 12tet is possible in JI, despite any ambiguouty.

Marcel

ðŸ”—Carl Lumma <carl@...>

2/19/2010 12:39:03 PM

Mike Battaglia wrote:

> So a pun just refers to any two justly tuned intervals which are
> so close together as to be audibly indistinguishable by the ear
> then?

No. It's only a pun if they ARE distinguishable (and the more
distinguishable, the more punny). That is, you said justly tuned.
They're obviously indistinguishable in the temperament.

> For that matter, how about the schisma? Schismatic tunings are
> the best for 5-limit I've ever seen... or would you say that the
> pun there isn't all that great since it takes like 8 fourths to
> finally get to the third?

This ties in to what you and Kalle were discussing. Kalle
doesn't think we hear puns at all ('no adaptive reason for us
to be able to hear the JI lattice structure' etc.)

It's hard to know whether Kalle's right or not. We're so
used to hearing the syntonic pun that articulating the 81/80
sounds perspicacious, rather than the other way around.

Tempered progressions involving commas that ARE distinguished
in 12-ET certainly sound punny to me (as long as the required
prog. is short enough), but how do I know they only sound this
way because they defy the system I learned, rather than some
JI ideal?

One way to test this might be to listen to non-diatonic (and
therefore less commonly-heard) puns in 12. For instance,
C - E - G# - C. Sound punny?

Or, if you've ever heard the title track from the King Crimson
album _Red_, it's based on a diminished (aka octatonic)
progression. Sound punny?

You can see this post too:
/tuning/topicId_81878.html#81948

Links are given to a diminished pun in 12, and to the famous
porcupine pun (both tempered in 22 and untempered in 12).

There's also this post by Petr:
/tuning/topicId_81878.html#81919

which is maybe the best example of a pun I've ever heard.
Unfortunately, the file's no longer up. Petr, can you please
find a place to permanently host your files (pretty please?)

We can see I replied at the time, that it proves puns are
real. But real relative to JI, or relative to 12? The
evidence seems to support the latter conclusion.

> It's also funny that you're talking about tempering 225/224
> (marvel, right?), because I believe that Petr was just talking
> in his Word document about how he thinks we need to get away
> from that, since it's a hangover from the old "meantone" way
> of thinking. Or at least I think that's what he was saying.

Yep, marvel. I don't remember him saying this though.

-Carl

I guess that the progression starts to sound less punny once the new
template becomes familiar.

ðŸ”—caleb morgan <calebmrgn@...>

2/19/2010 1:57:35 PM

Thanks, I'll check it out.

Thanks for kind comments, everybody.

I just decided that the D-50 sucked as a controller, and hooked up a
full-sized Midi controller--a Fatar SL-880.

This is MUCH, much better for large scales. The D-50 had other
strange problems, as well.

But I can't seem to regulate the Midi velocity output very well out of
the SL-880. Despite following the instruction manual,

all the velocities are coming into PianoTeq at 70 or higher. Nothing
I do in 'edit' mode on the SL-880 seems to make any difference.

However, PianoTeq is great, because it lets you just draw in a graph
of velocity response.

I'll share one more 'jam' in the nearish future, when I'm playing
better.

This one was all about saying hello after a long, long time.

Thanks again.

Scala format is awesome. Now I can check out all these scales people
are talking about!

Caleb

ðŸ”—Carl Lumma <carl@...>

2/19/2010 2:54:28 PM

> --- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Carl Lumma" <carl@> wrote:
> >
> > This ties in to what you and Kalle were discussing. Kalle
> > doesn't think we hear puns at all ('no adaptive reason for us
> > to be able to hear the JI lattice structure' etc.)
>
> Not exactly, I think that we hear puns but only relative to our
> template of hearing. This just isn't JI for most of us.
>
> I guess that the progression starts to sound less punny once
> the new template becomes familiar.

Ok so, you agree with the "latter conclusion".

One wonders what would happen if musicians started broadly
using many different temperaments. Would all puns go away,
leaving us with a much more sensitive perception, where we
could identify different temperaments by ear?

I can't help feeling that the porcupine progression sounds
more punny in 15 and 22 than in 12. Herman, do you have a
JI version of it?

-Carl

ðŸ”—Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...>

2/19/2010 3:45:26 PM

> No. It's only a pun if they ARE distinguishable (and the more
> distinguishable, the more punny). That is, you said justly tuned.
> They're obviously indistinguishable in the temperament.

> It's hard to know whether Kalle's right or not. We're so
> used to hearing the syntonic pun that articulating the 81/80
> sounds perspicacious, rather than the other way around.

I'm confused here - given the definition you gave above, it would be that
we're not used to hearing the syntonic pun, because 5/4 and 81/64 are
indistinguishable in 12-tet?

Or are you saying that we can "pick up" on the underlying pun that WOULD
exist if it were set back into JI?

> Tempered progressions involving commas that ARE distinguished
> in 12-ET certainly sound punny to me (as long as the required
> prog. is short enough), but how do I know they only sound this
> way because they defy the system I learned, rather than some
> JI ideal?
>
> One way to test this might be to listen to non-diatonic (and
> therefore less commonly-heard) puns in 12. For instance,
> C - E - G# - C. Sound punny?
>
> Or, if you've ever heard the title track from the King Crimson
> album _Red_, it's based on a diminished (aka octatonic)
> progression. Sound punny?

Red is too busy sounding awesome for me to hear it as punny. Which isn't
trivial, there's a point to this, an untestable hypothesis that I have: that
song manages to temper out 640/625 but not make it sound like you're
awkwardly back at the root. Although now that I'm listening to it again, it
sort of does, but not always.

Danny Elfman's favorite trick - major chords ascending in tritones - is
punbelieva -- well you get it.

Probably the best example I have ever heard of is John Coltrane's tune
"Giant Steps." This piece makes use of the fact that 12-tet tempers out the
diesis. Although you're probably familiar with the chords, just for
everyone's sake, they are:

Bmaj D7 | Gmaj Bb7 | Ebmaj | Am7 D7
Gmaj Bb7 | Ebmaj F#7| Bmaj | Fm7 Bb7

And then it goes on to the rest of the song. In case any of you can't
immediately see the pattern, I'm going to shift the bottom line over so it
syncs up:

Bmaj D7 | Gmaj Bb7 | Ebmaj | Am7 D7
Gmaj Bb7 | Ebmaj F#7| Bmaj | Fm7 Bb7

OK, so you see the pattern. If we were to do this in JI, Bmaj would be the I
chord, and then it modulates down to 8/5 (one step "down" the 5-limit axis).
Then it modulates to the key of 32/25 (two steps along down 5-limit axis).
Then it temporarily modulates back one step to 8/5, goes down to 32/25
again, and finally arrives at 128/125. That's 3 steps along the 5-limit
axis. Chew on that.

Except in 12-equal, there is no 128/125, so you're just back at the root.
Until I took the time to learn to play and improvise over this song I had NO
IDEA we were back at the root there, because it sure didn't sound like it.
People would say "oh yeah Giant Steps is easy because it's just like major
thirds and stuff brah" and I didn't know what they were saying at all. And
this is coming from a guy with AP0 or whatever it's called.

So yes, I think that the perception of comma pumps or puns exist even in
tempered systems - to an extent. And furthermore, because at first I had no
idea that the tempered 1/1 relationship between those two chords even
existed at all - I only heard a large sequence of chords moving in awesome
intervals happening, with that final Bmaj sounding insanely colorful and
awesome. Then I started hearing the 1/1 relationship (thanks to music theory
teachers), and the multistable perception began. And now I no longer feel
"compelled" to hear it as 1/1 anymore, and I can hear it the way I used to,
which is awesome.

This also ties into what you were saying - that they only sound punny if
they're short enough. Well, yes, because if they're too long, you might not
remember what the original chord was that you're punning back around to.
AKA, an endless Cmaj-Am-Dm-G7 progression might not sound punny if played
slow enough, but if you play it really fast - it starts to sound a little
hokey.

-Mike

ðŸ”—Carl Lumma <carl@...>

2/19/2010 7:21:44 PM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...> wrote:
>
> > No. It's only a pun if they ARE distinguishable (and the more
> > distinguishable, the more punny). That is, you said justly
> > tuned. They're obviously indistinguishable in the temperament.
> //
> > It's hard to know whether Kalle's right or not. We're so
> > used to hearing the syntonic pun that articulating the 81/80
> > sounds perspicacious, rather than the other way around.
>
> I'm confused here - given the definition you gave above, it
> would be that we're not used to hearing the syntonic pun,
> because 5/4 and 81/64 are indistinguishable in 12-tet?

A pun is a sujection

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Surjection.svg

where, in the case of temperament theory, the thing on the
left is JI. The farther apart 3 & 4 are, the 'greater' the pun.
In temperament theory, 3 & 4 would be far apart in cents.
In comedy, 3 & 4 would be far apart in sense. Nyark.

> Or are you saying that we can "pick up" on the underlying pun
> that WOULD exist if it were set back into JI?

Uh, I think so.

> Danny Elfman's favorite trick - major chords ascending in
> tritones - is punbelieva -- well you get it.

Any examples come to mind?

> Probably the best example I have ever heard of is John
> Coltrane's tune "Giant Steps."

Yep, it's been discussed here in the past.

> Bmaj D7 | Gmaj Bb7 | Ebmaj | Am7 D7
> Gmaj Bb7 | Ebmaj F#7| Bmaj | Fm7 Bb7
>
> OK, so you see the pattern. If we were to do this in JI, Bmaj
> would be the I chord, and then it modulates down to 8/5 (one
> step "down" the 5-limit axis). Then it modulates to the key
> of 32/25 (two steps along down 5-limit axis). Then it
> temporarily modulates back one step to 8/5, goes down to 32/2
> again, and finally arrives at 128/125. That's 3 steps along the
> 5-limit axis. Chew on that.

It's augmented temperament.

> So yes, I think that the perception of comma pumps or puns exist
> even in tempered systems - to an extent.

They *only* exist in tempered systems.

> This also ties into what you were saying - that they only sound
> punny if they're short enough. Well, yes, because if they're too
> long, you might not remember what the original chord was that
> you're punning back around to.

Right.

-Carl

ðŸ”—Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...>

2/19/2010 7:50:42 PM

> > I'm confused here - given the definition you gave above, it
> > would be that we're not used to hearing the syntonic pun,
> > because 5/4 and 81/64 are indistinguishable in 12-tet?
>
> A pun is a sujection
>
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Surjection.svg
>
> where, in the case of temperament theory, the thing on the
> left is JI. The farther apart 3 & 4 are, the 'greater' the pun.
> In temperament theory, 3 & 4 would be far apart in cents.
> In comedy, 3 & 4 would be far apart in sense. Nyark.

H0h0. OK, then I'll rephrase my question this way: would the thing on
the right be a temperament, in which 3 & 4 are represented by the same
pitch? Or is it a conceptual thing - like that even in JI, where 5/4
and 81/64 are represented by two different pitches, they still sound
very similar.

So, is it that in temperaments in which 81/80 is tempered out, 5/4 and
81/64 make a "pun?" Or that even in JI, they would still be a pun,
just because the ear tends to hear 81/64 as a mistuned 5/4?

Here, let's put it this way: the chord progression ||: Cmaj | Am | Dm
| G7 :|| is a comma pump when tuned in JI. In 12-tet, however, you end
up back at the root each time. So is it that that chord progression is
a "pun" in JI, or in 12-tet?

That would clear it up.

> > So yes, I think that the perception of comma pumps or puns exist
> > even in tempered systems - to an extent.
>
> They *only* exist in tempered systems.

Now I'm really confused -- I thought the purpose of temperament was to
make it so that comma pumps don't exist. One of the purposes, anyway.

Also as for Danny Elfman's famous thing, it's like (picture in 6/8)

| C E G | F# A# C# | C' E' G' | F#' A#' C#' |

etc, where all of those are just notes, not chords, and they keep
going up in pitch forever. Cmaj, F#maj, Cmaj, F#maj, going up in a
tritone each time. You know, it's like the "Wow, we've broken into
Willy Wonka's chocolate factory!!" chord progression.

-Mike

ðŸ”—Carl Lumma <carl@...>

2/19/2010 8:26:09 PM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...> wrote:

> H0h0. OK, then I'll rephrase my question this way: would the
> thing on the right be a temperament, in which 3 & 4 are
> represented by the same pitch?

Yes!

> So, is it that in temperaments in which 81/80 is tempered out,
> 5/4 and 81/64 make a "pun?"

Yes.

> Or that even in JI, they would still be a pun,
> just because the ear tends to hear 81/64 as a mistuned 5/4?

No!

> Here, let's put it this way: the chord progression
> ||: Cmaj | Am | Dm | G7 :|| is a comma pump when tuned in JI.
> In 12-tet, however, you end up back at the root each time. So
> is it that that chord progression is a "pun" in JI, or
> in 12-tet?

12-ET!

> Also as for Danny Elfman's famous thing, it's like (picture in 6/8)
>
> | C E G | F# A# C# | C' E' G' | F#' A#' C#' |
>
> etc, where all of those are just notes, not chords, and they
> keep going up in pitch forever. Cmaj, F#maj, Cmaj, F#maj, going
> up in a tritone each time. You know, it's like the "Wow, we've
> broken into Willy Wonka's chocolate factory!!" chord progression.

I liked the soundtrack for that movie - lot of weird vocal
samples from Elfman himself, IIRC. Don't remember this
progression, but that's not saying anything.

-Carl

ðŸ”—Petr Parízek <p.parizek@...>

> more punny in 15 and 22 than in 12.

Speaking of porcupine, one of the shortest possible triadic pumps can be found towards the end of this piece which many of you have probably heard more than twice:
www.box.net/shared/c2rcg04x8x

Petr

ðŸ”—martinsj013 <martinsj@...>

2/20/2010 5:04:16 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...> wrote:

Mike>>> So yes, I think that the perception of comma pumps or puns exist even in tempered systems - to an extent.
Carl>> They *only* exist in tempered systems.
Mike> Now I'm really confused -- I thought the purpose of temperament was to make it so that comma pumps don't exist. One of the purposes, anyway.

I think (based on Carl's answers) that we can only perceive a pun where a comma is tempered out, and can only perceive a comma pump where a comma is not tempered out. So Carl's "they" (above) refers to puns, not comma pumps.

Steve.

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/20/2010 5:08:16 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Carl Lumma" <carl@...> wrote:

>
> > So yes, I think that the perception of comma pumps or puns exist
> > even in tempered systems - to an extent.
>
> They *only* exist in tempered systems.

Conflating tempered-out comma pumps with intervallic "puns" is a lousy idea. Puns certainly do exist in untempered systems. I have uploaded two brief files illustrating a couple of "natural puns".

ðŸ”—Kalle <kalleaho@...>

2/20/2010 5:45:50 AM

> lousy idea. Puns certainly do exist in untempered systems. I have

Hi Cameron,

if you are using 128:225 as a ~4:7 aren't you thereby using marvel
temperament?

Kalle Aho

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/20/2010 8:11:48 AM

225/128 would be an untempered interval, so I think the proper description would be that marvel temperament makes use of this "organic pun", tempering out the small comma involved. Should work splendidly.

The 7:4's in the examples I posted are pure 7:4's.

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Kalle" <kalleaho@...> wrote:
> Hi Cameron,
>
> if you are using 128:225 as a ~4:7 aren't you thereby using marvel
> temperament?
>
> Kalle Aho
>

ðŸ”—Petr Parízek <p.parizek@...>

2/20/2010 11:33:13 AM

Steve wrote:

> I think (based on Carl's answers) that we can only perceive a pun where a comma is
> tempered out, and can only perceive a comma pump where a comma is not tempered out.

My goodness, does that mean that if I play "C major, A minor, D minor, G major, C major" in meantone, then that's not a comma pump?

Petr

ðŸ”—Carl Lumma <carl@...>

2/20/2010 11:44:42 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Petr Parízek <p.parizek@...> wrote:
>
> Steve wrote:
>
> > I think (based on Carl's answers) that we can only perceive a
> > pun where a comma is tempered out, and can only perceive a comma
> > pump where a comma is not tempered out.
>
> My goodness, does that mean that if I play "C major, A minor,
> D minor, G major, C major" in meantone, then that's not a
> comma pump?
>
> Petr

We're splitting hairs here, but I'd say it's not a comma pump
because it's not pumping anything. It's a pun.

comma pump + temperament = pun

But in normal discourse, you could still call it a comma pump
and people would probably understand you.

-Carl

ðŸ”—Carl Lumma <carl@...>

2/20/2010 11:43:09 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "cameron" <misterbobro@...> wrote:
>
> 225/128 would be an untempered interval, so I think the proper
> description would be that marvel temperament makes use of this
> "organic pun", tempering out the small comma involved. Should
> work splendidly.
>
> The 7:4's in the examples I posted are pure 7:4's.

Let's not muddy the water. The definition of "pun" is pretty
well settled. If you call 8 cents imperceptible, then JI has
become a temperament. There are of course an infinite number
of pairs of lattice points that are imperceptibly close
together, where one does not need to change the size of any
intervals to achieve temperament. That doesn't change the
fact that temperament (in the abstract sense we use on
tuning-math) has been achieved.

-Carl

ðŸ”—Petr Parízek <p.parizek@...>

2/20/2010 12:23:55 PM

Carl wrote:

> We're splitting hairs here, but I'd say it's not a comma pump
> because it's not pumping anything. It's a pun.
>
> comma pump + temperament = pun

Aha, then I would have to completely rewrite the article which I'm currently working on.

> But in normal discourse, you could still call it a comma pump
> and people would probably understand you.

Well, I've been using the term for the progressions where the last chord is the desired "comma" lower than the first chord in pure JI and where the first and last chord sound the same in the tuning tempering that comma out. So, for example, the progression I mentioned would then be simply "one possible comma pump for meantone", no matter if I played it in JI or meantone. If it's a pun in meantone and a pump in JI, then I'm missing a general term for this.

So now we have three terms in action: Comma shifts, commatic drifts, comma pumps. Once I understand which one is which, then I can, for example, try to find appropriate Czech translations for them.

Petr

ðŸ”—Carl Lumma <carl@...>

2/20/2010 1:13:57 PM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Petr Parízek <p.parizek@...> wrote:

> > But in normal discourse, you could still call it a comma pump
> > and people would probably understand you.
>
> Well, I've been using the term for the progressions where the
> last chord is the desired "comma" lower than the first chord in
> pure JI and where the first and last chord sound the same in the
> tuning tempering that comma out. So, for example, the
> progression I mentioned would then be simply "one possible
> comma pump for meantone", no matter if I played it in JI or
> meantone. If it's a pun in meantone and a pump in JI, then I'm
> missing a general term for this.

I don't think the terminology needs to be so exact. If it's
a comma pump in JI I think we can refer to it also in meantone,
as long as we mention that the comma is now gone. It's just
when Mike & I were trying to get sync'd up, that it can help to
dig into things.

> So now we have three terms in action: Comma shifts, commatic
> drifts, comma pumps. Once I understand which one is which,
> then I can, for example, try to find appropriate Czech
> translations for them.

Comma pumps are progressions that require either comma shifts
or comma drift in strict JI. Drift is where the pitch is
allowed to rise (or fall) each time the pump repeats. Shift
is where instead, common tones between adjacent chords are
adjusted to keep the pitch level constant, introducing tiny
melodic motions. Naturally one can use some combination of
these methods to tune a progression in strict JI.

In adaptive JI, the shifts are allowed to be irrational
(example: 1/4 syntonic comma steps). It is essentially the
comma shift solution, but we are allowed to divide the shifts
into smaller (irrational) intervals and distribute them more
widely.

Make sense?

-Carl

ðŸ”—Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...>

2/20/2010 2:33:24 PM

If in JI you play 225/128 instead of 7/4, it could be a "pun" because
you can view it like the ear itself tempers out the comma, since
225/224 is only like 7 cents wide, which could be argued makes the two
just "barely" distinguishable. The ear has its own temperament.

-Mike

On Sat, Feb 20, 2010 at 11:11 AM, cameron <misterbobro@...> wrote:
>
>
>
> 225/128 would be an untempered interval, so I think the proper description would be that marvel temperament makes use of this "organic pun", tempering out the small comma involved. Should work splendidly.
>
> The 7:4's in the examples I posted are pure 7:4's.
>
> --- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Kalle" <kalleaho@...> wrote:
> > Hi Cameron,
> >
> > if you are using 128:225 as a ~4:7 aren't you thereby using marvel
> > temperament?
> >
> > Kalle Aho
> >
>
>

ðŸ”—Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...>

2/20/2010 3:15:36 PM

Also, as an interesting way of maybe hearing exactly where the
inharmonicity lies in the "syntonic pun":

Play the sound of Cmaj Am Fmaj G, which does not involve a pun, a few
times to get it in your head. Then just subtly change the C in that
Fmaj chord to a D, which is an old "classical" trick that I don't hear
done much anymore. It also kind of trips you out at first in a way
that you might not notice unless you're really paying attention to,
and I think that's the sound of the syntonic "pun."

In JI, the F-A-D chord might be tuned 4/3 5/3 9/8, meaning the A-D
would be a comma sharp. Which, musically and in context, actually
sounds pretty good. But when you do this in a meantone tuning, you
hear the 10:12:15-ness of the whole thing come out, which conflicts
with the other interpretation, hey hey hey. At least that's how I hear
it. It helps to "imagine" the JI lattice in your head - from
Cmaj-Am->Fmaj works fine. But then from Cmaj-Am->F6 doesn't work
anymore, especially leading into the G.

Of course, the possibility always exists that the sheer act of
imagining the JI lattice causes some kind of placebo effect, but I
think if you do it enough and really focus on it, you will start to
hear a bit of what I can only describe as "inharmonicity" in what's
going on. Like a bit of "dirtiness" or "grunginess" to the
progression. Kind of like how a bell has an inharmonic timbre - you
start to detect a very, very slight vibe of that in the "background"
as the whole progression goes on. At least I do, if I listen to it
hard enough.

This effect is really much more prominent if you do it in a tuning
like 31-et or 1/4 comma meantone - it isn't as noticeable in 12-tet.
In essence it's responsible for the meantone "sound."

-Mike

2/20/2010 9:56:19 PM

Well, the 22-tet porcupine pun that you posted in response to Marcel's thing
doesn't sound quite right to me. Maybe if I heard an adaptive JI version or
something, it would make sense. Or maybe that's supposed to be the point of
a "pun." But it modulates into some ridiculous key, then into another
ridiculous key, then it sounds like it's going to end a half or a quarter
step up or so, but somehow we're back at the root. So I assume that's the
"pun" there. It's an unsettling kind of sound.

I don't even know what to say about the 3125/2916 pun, I feel like I'm a Tim
Burton film. It took me a second to figure out where the root even was,
because it just keeps jumping all over the place.

On a second listen I don't really hear the pun at all. It sounds like the
roots are moving down in tempered neutral thirds. Or maybe it's alternate
minor and major thirds. But that shouldn't lead to a pun - C -> A -> F -> D
-> Bb -> G -> back to C. I dunno how you guys are thinking of the root
movements though.

http://i232.photobucket.com/albums/ee200/chazee1/305828688.gif

-Mike

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/21/2010 1:10:25 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Carl Lumma" <carl@...> wrote:
>
> --- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "cameron" <misterbobro@> wrote:
> >
> > 225/128 would be an untempered interval, so I think the proper
> > description would be that marvel temperament makes use of this
> > "organic pun", tempering out the small comma involved. Should
> > work splendidly.
> >
> > The 7:4's in the examples I posted are pure 7:4's.
>
> Let's not muddy the water.

I am attempting to clear the waters, not muddy them.

>The definition of "pun" is pretty
> well settled.

Yes, it is, but it has nothing to do with what we're talking about:
"musical pun" in the "mainstream" refers to stuff like B,A,C,H, or
using a "false relation" in a piece about your unloved uncle, that
kind of thing.

>If you call 8 cents imperceptible, then JI has
> become a temperament.

I don't call 8 cents imperceptible: in fact, I specifically said
that a pun occurs at distinguishables. A series of consecutive diminishing epimoric intervals (climbing the harmonic series) starting with 8/7 up through the 14th partial doesn't "pun" with
the octave, nor do two 3/2s "pun" with 9/8.

>There are of course an infinite number
> of pairs of lattice points that are imperceptibly close
> together, where one does not need to change the size of any
> intervals to achieve temperament. That doesn't change the
> fact that temperament (in the abstract sense we use on
> tuning-math) has been achieved.

I specifically talked about lower partials and "quick trips",
and I specifically mention scalar names, with a reason: the
reference point of a near-coincidence of intervals is at least
as scalar as it is literal (near-coincidence of cycles per second).

The file PunDemo01 in the Files section here (in Bobro Tuning Examples) is a very concrete demonstration of this. It is also,
among other things, a demonstration of one of the very nice features of tunings made with the "secor", miracle temperaments, for they have include the exact same pun, in minutely tempered
form, as this low-limit "Just" example does.

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/21/2010 2:06:56 AM

The real problem is always the same: listening to what is "supposed to be" rather than "what is". Obviously a person has to get over hearing a 7/6 as a very flat 6/5, for example, before appreciating fluidity in "7-limit".

"Dang that girl is ugly- she doesn't look like Sharon Stone at all!"

That describes the basic problem very well I think.

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...> wrote:
>
> > Oh yes what I forgot to say against 7 or higher limit JI.
> >
> > With 5-limit one allready gets sooo much music and musical structure.
> > Which works 100% of the time.
> > Perfect 12 tone scale from tonic. Perfect modulation structures etc. Atleast in my opinion.
> > It can do everything.
>
> OK, but the question is - why? I would like to believe it's because
> nobody has figured out fluid 7-limit JI yet. Although, perhaps they
> have, and perhaps it's expressed in this pajara temperament.
>
> > Now 6-limit will give a 19-tone per octave scale tonality.
> > But it's not all that nice anymore, extremely chromatic, comma drifting progressions become possible etc, and some of base chords in it don't sound very nice to me and not musical.
> > Even counterpoint clearly says that outer fifths in chords should not move parallel. This is exactly what 6-limit harmonic permutation does in it's core.
> > 6-limit is not very musical to me, or atleast at the very limit of it.
>
> I wish you could come up with some musical examples to illustrate what
> you mean. I do think you're onto something with your theory, but
> sometimes it's hard to wrap my head around it.
>
> > After that comes 7-limit. I have not calculated the number of tones per octave for it's tonality scale but I suspect it's a lot. Perhaps 50 or so per octave.
> > It's a comma gallore, chords in inversions that make no sense, progressions that do nothing but shift and jump all over the place.
> > No man can recognise music in this.
> >
> > Then comes 8-limi, 9-limit 10-limit, 11-limit.. well. In my opinion this has nothing to do with musical structure anymore but is in the realm of harmonics of sound.
> >
> > So as far as I'm concerned music is 5-limit.
>
> But is there music to be recognized in it anyway? After a lifetime of
> training, I am becoming much better in fluidly communicating ideas in
> 12-tet. But why is 12-tet so special? So then I moved into meantone.
> But why is meantone so special? And why is 5-limit so special?
>
> There's no reason why, except that that's the status quo for the moment.
>
> -Mike

ðŸ”—Petr Parízek <p.parizek@...>

2/21/2010 2:19:52 AM

Mike wrote:

> What would be really interesting is if you did it in a tuning in which that comma was reversed, or found some other
> pun that you could set up like that.

You may try that yourself if you use, let's say, an octave of 1200 and a fifth of 676 cents -- or, maybe better, an octave of 1210 and a fifth of 681 cents. This gives you two possible versions of mavila where major and minor thirds sound like swapped and where C# is lower than C, not higher.

Petr

http://www.io.com/~hmiller/midi/porcupine-JI.mid

I started with the 12-ET version and ended up retuning 3 different JI versions (one for each repetition), pasted them together, and adjusted the notes at the seams.

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/22/2010 2:11:51 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Carl Lumma" <carl@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Cameron,
>
> > >The definition of "pun" is pretty well settled.
> >
> > Yes, it is, but it has nothing to do with what we're talking >about:
> > "musical pun" in the "mainstream" refers to stuff like B,A,C,H, or
> > using a "false relation" in a piece about your unloved uncle, that
> > kind of thing.
>
> I meant the microtonal theory definition.
>
> > > If you call 8 cents imperceptible, then JI has
> > > become a temperament.
> >
> > I don't call 8 cents imperceptible:
>
> Then it isn't a pun.

In a pun, you wouldn't use "red" and "red", you would use "red" and "read" (past tense of to read). In most dialects of the English language, these are actually not pronounced absolutely identically, nor are any "homophones" that I know of; in the first the vowel is slightly shorter. Same thing in the most famous German pun, Man ist, was man isst; the first vowel is shorter (even if some claim the two "i"'s are the same).

Anyway, this is not important- I could just continue to say "organic
place to put a homophonic vector" or something.
>
> > I specifically talked about lower partials and "quick trips",
> > and I specifically mention scalar names, with a reason: the
> > reference point of a near-coincidence of intervals is at least
> > as scalar as it is literal (near-coincidence of cycles
> > per second).
>
> Sorry, you lost me. Can you elucidate?

Hm, what I wrote there is extremely precise. In the file PunDemo01, the first part, before it drops an octave, is clearly sol-do-te-do-re-do-sol-do, with very wide te and re. Te and re are steps of pure 8/7s- they are certainly Just, but strongly wide of 5-limit. I imagine some might hear them as ta and ri (movable do here of course).
But sol is clearly sol, and I think you'd have to go pretty far afield anywhere on the planet to find a music where this or something essentially similar is not the case, as that which we call the "fifth" is arguably even more prevalent than the octave.

That ("sol") is the scalar reference point, and it is patently, easily, at least as real as a spectral reference point, otherwise we would not be able to recognize melodies performed "out of tune", much less recognize melodies when radically (spectrally speaking) altered, as we do with ease, at least in Western music at least, even in cases when thirds are swapped from major to minor. For example.

But there is no "fifth", as in 3/2, in that example at all. It is an illusion, pointed out in the second part of the example( where the tonic drops an octave). "Sol" here is literally a septimal tritone: three consecutive steps of pure 8/7. There are actually ONLY a bunch of steps of 8/7 in this example- the whole thing is pretty much a brute mimesis of audible spectral proportions, it could hardly sound anything but pretty, regardless of how "good" or "meaningful" or whatever.

Lower partials, 8/7. Quick trip, three of them.

Hopefully this elucidates my point. My personal opinion is that the aug6/m7 homophonic vector is not really the actual key to riding up the harmonic series from 5 to 7. And, I think example one illustrates this very well. In tuninglistese, I would say that first key comma is actually 1029/1024. The next comma is addressed in example 2. And I think that example

> Are you referring to 225/224? Miracle tempers it to zero,
> so comma pumps based on 225/224 do in fact become puns.

1029/1024 in the first example, and something else, requiring a
full article, in the second.
>
> I've renamed your folder to conform to the naming convention
> in the Files area
> /tuning/files/CameronBobro/
> Is this OK with you? Let me know if you want it changed
> back. At the very least though, we don't want spaces in it.

Right, I had forgotten about that, thanks for fixing it.

> On a slightly different note, I'd love to know a little more
> about the timbre you're using.

I made a "hey man, no cheating!" patch in Straightliner, specifically
for tuning demonstrations. There is no detuning, vibrato, or tremolo; it is dead straight pitchwise and quite bright, no detuned or missing partials. It's really just a mildly lumpy pretty-much-sawtooth low-passed enough not to rip your ear off, with attack time inversely patched to velocity (play harder, sharper attack) and other subtle velocity routings in order to make it suited for counterpoint, specifically fugues, which remain in my opinion THE test of tuning.

I'd be happy to send the patch and the custom waveforms I made for it to anyone who has Straightliner, or is wise enough to buy it (it supports .tun files, is cheap, simple, and sounds solid).

-Cameron

ðŸ”—Carl Lumma <carl@...>

2/22/2010 12:09:33 PM

Cameron wrote:

> > > > If you call 8 cents imperceptible, then JI has
> > > > become a temperament.
> > >
> > > I don't call 8 cents imperceptible:
> >
> > Then it isn't a pun.
>
> In a pun, you wouldn't use "red" and "red", you would use
> "red" and "read" (past tense of to read). In most dialects of
> the English language,

Sorry, but I'm telling you what the specialized definition
of "pun" is. If you don't like it, fine. You're free to
disagree. But not on the grounds that it isn't the same as
a "pun" in some other field.

> > > I specifically talked about lower partials and "quick trips",
> > > and I specifically mention scalar names, with a reason: the
> > > reference point of a near-coincidence of intervals is at least
> > > as scalar as it is literal (near-coincidence of cycles
> > > per second).
> >
> > Sorry, you lost me. Can you elucidate?
>
> Hm, what I wrote there is extremely precise. In the file
> PunDemo01, the first part, before it drops an octave, is clearly
> sol-do-te-do-re-do-sol-do, with very wide te and re. Te and re
> are steps of pure 8/7s- they are certainly Just, but strongly
> wide of 5-limit. I imagine some might hear them as ta and ri
> (movable do here of course).

ok

> But there is no "fifth", as in 3/2, in that example at all. It is
> an illusion, pointed out in the second part of the example (where
> the tonic drops an octave). "Sol" here is literally a septimal
> tritone: three consecutive steps of pure 8/7. There are actually
> ONLY a bunch of steps of 8/7 in this example- the whole thing is
> pretty much a brute mimesis of audible spectral proportions, it
> could hardly sound anything but pretty, regardless of how "good"
> or "meaningful" or whatever.

694 cents is an approximate 3:2. That has to do with
psychoacoustics, not the structure of chord progressions,
which are what xenharmonic puns are about.

> > On a slightly different note, I'd love to know a little more
> > about the timbre you're using.
>
> I made a "hey man, no cheating!" patch in Straightliner,
> specifically for tuning demonstrations. There is no detuning,
> vibrato, or tremolo; it is dead straight pitchwise and quite
> bright, no detuned or missing partials. It's really just a
> mildly lumpy pretty-much-sawtooth low-passed enough not to rip
> your ear off, with attack time inversely patched to velocity
> (play harder, sharper attack) and other subtle velocity
> routings in order to make it suited for counterpoint,
> specifically fugues, which remain in my opinion THE test
> of tuning.

Well it's similar (or identical) to a timbre you used in the
past, which I think I praised then. Simple but effective.
A "synth trombone" perhaps.

> I'd be happy to send the patch and the custom waveforms I made
> for it to anyone who has Straightliner, or is wise enough to
> buy it (it supports .tun files, is cheap, simple, and sounds
> solid).

Thanks! I thought you used Csound. Never heard of Straightliner
before.
http://www.rs-met.com/

ðŸ”—Marcel de Velde <m.develde@...>

2/22/2010 12:54:27 PM

Mike,

Have been doing some more thinking about the C E G B D F# A C# chord.
This has led me to a different tuning than the one I gave before.
Instead of 1/1 5/4 3/2 15/8 9/4 45/16 27/8 135/32
I would tune it 6/5 3/2 9/5 9/4 8/3 10/3 4/1 5/1 (root of the chord = 1/1)
Seen from 1/1:
1/1 5/4 3/2 15/8 20/9 25/9 20/3 25/6 (root of the chord = 5/3)

Still a very dissonant chord (although a bit less dissonant) but musically
very usefull.

I'm getting back more and more to 6-limit harmonic permutation of a single
root for chords.
1/1 is the root, 1/1 9/8 6/5 5/4 4/3 3/2 8/5 5/3 9/5 15/8 2/1 is the scale
in one octave that results from all the permutations of the harmonic series
up till the 6th harmonic, centering on 1/1.

Marcel

And for the other one:
>
> C E G B D F# A C#
> You tune it like this::
> 1/1 5/4 3/2 15/8 9/4 45/16 27/8 135/32
> As you can see you also tune a 1/1 5/4 27/16 minor triad (1/1 32/27 40/27
> in inversion)
> And you also tune a 1/1 5/4 40/27 major triad with 5/4 27/8 135/128.
> I think your tuning is correct here.
> And that this is indeed an example of 1/1 5/4 40/27 major triad.
> The chord sounds very very dissonant to me no matter the tuning.
>

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/23/2010 2:41:58 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Carl Lumma" <carl@...> wrote:
>
> Cameron wrote:
>
> > > > > If you call 8 cents imperceptible, then JI has
> > > > > become a temperament.
> > > >
> > > > I don't call 8 cents imperceptible:
> > >
> > > Then it isn't a pun.
> >
> > In a pun, you wouldn't use "red" and "red", you would use
> > "red" and "read" (past tense of to read). In most dialects of
> > the English language,
>
> Sorry, but I'm telling you what the specialized definition
> of "pun" is. If you don't like it, fine. You're free to
> disagree. But not on the grounds that it isn't the same as
> a "pun" in some other field.

You're telling me what the definition of "pun" is at the tuning
list. And I certainly can, should, and will continue to, prefer
usages which better link to broadly accepted meanings. That is,
if it makes more sense and makes for better communication, I'm going to use it.

> 694 cents is an approximate 3:2. That has to do with
> psychoacoustics, not the structure of chord progressions,
> which are what xenharmonic puns are about.

This is what you say xenharmonic puns are about, but this
definition has a gaping hole, which damages potential ways of
linking microtonal theory to practice.

Pundemo03.wav demonstrates that the "comma shift" sensation
does not require a chord progression, nor does it even require
two literal different manifestions of the nominally same interval.

Pundemo03 (in Files/CameronBobro at this site) is very like Pundemo01, but voiced a little differently, via octave
displacement, and the last note is dropped off, leaving "sol"
hanging (a "half cadence"). The small (~8 cents) comma in PunDemo01 is much more apparent in PunDemo3. Whether it sounds slightly flat,
a little "blue", or like a "comma shift", in this version it is
clear that the "sol" is not 3/2.

We do not need chords to hear this, and we do not need a pure 3/2 performed before or after to hear this: 3:1 is already there as a reference in the harmonic series. If the octave-dropped Do were
sustained through the second phrase, this would be glaringly
obvious, but I think it is important to hear how these things
happen even without vertical harmony.

This cannot really be "tempered out" in a tuning. The spectra of the instruments can be tempered, a la Sethares, or gapped (taking out
every harmonic which is a multiple of 3 would do the trick here),
or reduced to a tonic sine, or buried in noise, but with more or less rich harmonic spectra, there is no getting away from 1029/1024 when you have three steps of 8/7. 31-equal, quartertone meantone, 26 equal, Miracle temperament, all blur the 8/7 proportion and the 3/2 proportion, so this comma is really quite easily dealt with- it is
a pretty darn good pun in "nature" anyway. But it will never disappear
completely, thanks to the harmonic series, so the practical solution remains as it has been for centuries: compositional balance, such that overall there is more or less as much spectral blur above as below the harmonic in question, thereby making the harmonic a nice fuzzy region.

(In maqam kinds of music of course you probably wouldn't want to balance out all such junctures of intervals and spectra, for you'd lose forward momentum and weaken specific characteristic colors, so
new musics which are both maqam-like and polyphonic are sure to be
partly or wholly less symmetrical than for example an early 18th century permutation fugue).

> Thanks! I thought you used Csound. Never heard of Straightliner
> before.
> http://www.rs-met.com/

Yip- Csound, analog synthesizers and acoustic instruments. Straightliner is great for specific things, as I can microtune it
by simply dropping in a .tun file, and the polyphony is immense
compared to my Csound instruments, which are aimed at quality and
are CPU hogs.

-Cameron Bobro

ðŸ”—Carl Lumma <carl@...>

> does not require a chord progression, nor does it even require

> Pundemo03 (in Files/CameronBobro at this site) is very like
> Pundemo01, but voiced a little differently, via octave
> displacement, and the last note is dropped off, leaving "sol"
> hanging (a "half cadence"). The small (~8 cents) comma in

three examples use 10% of the available space (blame yahoo
for the chintzy allotment).
