ðŸ”—Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...>

2/23/2010 12:07:11 PM

Marcel,

> Have been doing some more thinking about the C E G B D F# A C# chord.
> This has led me to a different tuning than the one I gave before.
> Instead of 1/1 5/4 3/2 15/8 9/4 45/16 27/8 135/32
> I would tune it 6/5 3/2 9/5 9/4 8/3 10/3 4/1 5/1 (root of the chord = 1/1)
> Seen from 1/1:
> 1/1 5/4 3/2 15/8 20/9 25/9 20/3 25/6 (root of the chord = 5/3)
>
> Still a very dissonant chord (although a bit less dissonant) but musically very usefull.
>
> I'm getting back more and more to 6-limit harmonic permutation of a single root for chords.
> 1/1 is the root, 1/1 9/8 6/5 5/4 4/3 3/2 8/5 5/3 9/5 15/8 2/1 is the scale in one octave that results from all the permutations of the harmonic series up till the 6th harmonic, centering on 1/1.

This tuning actually sounds very good. I was surprised, because I
didn't expect it to. But it certainly does. It has more of a "relaxed"
feel to it than 1/1 5/4 3/2 15/8 9/4 45/16 27/8 135/32. Perhaps that's
just because 25/6 is more consonant than 135/32 - not sure.

It also sounds good if you tune it the way I suggested, but just
replace the top 135/32 with 25/6. It gives the upper dyad a bit of a
"bite" to it that I kind of like.

Actually, I just noticed that if you take my tuning and comma-shift
the top two notes down, it also sounds good. And the top 3 notes down,
and the top 4 notes, and so on. Where you put the wolf third changes
the "mood" of the chord slightly. After being used to the 20/9, going
back to 9/4 is kind of weird, but then after getting used to the 9/4,
going back to the 20/9 is kind of weird.

Also, leaving the 20/9 in but changing the 25/9 back to 45/16 is also
a nice sound.

Marcel, I think that your ideas deserve a bit more consideration, but
I wish you could explain them more simply, perhaps with pictures and
stuff :) as well as give an explanation for WHY some of your ideas
work, rather just that they arbitrarily do. (Harmonic permutations and
such)

-Mike

ðŸ”—Marcel de Velde <m.develde@...>

2/23/2010 3:28:28 PM

Hi Mike,

This tuning actually sounds very good. I was surprised, because I
> didn't expect it to. But it certainly does. It has more of a "relaxed"
> feel to it than 1/1 5/4 3/2 15/8 9/4 45/16 27/8 135/32. Perhaps that's
> just because 25/6 is more consonant than 135/32 - not sure.
>

Yes, if you look at the interval matrix of the chord, the new tuning is more
consonant overall.
No high ratios like 45 and 135.

>
> It also sounds good if you tune it the way I suggested, but just
> replace the top 135/32 with 25/6. It gives the upper dyad a bit of a
> "bite" to it that I kind of like.
>

I agree, but would perhaps tune the top note 21/5 instead of 25/6.
Yes I know, only a week ago or so I spoke out against 7-limit, but I'm maybe
comming back from this allready :)
(for the zillionth time lol)

>
> Actually, I just noticed that if you take my tuning and comma-shift
> the top two notes down, it also sounds good. And the top 3 notes down,
> and the top 4 notes, and so on. Where you put the wolf third changes
> the "mood" of the chord slightly. After being used to the 20/9, going
> back to 9/4 is kind of weird, but then after getting used to the 9/4,
> going back to the 20/9 is kind of weird.
>
>
> Also, leaving the 20/9 in but changing the 25/9 back to 45/16 is also
> a nice sound.
>

To stay within 1/1 9/8 6/5 5/4 4/3 3/2 8/5 5/3 9/5 15/8 2/1, I see 2 other
options:
(missed these the first time)

The one I allready gave was:
6/5 3/2 9/5 9/4 8/3 10/3 4/1 5/1

And these are possible too:
8/5 2/1 12/5 3/1 18/5 9/2 16/3 20/3

9/5 9/4 8/3 10/3 4/1 5/1 6/1 15/2

All have as their root 1/1

Now this shows there's an even bigger chord possible :)
6/5 3/2 9/5 9/4 8/3 10/3 4/1 5/1 6/1 15/2
LOL

> Marcel, I think that your ideas deserve a bit more consideration, but
> I wish you could explain them more simply, perhaps with pictures and
> stuff :) as well as give an explanation for WHY some of your ideas
> work, rather just that they arbitrarily do. (Harmonic permutations and
> such)
>
> -Mike
>

Yes sorry I know!
I'm planning a website where I'll explain everything.
But I've been too bussy working out the details for now to start on the
website yet.
There are so many ways to look at the theory, and I think the proof is in
the tuning so I have to test it first on actual music. (I've got a new
Beethoven comming up that's completely amazing! Everybody will like it
immediately I think :))

Just the basic thought that led to the theory was this:
Take the harmonic series, one step at a time.
So 1/1 2/1
1/1 2/1 3/1
1/1 2/1 3/1 4/1
1/1 2/1 3/1 4/1 5/1
1/1 2/1 3/1 4/1 5/1 6/1
We'll stop at 6 for now.

It goes from most simple to more complex every step.
The harmonic series is the most perfect way in it's own very specific way
that waves can sound together in harmony.
Now I got the idea that if the harmonic series is perfect, but it is not
music. Then what makes the harmonic series perfect, and what makes it not
music.

I thought of the following things that make it perfect in it's own way:
It's intervals are perfect 2/1 3/2 4/3 5/4 6/5 etc.
It's order is perfect. from large to smaller etc.

What makes the harmonic series not music?
I belief all musical harmonies to exist in the harmonic series somewhere,
and therefore all musical intervals to exist in harmonic series somehwere.
So the way the intervals are perfect is not the way the harmonic series
differs from music.
But the order of the harmonic series, that doesn't resemble music to me at
all.
Music is somewhat symetric, there are inversions and mirrors everywhere,
intervals follow eachother in all sorts of orders etc.
So what makes the harmonic series not music is it's order I thought.

Not that this is perfect thinking, it's just one of many thoughts trying to
make sense of things.

There was another thing that I wanted to do.
I want to be able to classify chords in many ways.
Classify chords from simple to more complex etc.

Now the harmonic series is easily classified.
1/1 2/1 is more simple than 1/1 2/1 3/1, or 2/1 3/1 etc

Now back to the order of the harmonic series not beeing music.
What happends if we change the order of the intervals in the harmonic
series?
Starting from simple to more complex.

1/1 2/1 you can't change the order.
1/1 2/1 3/1 you can. there is 2/1 interval followed by 3/2 interval. We can
change the order to 1/1 3/2 3/1 (3/2 + 2/1 instead of 2/1 + 3/2)
Now that doesn't sound terrible at all :)
It is still the most simple in a certain way, limited the harmonic series to
the 3rd harmonic.
But it lost the harmonic perfection of interval order.
Now we try thesame with 4th harmonic limit:
1/1 2/1 3/1 4/1 (2/1 + 3/2 + 4/3)
We can make it:
1/1 2/1 8/3 4/1 (2/1 + 4/3 + 3/2)
1/1 3/2 3/1 4/1 (3/2 + 2/1 + 4/3)
1/1 3/2 2/1 4/1 (3/2 + 4/3 + 2/1)
1/1 4/3 8/3 4/1 (4/3 + 2/1 + 3/2)
1/1 4/3 2/1 4/1 (4/3 + 3/2 + 2/1)

If we keep the 1/1 at thesame frequency, and lay on top of eachother all the
possible permutations of 4-limit harmonic series (as given above) we get:
1/1 4/3 3/2 2/1 8/3 3/1 4/1
Reduced to one octave it is: 1/1 4/3 3/2 2/1

Of the above scale we can say the following:
All the intervals come from / are related to 1/1.
All these permutations are the simplest in an harmonic sense just like a
limited harmonic series is, with the only difference that the harmonic order
is permutated.

For 5-limit harmonic permutation the scale is:
1/1 5/4 4/3 3/2 5/3 15/8 2/1 (when reduced to one octave)

For 6-limit harmonic permutation the scale is:
1/1 9/8 6/5 5/4 4/3 3/2 8/5 5/3 9/5 15/8 2/1

For 7-limit harmonic permutation the scale is:
1/1 21/20 35/32 9/8 7/6 6/5 5/4 21/16 4/3 7/5 35/24 3/2 14/9 8/5 5/3 7/4 9/5
28/15 15/8 35/18 2/1

Now I do not think that for instance a musical mode like major and minor
scales are nessecarily in 1 root.
It's quite possible there's a change of interval root / chord root going on
during the playing of a mode.

So for instance major mode: 1/1 9/8 5/4 4/3 3/2 5/3 15/8 2/1 could be part
of 1 "root" / all intervals comming from thesame 1/1 source in the 6-limit
harmonic permutation scale.
But it could also be that there's a 3/2 change of root somewhere while
playing the mode, and that there are 2 roots, 1/1 and 3/2 and both roots
have the 5-limit harmonic permutation scale comming / centering from them.
giving (1/1 9/8 5/4 4/3 45/32 3/2 5/3 15/8 2/1)

And there's another way of looking at it.
If you take 5-limit harmonic series.
And instead of centering all permutations on 1/1, you also center them on
2/1 3/1 4/1 and 5/1, you get the following scale:
1/1 16/15 9/8 6/5 5/4 4/3 45/32 3/2 8/5 5/3 9/5 15/8 2/1 (12 tone scale!)
You can hear a simplified result of this line of thinking in my computer
generated choir composition at www.develde.net (bottom of page)
6-limit harmonic permutation scale centering around 1/1 2/1 3/1 4/1 5/1 6/1
gives: 1/1 25/24 16/15 10/9 9/8 6/5 5/4 4/3 27/20 25/18 45/32 3/2 25/16 8/5
5/3 27/16 16/9 9/5 15/8 2/1

But I've come back a bit to seeing chords as stemming from intervals comming
from a single 1/1 root.
Though not sure about anything really.

But the above things give me some reference to chords and modes, and changes
of roots (something similar to a modulation, only a bit deeper and much more
frequent, more like change of root or fundamental bass).
Thesame things above can be aplied to "changes of roots" and give
interesting musical results and insights.

Many many more things to tell but I'll figure things out a bit more myself
and then make a pretty website.

As for why it works.
Well you can read my above story to start.
Lots more to tell besides this though. I've put a lot of thinking into
things.
Both mathematically and logically, thinking about things like comma pumps
and other impossibilities and possibilities etc.
And offcourse tried to test everything by ear and by tuning things, trying
to make sense of music etc.
And of all things I tried (many many things over the past several years),
the above way of seeing things is by far the most musical I've ever
encountered, and it works out.
Not saying I'm done yet though, but it's allready really good in my opinion.
And as far as I know there isn't anything better out there.

Marcel

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/24/2010 12:40:06 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Carl Lumma" <carl@...> wrote:
>
> --- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "cameron" <misterbobro@> wrote:
>
> > You're telling me what the definition of "pun" is at the tuning
> > list. And I certainly can, should, and will continue to, prefer
> > usages which better link to broadly accepted meanings. That is,
> > if it makes more sense and makes for better communication, I'm
> > going to use it.
>
> I definitely think you should use what makes the best
> communication.

Yes indeed. Usually when I'm talking about these things it is
with people "in the flesh", where we can sing and play everything we talk about immediately, and I will continue to prefer
usages which function there.
>
> > > 694 cents is an approximate 3:2. That has to do with
> > > psychoacoustics, not the structure of chord progressions,
> > > which are what xenharmonic puns are about.
> >
> > This is what you say xenharmonic puns are about, but this
> > definition has a gaping hole, which damages potential ways of
> > linking microtonal theory to practice.
>
> Really? What's the gaping hole?

The examples I presented, PunDemo01 and PunDemo03, clearly
illustrate xenharmonic puns in a way immediately audible- Sol suddenly appearing as a tritone, and 1024/1024 hidden in one context and suddenly revealed in another- without a chord in sight. As
I clearly stated earlier.

>
> > Pundemo03.wav demonstrates that the "comma shift" sensation
> > does not require a chord progression, nor does it even require
> > two literal different manifestions of the nominally same interval.
> > Pundemo03 (in Files/CameronBobro at this site) is very like
> > Pundemo01, but voiced a little differently, via octave
> > displacement, and the last note is dropped off, leaving "sol"
> > hanging (a "half cadence"). The small (~8 cents) comma in
> > PunDemo01 is much more apparent in PunDemo3. Whether it sounds
> > slightly flat, a little "blue", or like a "comma shift", in
> > this version it is clear that the "sol" is not 3/2.
> > We do not need chords to hear this, and we do not need a
> > pure 3/2 performed before or after to hear this: 3:1 is already
> > there as a reference in the harmonic series. If the octave-
> > dropped Do were sustained through the second phrase, this
> > would be glaringly obvious, but I think it is important to hear
> > how these things happen even without vertical harmony.
>
> I have no idea what you're talking about re. this example.

understood.

> three examples use 10% of the available space (blame yahoo

"permanent" purposes (website etc.) and the massive transfers

but the robots will erase them in ten days.

2/24/2010 4:54:28 AM

> I'll take them down soon then, and try to find another place.
> We've got a great server of our own but it is intended for specific
> "permanent" purposes (website etc.) and the massive transfers
> involved in the digital arts, so I can upload huge files at whim
> but the robots will erase them in ten days.
>

ðŸ”—Carl Lumma <carl@...>

2/24/2010 10:14:54 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "cameron" <misterbobro@...> wrote:

> > Really? What's the gaping hole?
>
> The examples I presented, PunDemo01 and PunDemo03, clearly
> illustrate xenharmonic puns in a way immediately audible- Sol
> suddenly appearing as a tritone, and 1024/1024 hidden in one
> context and suddenly revealed in another- without a chord in
> sight. As I clearly stated earlier.

Uh... "tritone" here refers to scale degrees, which have nothing
to do with puns... at all. 1024/1024 = 1/1. And I'm going to
duck out.

-Carl

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/24/2010 10:29:52 PM

Great, thanks!

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/24/2010 10:52:07 PM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Carl Lumma" <carl@...> wrote:
>
> --- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "cameron" <misterbobro@> wrote:
>
> > > Really? What's the gaping hole?
> >
> > The examples I presented, PunDemo01 and PunDemo03, clearly
> > illustrate xenharmonic puns in a way immediately audible- Sol
> > suddenly appearing as a tritone, and 1024/1024 hidden in one
> > context and suddenly revealed in another- without a chord in
> > sight. As I clearly stated earlier.
>
> Uh... "tritone" here refers to scale degrees, which have nothing
> to do with puns... at all. 1024/1024 = 1/1. And I'm going to
> duck out.
>
> -Carl
>

Hahaha! You resort to sophistry. Anyone following the thread will see that I simply made a typo, it should 1029/1024, as I wrote earlier in the thread.

And of course you are ducking out- anyone listening to the examples
I presented can hear how the 1029/1024 comma can be quite masked, or revealed, with a "shifting" sound, according to context. Without chords.

And scale degrees most certainly can be involved in "puns", also demonstrated very clearly in the examples I gave. You seek to limit the meaning of the word, unreasonably.

But let's say we forget about definitions, let's say I agree to use a different terms, say " a Mathilda" or "a flornk". It is indeed the case- as I said earlier!- that I don't really care. Hmmm! Forgetting about that, let's see what is happening... you have managed to completely avoid addressing what is going on the sound examples, regardless of what we call it!

Yet these are very specific responses to some of Mike Battaglia's posts, for they demonstrate very plainly "organic" links of the 3rd and 5th partials to the 7th.

It seems more important to you to insist on a tuning-list developed definition than to address phenomena which directly apply to the creation of music. Very unwise, for the examples are in plain earshot and anyone listening can hear for themselves that they do the things I'm saying they do. A moment of thought will reveal how these directly relate to actual music making in a large number of tunings and temperaments, including Miracle.

-Cameron Bobro

ðŸ”—Kalle <kalleaho@...>

2/25/2010 12:55:55 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "cameron" <misterbobro@...> wrote:

> And of course you are ducking out- anyone listening to the examples
> I presented can hear how the 1029/1024 comma can be quite masked,
> or revealed, with a "shifting" sound, according to context. Without
> chords.

Cameron,

I'm now listening to PunDemo03, I'm not sure what I'm supposed to hear.
Is it that some scale degree has two different instances tuned
differently but nevertheless heard as the same scale degree or what?

Kalle Aho

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/25/2010 2:54:53 AM

> Cameron,
>
> I'm now listening to PunDemo03, I'm not sure what I'm supposed to hear.
> Is it that some scale degree has two different instances tuned
> differently but nevertheless heard as the same scale degree or what?
>
> Kalle Aho
>

It doesn't, that's the strange thing about it. The first phrase has the same "comma shifted" pseudo-fifth as the second phrase, a literal septimal tritone, 3 steps of 8/7 (1029/1024, about 8 cents, down from 3/2).

It's quite well hidden in the first phrase. It is hidden by the heavy-handed function of 3/2, which is a deeper effect than merely that of any specific culture of course, as it is obviously based on the third harmonic partial. Less obvious is that the 1029/1024 comma is hidden not just by sol!>do!, but by putting the steps the pseudo-fifth is made of into the phrase: all steps in the piece are pure 8/7s.

In phrase two of PunDemo03, the pseudo-fifth is left exposed (not hiding in resolution to the tonic) as well as right up against a recently sounding pure "3:2", in the form of the third partial of the lowest sound tone. Now the 1029/1024 difference clearly shows up, but not tragically, as a seven-limit interval has been introduced in terms of 7-limit intervals.

This is a "worst case" example, in terms of commas, because there are no tempered intervals. In a myriad of tunings and temperaments, this pun- or should I say florp?- works beautifully: Miracle, 31-et, and even straight-up 1/4 comma meantone.

There are many points being made in these little demos, including the point you made recently that our "reference grids" are also scalar, not just "JI lattice", but I'll stop here for the moment, thanks for listening...

-Cameron Bobro

ðŸ”—Kalle <kalleaho@...>

2/26/2010 6:52:28 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "cameron" <misterbobro@...> wrote:
>
>
> > Cameron,
> >
> > I'm now listening to PunDemo03, I'm not sure what I'm supposed to
> > hear. Is it that some scale degree has two different instances
> > tuned differently but nevertheless heard as the same scale degree
> > or what?
> >
>
> It doesn't, that's the strange thing about it. The first phrase has
> the same "comma shifted" pseudo-fifth as the second phrase, a
> literal septimal tritone, 3 steps of 8/7 (1029/1024, about 8 cents,
> down from 3/2).

What do you mean by "pseudo-fifth", that the 343:512 is not exactly
2:3, that it is a tritone, or what?

> It's quite well hidden in the first phrase.

What is?

> It is hidden by the heavy-handed function of 3/2, which is a deeper
> effect than merely that of any specific culture of course, as it is
> obviously based on the third harmonic partial. Less obvious is that
> the 1029/1024 comma is hidden not just by sol!>do!, but by putting
> the steps the pseudo-fifth is made of into the phrase: all steps in
> the piece are pure 8/7s.

I don't get this. I think the comma is hidden simply because there is
just one voice and that an 8 cents mistuning of 2:3 doesn't make the
interval sound like something else than a fifth. But if the 7:8 steps
are played successively and the listener expects to hear a tritone
(which it literally is if 7:8 is heard as a "tone") but hears an ~2:3
then that would be interesting. I should try that.

> In phrase two of PunDemo03, the pseudo-fifth is left exposed (not
> hiding in resolution to the tonic) as well as right up against a
> recently sounding pure "3:2", in the form of the third partial of
> the lowest sound tone. Now the 1029/1024 difference clearly shows
> up, but not tragically, as a seven-limit interval has been
> introduced in terms of 7-limit intervals.

Sorry but I don't hear anything like that. I just generally don't
hear out individual harmonics from pitched tones so I don't hear the
"pseudo-fifth" against a pure 2:3.

> This is a "worst case" example, in terms of commas, because there
> are no tempered intervals.

Well, if that 343:512 is used as an ~2:3, it can be considered a
tempered fifth, why not?

> In a myriad of tunings and temperaments, this pun- or should I say
> florp?- works beautifully: Miracle, 31-et, and even straight-up 1/4
> comma meantone.
>
> There are many points being made in these little demos, including
> the point you made recently that our "reference grids" are also
> scalar, not just "JI lattice", but I'll stop here for the moment,
> thanks for listening...

Actually my point was that most people don't hear in terms of JI
lattice at all.

Kalle Aho

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/27/2010 11:44:24 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Kalle" <kalleaho@...> wrote:

> What do you mean by "pseudo-fifth", that the 343:512 is not exactly
> 2:3, that it is a tritone, or what?

Both. I just called it that to note that it isn't 3:2, and it is a septimal tritone. But it's obviously "sol", as I said.
>
> > It's quite well hidden in the first phrase.
>
> What is?

The difference between 512:343 and 3:2.
>
> > It is hidden by the heavy-handed function of 3/2, which is a >deeper
> > effect than merely that of any specific culture of course, as it is
> > obviously based on the third harmonic partial. Less obvious is that
> > the 1029/1024 comma is hidden not just by sol!>do!, but by putting
> > the steps the pseudo-fifth is made of into the phrase: all steps in
> > the piece are pure 8/7s.
>
Kalle:
> I don't get this. I think the comma is hidden simply because there >is
> just one voice and that an 8 cents mistuning of 2:3 doesn't make >the
> interval sound like something else than a fifth.

That what I just said: Heavy-handed function of 3:2. Sol!-Do!

>But if the 7:8 steps
> are played successively and the listener expects to hear a tritone
> (which it literally is if 7:8 is heard as a "tone") but hears an >~2:3
> then that would be interesting. I should try that.

That is precisely what happens in the second phrase of PunDemo01 and PunDemo02. And exactly what I already said, and deliberately did: 3 steps of pure 8/7.
>
> > In phrase two of PunDemo03, the pseudo-fifth is left exposed (not
> > hiding in resolution to the tonic) as well as right up against a
> > recently sounding pure "3:2", in the form of the third partial of
> > the lowest sound tone. Now the 1029/1024 difference clearly shows
> > up, but not tragically, as a seven-limit interval has been
> > introduced in terms of 7-limit intervals.
>
> Sorry but I don't hear anything like that. I just generally don't
> hear out individual harmonics from pitched tones so I don't hear the
> "pseudo-fifth" against a pure 2:3.

Yet in your first response, you asked if it were two intervals going under the same "name". Which is precisely how I hear it, even knowing exactly what the intervals are and hearing it many times: the context makes it sound like "sol" in the second phrase is "blue" or somehow altered.
>
> > This is a "worst case" example, in terms of commas, because there
> > are no tempered intervals.
>
> Well, if that 343:512 is used as an ~2:3, it can be considered a
> tempered fifth, why not?

??? Obviously it can be used as a tempered fifth, I have called it "sol" a number of times already.

We've strayed far afar from the original point, though. Mike, a jazz pianist versed in 12-tET but looking for harmonic-series evolution of the art in fixed-pitch instruments, wanted a fluid connection to the seventh partial, all I did was present one of the "organic" connections.

Carl suggested 22-tET to Mike, pajara temperament. Now, take a look at the examples I posted...

That stuff about terminology, what's a "pun"- that's just smoke, a distraction. The real issue is that I consider the 8:7...3:2 (7:4...4:3) connection vital to a fluid evolution from 5-limit to 7. "Pajara" temperament in general, either solidly undershoots or overshoots this, as far as I know. 22 equal certainly does. Yes, I think 22 is simply a wrong answer. Of course Mike may try 22 and find that it the holy grail for him.

Snuck in a few minutes to noodle out a short example of a tuning that
I think much better does fulfil what Mike is looking for, if he's looking ideally for a fluid connection from pure 5-limit to pure 7-limit, at least partially/at first.

http://dl.kibla.org/dl.php?filename=5and7example.wav

-Cameron

ðŸ”—Kalle Aho <kalleaho@...>

2/28/2010 1:29:11 PM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "cameron" <misterbobro@...> wrote:
> --- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Kalle" <kalleaho@> wrote:
>
> > What do you mean by "pseudo-fifth", that the 343:512 is not
> > exactly 2:3, that it is a tritone, or what?
>
> Both. I just called it that to note that it isn't 3:2, and it is a
> septimal tritone. But it's obviously "sol", as I said.

No, it isn't that obviously "sol". Solfège is usually used with the
diatonic scale but the 7:8 doesn't behave like a diatonic whole tone,
the "septimal ditone" of 49:64 already has nothing to do with
diatonic major third.

> > > It's quite well hidden in the first phrase.
> >
> > What is?
>
> The difference between 512:343 and 3:2.
> >
> > > It is hidden by the heavy-handed function of 3/2, which is a
> > > deeper effect than merely that of any specific culture of
> > > course, as it is obviously based on the third harmonic partial.
> > > Less obvious is that the 1029/1024 comma is hidden not just by
> > > sol!>do!, but by putting the steps the pseudo-fifth is made of
> > > into the phrase: all steps in the piece are pure 8/7s.
> >
> Kalle:
> > I don't get this. I think the comma is hidden simply because
> > there is just one voice and that an 8 cents mistuning of 2:3
> > doesn't make the interval sound like something else than a fifth.
>
> That what I just said: Heavy-handed function of 3:2. Sol!-Do!

Yes but I was objecting to the second claim that the 1024:1029 is
"hidden" also by pure 7:8 steps. Of course they add up to 343:512
which is 1024:1029 shy of 2:3 but I think I'd hear anything radically
different if the 7:8s were replaced by (third root of 2:3)s.

> > But if the 7:8 steps are played successively and the listener
> > expects to hear a tritone (which it literally is if 7:8 is heard
> > as a "tone") but hears an ~2:3 then that would be interesting. I
> > should try that.
>
> That is precisely what happens in the second phrase of PunDemo01
> and PunDemo02. And exactly what I already said, and deliberately
> did: 3 steps of pure 8/7.

What I had in mind was an effect where a listener expects to hear a
diatonic tritone/augmented fourth but hears an ~2:3. I tried to hear
it that way but it didn't work. Anyway, that was just a side
point.

> > > In phrase two of PunDemo03, the pseudo-fifth is left exposed
> > > (not hiding in resolution to the tonic) as well as right up
> > > against a recently sounding pure "3:2", in the form of the
> > > third partial of the lowest sound tone. Now the 1029/1024
> > > difference clearly shows up, but not tragically, as a
> > > seven-limit interval has been introduced in terms of 7-limit
> > > intervals.
> >
> > Sorry but I don't hear anything like that. I just generally don't
> > hear out individual harmonics from pitched tones so I don't hear
> > the "pseudo-fifth" against a pure 2:3.
>
> Yet in your first response, you asked if it were two intervals
> going under the same "name".

Only to be sure what I was supposed to listen for.

> Which is precisely how I hear it, even knowing exactly what the
> intervals are and hearing it many times: the context makes it sound
> like "sol" in the second phrase is "blue" or somehow altered.

I don't hear that alteration. I wish others would comment.

> > > This is a "worst case" example, in terms of commas, because
> > > there are no tempered intervals.
> >
> > Well, if that 343:512 is used as an ~2:3, it can be considered a
> > tempered fifth, why not?
>
> ??? Obviously it can be used as a tempered fifth, I have called it
> "sol" a number of times already.

OK, why then did you say "there are no tempered intervals"? As Carl
said in message #86723:

"There are of course an infinite number of pairs of lattice points
that are imperceptibly close together, where one does not need to
change the size of any intervals to achieve temperament. That doesn't
change the fact that temperament (in the abstract sense we use on
tuning-math) has been achieved."

> We've strayed far afar from the original point, though. Mike, a
> jazz pianist versed in 12-tET but looking for harmonic-series
> evolution of the art in fixed-pitch instruments, wanted a fluid
> connection to the seventh partial, all I did was present one of the
> "organic" connections.
>
> Carl suggested 22-tET to Mike, pajara temperament. Now, take a
> look at the examples I posted...
>
> That stuff about terminology, what's a "pun"- that's just smoke, a
> distraction. The real issue is that I consider the 8:7...3:2
> (7:4...4:3) connection vital to a fluid evolution from 5-limit to
> 7.

This is puzzling in so many ways. How does this 7:8s to 2:3
connection constitute a fluid evolution from 5-limit to 7-limit?
1024:1029 doesn't even contain factors of 5. I would have thought
that going from 5-limit to 7-limit would start with 5-limit intervals
but you just introduce 7:8s out of nowhere. And why do we have to
find these bridges first in the "untempered" JI lattice? That smacks
of JI fundamentalism.

> "Pajara" temperament in general, either solidly undershoots or
> overshoots this, as far as I know. 22 equal certainly does. Yes, I
> think 22 is simply a wrong answer. Of course Mike may try 22 and
> find that it the holy grail for him.

Wrong answer to what question? And maybe Mike is better suited to
answer: why there has to be a fluid evolution instead of a direct
leap?

I don't think it is a good argument against Pajara or 22-equal that
they don't temper out 1024:1029. Even 99-equal which has very
accurate 7-limit approximations doesn't temper it out.

Kalle Aho

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

2/28/2010 10:21:26 PM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Kalle Aho" <kalleaho@...> wrote:
>
>
>
> --- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "cameron" <misterbobro@> wrote:

> > > exactly 2:3, that it is a tritone, or what?
> >

> > septimal tritone. But it's obviously "sol", as I said.
>
> No, it isn't that obviously "sol". Solfège is usually used with the
> diatonic scale but the 7:8 doesn't behave like a diatonic whole >tone,
> the "septimal ditone" of 49:64 already has nothing to do with
> diatonic major third.

I promise to let you know if one single person for whom I play
this out in the world ever hears it as something other than sol to do
or equivalent, pa to sa or sad to da etc. etc.

> Yes but I was objecting to the second claim that the 1024:1029 is
> "hidden" also by pure 7:8 steps. Of course they add up to 343:512
> which is 1024:1029 shy of 2:3 but I think I'd hear anything >radically
> different if the 7:8s were replaced by (third root of 2:3)s.

Ah, where is the "facepalm" smiley? "laughing out loud"- didn't I
specifically mention miracle temperament- twice!- as doing this exact particular thing very well? What is the "8/7" of miracle? I also think that there isn't much difference as long as three "8/7s" make a good "pun" with 3:2, that's the point! It is when they don't that you a disjointed 7th partial.

> > Which is precisely how I hear it, even knowing exactly what the
> > intervals are and hearing it many times: the context makes it >sound
> > like "sol" in the second phrase is "blue" or somehow altered.
>
> I don't hear that alteration. I wish others would comment.

Would be nice, but really it is not the point, the point is as above.
>
> > > > This is a "worst case" example, in terms of commas, because
> > > > there are no tempered intervals.
> > >
> > > Well, if that 343:512 is used as an ~2:3, it can be considered a
> > > tempered fifth, why not?
> >
> > ??? Obviously it can be used as a tempered fifth, I have called it
> > "sol" a number of times already.
>
> OK, why then did you say "there are no tempered intervals"? As Carl
> said in message #86723:
>
> "There are of course an infinite number of pairs of lattice points
> that are imperceptibly close together, where one does not need to
> change the size of any intervals to achieve temperament. That >doesn't
> change the fact that temperament (in the abstract sense we use on
> tuning-math) has been achieved."

I said that there are no tempered intervals because there are no tempered intervals. "imperceptibly close together"? I made a point
of stating that what I'm talking about does NOT require intervals
to be imperceptibly close together, even got lead off on a tangent
about the perceptible difference in the example I gave.

>
> > We've strayed far afar from the original point, though. Mike, a
> > jazz pianist versed in 12-tET but looking for harmonic-series
> > evolution of the art in fixed-pitch instruments, wanted a fluid
> > connection to the seventh partial, all I did was present one of the
> > "organic" connections.
> >
> > Carl suggested 22-tET to Mike, pajara temperament. Now, take a
> > look at the examples I posted...
> >
> > That stuff about terminology, what's a "pun"- that's just smoke, a
> > distraction. The real issue is that I consider the 8:7...3:2
> > (7:4...4:3) connection vital to a fluid evolution from 5-limit to
> > 7.
>
> This is puzzling in so many ways. How does this 7:8s to 2:3
> connection constitute a fluid evolution from 5-limit to 7-limit?
> 1024:1029 doesn't even contain factors of 5. I would have thought
> that going from 5-limit to 7-limit would start with 5-limit >intervals
> but you just introduce 7:8s out of nowhere. And why do we have to
> find these bridges first in the "untempered" JI lattice? That >smacks
> of JI fundamentalism.

What "JI lattice?" To be honest, my eyes kind of glaze over when I see those lattices. I'm talking about proportions in harmonic series combined with scalar modalities.

What do you mean, "out of nowhere"? Did you listen to the file I uploaded in conjunction, PunDemo02?
>
> > "Pajara" temperament in general, either solidly undershoots or
> > overshoots this, as far as I know. 22 equal certainly does. Yes, >I
> > think 22 is simply a wrong answer. Of course Mike may try 22 and
> > find that it the holy grail for him.
>
> Wrong answer to what question? And maybe Mike is better suited to
> answer: why there has to be a fluid evolution instead of a direct
> leap?

Of course Mike may like his 7th partial just "tacked on", or may even be up for losing the 5-limit altogether, I don't know.
>
> I don't think it is a good argument against Pajara or 22-equal that
> they don't temper out 1024:1029. Even 99-equal which has very
> accurate 7-limit approximations doesn't temper it out.

Well, there is the problem: too much noun, not enough verb. The 7/4 proportion is not just "so and so large", it is also "does this and that in relationship with these and those."

-Cameron Bobro

ðŸ”—Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...>

2/28/2010 11:08:07 PM

Hi everyone,

Just checked out some of the examples posted. It's interesting to see the
differing ideas that people have about extending to the 7-limit. I like the
"5and7example" clip that Cameron posted - although it's a different "way" of
extending to the 7-limit than I was picturing, it's good for me to hear how
other people are doing things as well.

It's kind of like if I was an early Catholic monk transported to the present
day asking how to extend music to the 5-limit. And some people are saying
"check out Beethoven," some say "check out Bach," yet others are saying
"listen to Chopin," and so on.

In case people are curious - I have found a lot of success by taking 12-tet
chord progressions that I -ALREADY- perceive as being in the 7-limit - and
then justly intonating them, starting with simple modal things for now. By
"meditating" on and thinking about common chord progressions, sometimes I
can get an intuitive glimmer of how I'm really perceiving things "under the
hood." Maybe it's all placebo but it's been working well so far.

Something like ||: Abmaj | F7 :||. This is a very Beatles-esque progression
and I find it works well in the 7-limit. You keep the C between the two
chords constant, and shift the Eb in the Ab chord down 36/35 - which works
very well as a "chromatic" interval in this case.

It is something fun to play with though - where in already existing 12-tet
music are 7-limit implications hinted at? I think that it might be
worthwhile (for me at least) to examine some more recent popular music:
later Beatles stuff, classic 60's soul, and so on. Sometimes it's just
5-limit modal stuff they use, but I think there's a deeper answer in there
somewhere.

One question to cameron: what is your pundemo02 supposed to be? Lots of
interesting stuff happening in there.

-Mike

> Ah, where is the "facepalm" smiley? "laughing out loud"- didn't I
> specifically mention miracle temperament- twice!- as doing this exact
> particular thing very well? What is the "8/7" of miracle? I also think that
> there isn't much difference as long as three "8/7s" make a good "pun" with
> 3:2, that's the point! It is when they don't that you a disjointed 7th
> partial.
>
>
>
> > > Which is precisely how I hear it, even knowing exactly what the
> > > intervals are and hearing it many times: the context makes it >sound
> > > like "sol" in the second phrase is "blue" or somehow altered.
> >
> > I don't hear that alteration. I wish others would comment.
>
> Would be nice, but really it is not the point, the point is as above.
>
> >
> > > > > This is a "worst case" example, in terms of commas, because
> > > > > there are no tempered intervals.
> > > >
> > > > Well, if that 343:512 is used as an ~2:3, it can be considered a
> > > > tempered fifth, why not?
> > >
> > > ??? Obviously it can be used as a tempered fifth, I have called it
> > > "sol" a number of times already.
> >
> > OK, why then did you say "there are no tempered intervals"? As Carl
> > said in message #86723:
> >
> > "There are of course an infinite number of pairs of lattice points
> > that are imperceptibly close together, where one does not need to
> > change the size of any intervals to achieve temperament. That >doesn't
> > change the fact that temperament (in the abstract sense we use on
> > tuning-math) has been achieved."
>
> I said that there are no tempered intervals because there are no tempered
> intervals. "imperceptibly close together"? I made a point
> of stating that what I'm talking about does NOT require intervals
> to be imperceptibly close together, even got lead off on a tangent
> about the perceptible difference in the example I gave.
>
> >
> > > We've strayed far afar from the original point, though. Mike, a
> > > jazz pianist versed in 12-tET but looking for harmonic-series
> > > evolution of the art in fixed-pitch instruments, wanted a fluid
> > > connection to the seventh partial, all I did was present one of the
> > > "organic" connections.
> > >
> > > Carl suggested 22-tET to Mike, pajara temperament. Now, take a
> > > look at the examples I posted...
> > >
> > > That stuff about terminology, what's a "pun"- that's just smoke, a
> > > distraction. The real issue is that I consider the 8:7...3:2
> > > (7:4...4:3) connection vital to a fluid evolution from 5-limit to
> > > 7.
> >
> > This is puzzling in so many ways. How does this 7:8s to 2:3
> > connection constitute a fluid evolution from 5-limit to 7-limit?
> > 1024:1029 doesn't even contain factors of 5. I would have thought
> > that going from 5-limit to 7-limit would start with 5-limit >intervals
> > but you just introduce 7:8s out of nowhere. And why do we have to
> > find these bridges first in the "untempered" JI lattice? That >smacks
> > of JI fundamentalism.
>
> What "JI lattice?" To be honest, my eyes kind of glaze over when I see
> those lattices. I'm talking about proportions in harmonic series combined
> with scalar modalities.
>
> What do you mean, "out of nowhere"? Did you listen to the file I uploaded
> in conjunction, PunDemo02?
>
> >
> > > "Pajara" temperament in general, either solidly undershoots or
> > > overshoots this, as far as I know. 22 equal certainly does. Yes, >I
> > > think 22 is simply a wrong answer. Of course Mike may try 22 and
> > > find that it the holy grail for him.
> >
> > Wrong answer to what question? And maybe Mike is better suited to
> > answer: why there has to be a fluid evolution instead of a direct
> > leap?
>
> Of course Mike may like his 7th partial just "tacked on", or may even be up
> for losing the 5-limit altogether, I don't know.
>
> >
> > I don't think it is a good argument against Pajara or 22-equal that
> > they don't temper out 1024:1029. Even 99-equal which has very
> > accurate 7-limit approximations doesn't temper it out.
>
> Well, there is the problem: too much noun, not enough verb. The 7/4
> proportion is not just "so and so large", it is also "does this and that in
> relationship with these and those."
>
> -Cameron Bobro
>
>
>

ðŸ”—Marcel de Velde <m.develde@...>

3/1/2010 5:03:55 AM

Hi Mike,

In case people are curious - I have found a lot of success by taking 12-tet
> chord progressions that I -ALREADY- perceive as being in the 7-limit - and
> then justly intonating them, starting with simple modal things for now. By
> "meditating" on and thinking about common chord progressions, sometimes I
> can get an intuitive glimmer of how I'm really perceiving things "under the
> hood." Maybe it's all placebo but it's been working well so far.
>

Well, on trying things like this out myself, I've found it's indeed very
very easy to get placebo effect all the time.
I do agree chord progressions are the right way to test out.

>
> Something like ||: Abmaj | F7 :||. This is a very Beatles-esque progression
> and I find it works well in the 7-limit. You keep the C between the two
> chords constant, and shift the Eb in the Ab chord down 36/35 - which works
> very well as a "chromatic" interval in this case.
>

I don't see why Eb needs to drop at all.
How're you tuning the rest?

As for trying to achieve 7-limit, I would personally find the above
progression a bit unclear to check with.
Yet I don't know myself how to do it either.

I know of only 1 clear 7-limit chord myself actually (though havent been
bussy searching for others).
The whole tone scale.
1/1 9/8 5/4 7/5 8/5 9/5 2/1 (there are other 7-limit possibilities for this
maybe)
I find it isn't possible in my 6-limit harmonic system, so it simply must be
7-limit.
There's also no possible prime-5-limit solution possible that's even
remotely acceptable, and 7-limit sounds absolutely correct to me here.

Marcel

ðŸ”—Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...>

3/1/2010 1:20:38 PM

> Well, on trying things like this out myself, I've found it's indeed very very easy to get placebo effect all the time.
> I do agree chord progressions are the right way to test out.

Luckily, there's a good test to see if it's the placebo effect: if you
tune it in 7-limit JI, and it makes you want to destroy your sound
system, it was a placebo.

>> Something like ||: Abmaj | F7 :||. This is a very Beatles-esque progression and I find it works well in the 7-limit. You keep the C between the two chords constant, and shift the Eb in the Ab chord down 36/35 - which works very well as a "chromatic" interval in this case.
>
> I don't see why Eb needs to drop at all.
> How're you tuning the rest?

The Abmaj is 4:5:6, the F7 is 4:5:6:7. The C between the two chords is
held constant. You could also hold the Eb constant if you wanted, but
that doesn't sound as good. And you could also intonate the F7 as
having two 6/5's stacked on top of each other at the top (instead of a
7/6) but it just doesn't sound as awesome (technical term).

-Mike

ðŸ”—Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...>

3/1/2010 1:21:42 PM

And by "also hold the Eb constant," I mean keep the Eb constant
between the two chords so that the root moves down by a 7:6 instead of
a 6:5. I can't get into the 7:6 root movement yet, it doesn't sound
right there. Or at the very least, it sounds unfamiliar.

-Mike

On Mon, Mar 1, 2010 at 4:20 PM, Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...> wrote:
>> Well, on trying things like this out myself, I've found it's indeed very very easy to get placebo effect all the time.
>> I do agree chord progressions are the right way to test out.
>
> Luckily, there's a good test to see if it's the placebo effect: if you
> tune it in 7-limit JI, and it makes you want to destroy your sound
> system, it was a placebo.
>
>>> Something like ||: Abmaj | F7 :||. This is a very Beatles-esque progression and I find it works well in the 7-limit. You keep the C between the two chords constant, and shift the Eb in the Ab chord down 36/35 - which works very well as a "chromatic" interval in this case.
>>
>> I don't see why Eb needs to drop at all.
>> How're you tuning the rest?
>
> The Abmaj is 4:5:6, the F7 is 4:5:6:7. The C between the two chords is
> held constant. You could also hold the Eb constant if you wanted, but
> that doesn't sound as good. And you could also intonate the F7 as
> having two 6/5's stacked on top of each other at the top (instead of a
> 7/6) but it just doesn't sound as awesome (technical term).
>
> -Mike

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

3/2/2010 1:06:49 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...> wrote:
>
> Hi everyone,
>
> Just checked out some of the examples posted. It's interesting to >see the
> differing ideas that people have about extending to the 7-limit. I >like the
> "5and7example" clip that Cameron posted - although it's a different >"way" of
> extending to the 7-limit than I was picturing, it's good for me to hear how
> other people are doing things as well.

Glad you liked it, just noodling there, but with the intent to illustrate 5 and 7 together. Anyone care to guess the tuning/temperament there?

That example is not actually "how I do it", personally, it's just an example- I'm basically at 7-11-13, even the irrational tunings I use usually work out to be very 13th partial based, and one of my Pi tunings turned out by coincidence to be basically indistinguishable from a particular large 11-limit Fokker periodictiy block.

> Something like ||: Abmaj | F7 :||. This is a very Beatles-esque progression
> and I find it works well in the 7-limit. You keep the C between the two
> chords constant, and shift the Eb in the Ab chord down 36/35 - which works
> very well as a "chromatic" interval in this case.

I agree that the 36/35 step here is great, anyway why would anyone want to take blue notes out of rock and roll?

> One question to cameron: what is your pundemo02 supposed to be? >Lots of
> interesting stuff happening in there.

It just races up from pure 5s to pure 7s then mixes them in the chords. But there are many possibilities implied, I think. The pivot tone there is the pun of two steps of 8/7 and the 5-limit augmented third. In some temperaments this is very slick indeed- in the secor-based temperaments you can sleekly move all over the place from the underlying 3*( 8:7) structure within the pentachord.

There's another interesting thing involved here. I have been saying for a couple of years here that in judging "good approximations" of Just intervals, sheer proximity is not enough. Let's say you have an 8/7 approximated at 230 cents, and an 8/7 approximated at 233 cents. The first is about 1 cent flat, the second about 2 cents sharp (of a pure 8/7). But if you are using this particular division of the pentachord, which interlocks with other divisions, the second, "worse" approximation is clearly better, not only because you'd probably want a 699 cent fifth rather than a 690 cent fifth, but because a 690 cent fifth will monkey up the symmetrical interlocking 5-limit-thirds structure of the pentachord, as well as the interlocking symmetrical 7-limit structure of the fourths. (And, obviously, it can make a big difference whether you temper up or down- the fifth of 22 is about 7 cents sharp and the fifth of 26 about 8 cents flat, but musically speaking they sound very different indeed, one is bright and the other is dark (or one is edgy and the other soggy, or whatever)).

-Cameron

ðŸ”—Kalle Aho <kalleaho@...>

3/4/2010 9:52:14 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "cameron" <misterbobro@...> wrote:

> > No, it isn't that obviously "sol". Solfège is usually used with
> > the diatonic scale but the 7:8 doesn't behave like a diatonic
> > whole tone, the "septimal ditone" of 49:64 already has nothing to
> > do with diatonic major third.
>
> I promise to let you know if one single person for whom I play
> this out in the world ever hears it as something other than sol to
> do or equivalent, pa to sa or sad to da etc. etc.

Well, everyone hears an ~2:3 but I don't hear it *as* pa to sa.
Someone who hears it *as* pa to sa might not hear it *as* sol to do.

> > Yes but I was objecting to the second claim that the 1024:1029 is
> > "hidden" also by pure 7:8 steps. Of course they add up to 343:512
> > which is 1024:1029 shy of 2:3 but I think I'd hear anything
> > radically different if the 7:8s were replaced by (third root of
> > 2:3)s.
>
> Ah, where is the "facepalm" smiley? "laughing out loud"- didn't I
> specifically mention miracle temperament- twice!- as doing this
> exact particular thing very well? What is the "8/7" of miracle? I
> also think that there isn't much difference as long as three "8/7s"
> make a good "pun" with 3:2, that's the point! It is when they don't
> that you a disjointed 7th partial.

Personally I don't hear those 7:8s with their harmonic connotations
because they are presented only melodically. They just sound like
some whole-toneish intervals. I just hear an ~2:3 divided into three
equal parts. So the pun is sort of lost on me even if I know what's
going on.

> > OK, why then did you say "there are no tempered intervals"? As
> > Carl said in message #86723:
> >
> > "There are of course an infinite number of pairs of lattice
> > points that are imperceptibly close together, where one does not
> > need to change the size of any intervals to achieve temperament.
> > That doesn't change the fact that temperament (in the abstract
> > sense we use on tuning-math) has been achieved."
>
> I said that there are no tempered intervals because there are no
> tempered intervals. "imperceptibly close together"? I made a point
> of stating that what I'm talking about does NOT require intervals
> to be imperceptibly close together, even got lead off on a tangent
> about the perceptible difference in the example I gave.

OK, to achieve temperament (in the abstract sense) two intervals
(or pitches) that are different in JI must be heard as "the same"
(i.e. belonging to the same specific interval category, scale degree
etc.).

> > > We've strayed far afar from the original point, though. Mike, a
> > > jazz pianist versed in 12-tET but looking for harmonic-series
> > > evolution of the art in fixed-pitch instruments, wanted a fluid
> > > connection to the seventh partial, all I did was present one of
> > > the "organic" connections.
> > >
> > > Carl suggested 22-tET to Mike, pajara temperament. Now, take a
> > > look at the examples I posted...
> > >
> > > That stuff about terminology, what's a "pun"- that's just
> > > smoke, a distraction. The real issue is that I consider the
> > > 8:7...3:2 (7:4...4:3) connection vital to a fluid evolution
> > > from 5-limit to 7.
> >
> > This is puzzling in so many ways. How does this 7:8s to 2:3
> > connection constitute a fluid evolution from 5-limit to 7-limit?
> > 1024:1029 doesn't even contain factors of 5. I would have thought
> > that going from 5-limit to 7-limit would start with 5-limit
> > intervals but you just introduce 7:8s out of nowhere. And why do
> > we have to find these bridges first in the "untempered" JI
> > lattice? That smacks of JI fundamentalism.
>
> What "JI lattice?" To be honest, my eyes kind of glaze over when I
> see those lattices. I'm talking about proportions in harmonic
> series combined with scalar modalities.
>
> What do you mean, "out of nowhere"? Did you listen to the file I
> uploaded in conjunction, PunDemo02?

Yes, I listened to all of them. I pointed out that the 7:8s to
2:3 connection is a no 5s-relation. So it is strange that you
consider it making a bridge from 5-limit to 7-limit. And I would have
thought that an organic progression from 5-limit to 7-limit would
involve some combination of 5-limit intervals sounding a bit like a 7-
limit one. Instead, the ~2:3 is found by stacking 7:8s. So we kind of
go from 7-limit intervals to a 3-limit interval. That's why I
said "out of nowhere".

Why exactly do you think 1024:1029 is vital to a fluid evolution from
5-limit to 7-limit? Do you have some kind of argument for this or is
it just an intuition of yours?

Kalle Aho

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

3/4/2010 2:38:15 PM

important part.
--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Kalle Aho" <kalleaho@...> wrote:

> Why exactly do you think 1024:1029 is vital to a fluid evolution from
> 5-limit to 7-limit? Do you have some kind of argument for this or is

Would say that the file 5and7example does not sound like a
fluid integration of 5s and 7s? I speak first and foremost from
practical experience of course. Try it for yourself.

ðŸ”—Kalle Aho <kalleaho@...>

3/5/2010 6:47:46 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "cameron" <misterbobro@...> wrote:
>
> Arg, now I've twice lost my replies. So I'll just cut to the most
> important part.

Oh, the horror of data loss! I always write longer posts in Notepad
or Metapad and hit 'save' obsessive-compulsorily.

> --- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Kalle Aho" <kalleaho@> wrote:
>
> > Why exactly do you think 1024:1029 is vital to a fluid evolution
> > from 5-limit to 7-limit? Do you have some kind of argument for
> > this or is it just an intuition of yours?
>
> Would say that the file 5and7example does not sound like a
> fluid integration of 5s and 7s?

Sure, it does! I interpreted "vital" to mean that the 1024:1029
bridge absolutely must be included. Don't you think there might be
other fluid integrations of 5s and 7s that don't include it?

> I speak first and foremost from practical experience of course. Try
> it for yourself.

Talking about 7-limit experience I've been playing in Pajara tunings.
Pajara has some things to recommend itself, it must be one of the
most compact arrangements of 7-limit tetrads and the pentachordal
decatonic scale shares many nice properties with the diatonic scale.
But I also think that no fixed pitch tuning of Pajara is particularly
great in terms of accuracy, at least with strictly harmonic
electronic timbres. So adaptive tuning of decatonic music is
definitely something I will be experimenting with.

Kalle Aho

ðŸ”—Carl Lumma <carl@...>

3/5/2010 12:00:23 PM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Kalle Aho" <kalleaho@...> wrote:

> Oh, the horror of data loss! I always write longer posts in Notepad
> or Metapad and hit 'save' obsessive-compulsorily.

Firefox saves everything you type into a web form, if you
accidentally go forward or back, even if you close a tab, and
even if the browser crashes.

-Carl

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

3/7/2010 1:18:44 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Kalle Aho" <kalleaho@...> wrote:
>
>
>
> --- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "cameron" <misterbobro@> wrote:
> >
> > Arg, now I've twice lost my replies. So I'll just cut to the most
> > important part.
>
> Oh, the horror of data loss! I always write longer posts in Notepad
> or Metapad and hit 'save' obsessive-compulsorily.
>
> > --- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Kalle Aho" <kalleaho@> wrote:
> >
> > > Why exactly do you think 1024:1029 is vital to a fluid evolution
> > > from 5-limit to 7-limit? Do you have some kind of argument for
> > > this or is it just an intuition of yours?
> >
> > Would say that the file 5and7example does not sound like a
> > fluid integration of 5s and 7s?
>
> Sure, it does! I interpreted "vital" to mean that the 1024:1029
> bridge absolutely must be included. Don't you think there might be
> other fluid integrations of 5s and 7s that don't include it?

Could be- I'd love to hear them! Of course I could get completely
circular here. My definition of "fluid" could insist on maintaining
certain proportions found in a Just implementation. But once we
accept temperament or using intervals that function as temperaments,
we have to draw some lines somewhere. Really it is a compositional
matter: for example, let's say we're in C. I think it would be a shame to temper out the "blueing" of the f in your standard backdoor cadence, for example. It's tempered out (you can hold the f from ii through bVII7)in 12-tET and pajara. To me that's avoiding the seventh
partial, not incorporating it.

> Talking about 7-limit experience I've been playing in Pajara >tunings.
> Pajara has some things to recommend itself, it must be one of the
> most compact arrangements of 7-limit tetrads and the pentachordal
> decatonic scale shares many nice properties with the diatonic >scale.
> But I also think that no fixed pitch tuning of Pajara is >particularly
> great in terms of accuracy, at least with strictly harmonic
> electronic timbres. So adaptive tuning of decatonic music is
> definitely something I will be experimenting with.

I think 22 is better in some ways than it appears because, for example, even though 7/4 is 13 cents off (unacceptable to me), it maintains a very good 7/6 relationship with the "3/2" (in keeping
with my insistence that it is not just a matter of sheer proximity
to a target interval, but also a matter of interrelationships).
So, it makes sense to me that 7-limit tetrads in 22 would sound more Just than the look. But I think that when the structure isn't
essentially blocked tetrads, it falls apart.

If you get adaptive tuning going, I'd love to hear it!

-Cameron Bobro

ðŸ”—John Moriarty <JlMoriart@...>

3/7/2010 9:25:28 PM

Hi Aaron,

> I'm not sure what you say about The Viking is correct, as
> The Viking appears to be able to produce more than
> 12-tones per octave. I was able to get it to do 19ET;
> it's just that the keyboard mapping is all screwed up.
> No matter...

Though one is able to get a 12 tone subset of 19-edo in the viking, the
piano layout it comes with, unfortunately, limits you to only 12 of those
19. Unless of course they've modified it since I last downloaded it, in
which case, I will have to stand corrected. I'll check on that soon.

> This is an attitude, not a fact. "Tonally relevant"
> according to whom, under what criteria? This is what I
> was talking about earlier. To prove this premise suspect,
> one need only to compose some music using those
> pitches that are excluded, showing how relevant those
> excluded pitches can be.

I think that my phrasing "tonally relevant" should be thrown out the window.
You are correct when you say that how "useful" a given set of pitches and
intervals may be is an opinion.

However, if one were to replace each "tonally relevant" with "functionally
discernible", things might make more sense and be less arguably opinion.
When defining functions as locations in a stack of generators, when you get
beyond the first 9 (or so) stacks above and below a tonic, those intervals
begin to be defined functionally as variations of diatonic interval sizes
that they will not function as perceptually. For example, the location in
the stack of fifths that is described as a triply diminished seventh will
almost never be perceived as a seventh. Instead, it will very likely be
perceived as a varied size of the perfect (or "major") fifth. If you are
going to provide the potential for variation within the sizes of discernible
functions that's fine, but don't define them as variations of other
functions when they won't be so perceptually. Is that fair?

> Which shows again the bias here towards thinking
> only in terms of diatonicism.

I do want to make the quick point that the bias is not so much towards
diatonicism, and more so towards MOS scales in general. Playing in other
temperaments provides compact configurations of all MOS scales because, by
definition, a scale composed of a continuous stack of a single generator and
reduced into a single period *will* be well-formed, and this is how the
thummer and the TFS locate pitches on their layout: by generator stacks and
period reductions that tightly surround a given tonal center. For instance,
in the magic temperament which is generated by the major third and octave,
there is an unnamed 10 note well-formed scale that functions similarly
across the entire temperament. It is easy to play on the Thummer or in the
TFS *because* it is a well formed scale. It is in a tight, unbroken region
on the keyboard.

Everything that applies to my first point about "functionally discernible"
intervals being closest to the tonic in a stack of generators applies to
every other temperament. Far beyond the first 19 stacks of major thirds and
off the edge of the thummer keyboard, one might come across a pitch that
gets very close to a pitch in that original 10 note scale, but defining it
as having a different function by name (due to its different location in the
stack of major thirds) while using it functionally similarly as a varied
size of that original interval would be inconsistent, the same way it is
inconsistent in the syntonic (or extended meantone) temperament as with my
example of the triply diminished seventh not functioning as a seventh.

John M

ðŸ”—hpiinstruments <aaronhunt@...>

3/8/2010 10:38:40 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, John Moriarty wrote:
> I think that my phrasing "tonally relevant" should be thrown
> out the window. You are correct when you say that how
> "useful" a given set of pitches and intervals may be is an opinion.

Good. Glad to hear it.

> However, if one were to replace each "tonally relevant" with
> "functionally discernible", things might make more sense
> and be less arguably opinion.

"Discernable" takes you into the territory of psychophysics and
music psychology. You may not want that can of worms on your
hands.

> When defining functions as locations in a stack of generators, when you get
> beyond the first 9 (or so) stacks above and below a tonic, those intervals
> begin to be defined functionally as variations of diatonic interval sizes
> that they will not function as perceptually. For example, the location in
> the stack of fifths that is described as a triply diminished seventh will
> almost never be perceived as a seventh. Instead, it will very likely be
> perceived as a varied size of the perfect (or "major") fifth. If you are
> going to provide the potential for variation within the sizes of discernible
> functions that's fine, but don't define them as variations of other
> functions when they won't be so perceptually. Is that fair?

I think you are saying something similar to this: in Pythagorean
tuning the diminished fourth is a schizma off from 5/4 so it will
be normal to use it as a M3 even though it is a d4. BUT, this does
not mean you throw out the d4. You still need it to write music
correctly, for example an augmented triad in inversion.

> I do want to make the quick point that the bias is not so much towards
> diatonicism, and more so towards MOS scales in general.

OK

> Everything that applies to my first point about "functionally discernible"
> intervals being closest to the tonic in a stack of generators applies to
> every other temperament. Far beyond the first 19 stacks of major thirds and
> off the edge of the thummer keyboard, one might come across a pitch that
> gets very close to a pitch in that original 10 note scale, but defining it
> as having a different function by name (due to its different location in the
> stack of major thirds) while using it functionally similarly as a varied
> size of that original interval would be inconsistent, the same way it is
> inconsistent in the syntonic (or extended meantone) temperament as with my
> example of the triply diminished seventh not functioning as a seventh.

I don't know why you are using a triply diminished seventh as your
example, when it never shows up in actual music. Why not use an
augmented sixth, or its inversion a diminished third, or even a
doubly augmented fourth? Those intervals actually show up in
common practice tonal music, with good reason for the way they
are spelled and used. If you need specific examples, I can supply
them, or you can just look at some scores by Haydn, Schumann,
J.S. Bach, etc.

Yours,
AAH
=====

ðŸ”—Kalle Aho <kalleaho@...>

3/9/2010 6:28:32 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "cameron" <misterbobro@...> wrote:

> > > Would say that the file 5and7example does not sound like a
> > > fluid integration of 5s and 7s?
> >
> > Sure, it does! I interpreted "vital" to mean that the 1024:1029
> > bridge absolutely must be included. Don't you think there might
> > be other fluid integrations of 5s and 7s that don't include it?
>
> Could be- I'd love to hear them! Of course I could get completely
> circular here. My definition of "fluid" could insist on maintaining
> certain proportions found in a Just implementation. But once we
> accept temperament or using intervals that function as
> temperaments, we have to draw some lines somewhere. Really it is a
> compositional matter: for example, let's say we're in C. I think it
> would be a shame to temper out the "blueing" of the f in your
> standard backdoor cadence, for example. It's tempered out (you can
> hold the f from ii through bVII7)in 12-tET and pajara. To me that's
> avoiding the seventh partial, not incorporating it.

I didn't know there is some standard JI interpretation for the
backdoor cadence. That tuning is not obvious to me, can you give me
the pitches when c is 1/1?

> > Talking about 7-limit experience I've been playing in Pajara
> > tunings. Pajara has some things to recommend itself, it must be
> > one of the most compact arrangements of 7-limit tetrads and the
> > pentachordal decatonic scale shares many nice properties with the
> > diatonic scale. But I also think that no fixed pitch tuning of
> > Pajara is particularly great in terms of accuracy, at least with
> > strictly harmonic electronic timbres. So adaptive tuning of
> > decatonic music is definitely something I will be experimenting
> > with.
>
> I think 22 is better in some ways than it appears because, for
> example, even though 7/4 is 13 cents off (unacceptable to me), it
> maintains a very good 7/6 relationship with the "3/2" (in keeping
> with my insistence that it is not just a matter of sheer proximity
> to a target interval, but also a matter of interrelationships).
> So, it makes sense to me that 7-limit tetrads in 22 would sound
> more Just than the look. But I think that when the structure isn't
> essentially blocked tetrads, it falls apart.

I agree with this, full tetrads are the norm and Paul Erlich also
mentions this in his 22-tone paper.

> If you get adaptive tuning going, I'd love to hear it!

I'll post examples as soon as I get them done.

Kalle Aho

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

3/12/2010 1:01:15 AM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, "Kalle Aho" <kalleaho@...> wrote:

>
> I didn't know there is some standard JI interpretation for the
> backdoor cadence. That tuning is not obvious to me, can you give me
> the pitches when c is 1/1?

There is no standard JI interpretation, though I'm sure you could
find interpretations that claim to be "the Truth". Actually, "backdoor cadence" seems to be used for more than one cadence, Mike would know about this. I believe I'm using the term
in a mainstream way: iv7-I would be a backdoor, or ii-bVII7-I (this is the one I meant). You can see how, given the key of c and addressing the seventh partial, the f for example is going to be
open to interpretation, temperament, or microtonal stepwise movement.
See Mike's "Beatles" progression Ab7-F for another specific septimal
question (fifth and seventh of respective chords, tied or blued?)

There is quite a bit to be written about these progression in terms of tuning, and I don't have the time at the moment to explain my
takes(s!) on them, but I'll get to it. With audio examples of course.

> > If you get adaptive tuning going, I'd love to hear it!
>
> I'll post examples as soon as I get them done.
>
> Kalle Aho
>

I'll get some more audio examples up asap, too. And I must take up Chris on his generous hosting offer...

-Cameron Bobro

ðŸ”—Mike Battaglia <battaglia01@...>

3/12/2010 1:24:12 AM

> > I didn't know there is some standard JI interpretation for the
> > backdoor cadence. That tuning is not obvious to me, can you give me
> > the pitches when c is 1/1?
>
> There is no standard JI interpretation, though I'm sure you could
> find interpretations that claim to be "the Truth". Actually, "backdoor cadence" seems to be used for more than one cadence, Mike would know about this. I believe I'm using the term
> in a mainstream way: iv7-I would be a backdoor, or ii-bVII7-I (this is the one I meant). You can see how, given the key of c and addressing the seventh partial, the f for example is going to be
> open to interpretation, temperament, or microtonal stepwise movement.

Different people have different definitions of the "backdoor" cadence.
Perhaps it's iv-I, or ivm7-I, or ivm(maj7)-I, or whatever. The thing
that ties them all together is basically the presence of the b6
somewhere resolving to the I chord. So if you're in C major, somewhere
in that chord progression is going to be an Ab. Whether you want to
treat that as a progression based in C harmonic major, or "descending
melodic major," or something in C minor that turns into C major - is
really arbitrary and up to you.

> See Mike's "Beatles" progression Ab7-F for another specific septimal
> question (fifth and seventh of respective chords, tied or blued?)

If you try the Ab7-Fmaj progression, honestly to me the most natural
sounding thing is to make the root move down 6/5. This would move the
Eb down chromatically (commatically?) and keep the C constant. Doing
it the other way - moving the root down 7/6 - would keep the Eb held
constant but makes the rest of it sound awful as far as I'm concerned.

Or maybe it sounds good, I just have to "get used to it." Who knows?

-Mike

ðŸ”—christopherv <chrisvaisvil@...>

3/24/2010 5:06:22 PM

--- In tuning@yahoogroups.com, Michael <djtrancendance@...> wrote:
>
> Chris,
> To put this ("JI Silver Scale") all into Scala simply input the following values into scala after selecting "new scale" type in
> 13/12,14/12,15/12,17/12,18/12, 20/12, 21/12
> (with the commas to indicate the separation of the ratios).
>
> Scala will automatically reduce the fractions for you.
> Note how the 12:13:14:15: 17:18:20: 21:24 notation relates to the above fractions, only scala creates the 24/12 Silver double octave and 12/12 root tone for you.
>
>
>
>

ðŸ”—Michael <djtrancendance@...>

3/25/2010 8:40:49 AM

Chris,

I'm still looking for the "non-Silver" 14-tone scale but, basically, it's a variant on the below 7 tone scale (recently improved)

1.08333333333 = 13/12 (starting generator of bold mirroring)
1.21875 = 39/32 (3/2 - (24/13 over 3/2))
1.33333 = 4/3
1.5 = 3/2 (2 over 4/3)
1.66666666 = 5/3
1.84615 = 24/13 (AKA *2* over *13/12*)

The odd/"mirror generated" notes are in bold, the rest pretty much fit into the x/12 harmonic series. Anything that's not related to a "mirror" is the 3:4:5:6 chord.

The odd thing is that using other x/12 fractions IE the typical 1.25 (5/4) and 1.83333 (11/6) to replace the symmetrical/"mirrored" tones actually makes many chords in the scale dissonant and very few more consonant. So the scale tries to bridge the fine line between Silver(and PHI-sections)-Scale-type mirroring optimization and JI optimization.

Since I know you like fiddling with a degree of dissonance and more tones you can also throw in the extra mirrors
1.38461 AKA 18/13 (*3/2* / *13/12*)
1.777777777 AKA 16/9 (2 over (*4/3* / *39/32*))
1.125 AKA 9/8 (2 over 16/9)
for good measure to make the 10 tone scale of

1.08333333333 = 13/12 (starting
generator of mirroring (marked with bold font)
1.125 AKA 9/8 (2 over 16/9)
1.21875 = 39/32 (3/2 - (24/13 over 3/2))
1.33333 = 4/3
1.38461 AKA 18/13 (*3/2* / *13/12*)
1.5 = 3/2 (2 over 4/3)
1.66666666 = 5/3
1.777777777 AKA 16/9 (2 over (*4/3* / *39/32*))
1.84615 = 24/13 (AKA *2* over *13/12*)
.........though, unlike with the 7 tone version it becomes possible to make fairly sour/"off key" chords due much in part to critical band "closeness" issues.

Just for grins I'll try to figure out a 12 (or more) tone version of the 7-tone scale but all this mirroring is making my head hurt. ;-)

-Michael

ðŸ”—Michael <djtrancendance@...>

3/25/2010 11:05:40 AM

Chris,

In case you want a scale with more notes that's not the "modified/extended Silver Scale" yet has nearly as many tones and uses the same sort of mirroring (which proves strangely popular according ), here's a 12 note version.
If you take the modified 10-tone version of my modified 7-tone Ptolemic ratio scale IE

1.08333333333 = 13/12 (starting
generator of mirroring (marked with bold font)
1.125
AKA 9/8 (2 over 16/9)
1.21875 = 39/32 (3/2 - (24/13 over 3/2))
1.33333 = 4/3
1.38461 AKA 18/13 (*3/2* / *13/12*)
1.5 = 3/2 (2 over 4/3)
1.66666666 = 5/3
1.777777777 AKA 16/9 (2 over (*4/3* / *39/32*))
1.84615 = 24/13 (AKA *2* over *13/12*)

and add the following "mirrored" tones

1.92592 AKA 52/27 (2 * ((13/12) over (9/8))
1.562499 AKA 25/16 (5/3 / (16/9 over 5/3))

...you can get a full 12 tone scale of (drum roll please) :-)
****************************
1/1
13/12
9/8
39/32
4/3
18/13
3/2
25/16
5/3
16/9
24/13
52/27
(octave of 2/1)
****************************

Let me know if this one works for you. Hopefully your next "mirror scale" based composition will have 10,000 downloads instead of nearly 2000 (muahahaha!) ;-)

As a side note....Marcel, there may yet be hope for translating this scale for formal entry into your competition that maintains "proper" mood as now I finally have a 12-note version.

ðŸ”—Chris Vaisvil <chrisvaisvil@...>

I'll give this a shot!

Chris

3/25/2010 7:45:53 PM

Me>"
...you can get a full 12 tone scale of (drum roll please) :-)
************ ********* *******
1/1

24/13

(octave of 2/1)"

Chris>"ok Mike,
I'll give this a shot!
Thanks,"

Side note to Chris and any other one trying this scale out:

I found that tuning the middle C AKA 1/1 to about 75/76 * middle C =approximately 258hz realigns the tonal centers in such a way it works well for re-tuning 12TET pieces. I tried this with Beethoven's "Drei Equeli" (sp.?) and it works well with about 90-95% of the notes. Makes me wonder just how pitch and perhaps alignment with the basilar membrane can skew perception of intervals as, of course, many of the intervals in the scale are very non-12TET like.

ðŸ”—cameron <misterbobro@...>

3/26/2010 3:02:46 AM

Played through your scale and marked the notes that stuck out
a little- they turned out on examination to only those
without a superparticular relation within the tuning. This is the
slightly modified version I'd personally use. It is a
very good and musical sounding tuning in my opinion.

1/1 0.000 unison, perfect prime
13/12 138.573 tridecimal 2/3-tone
9/8 203.910 major whole tone
39/32 342.483 39th harmonic, Zalzal wosta of
117/88 493.120
63/44 621.418
3/2 701.955 perfect fifth
25/16 772.627 classic augmented fifth
5/3 884.359 major sixth, BP sixth
16/9 996.090 Pythagorean minor seventh
24/13 1061.427 tridecimal neutral seventh
25/13 1132.100
2/1 1200.000 octave
